headline: Race to the bottom
pros: The pay is not the worst in the industry.  The benefits are ok.
cons:
Coming from a company that was acquired by Schwab, it has been a truly depressing experience.  I used to love my job and I actually looked forward to coming to work.   I was proud what we built and delivered.  I left work feeling satisfied almost every day.  Those feelings are gone now as Schwab completes its acquisition.  Against my better judgement, I’m waiting a little longer for positive change that will probably never come.  I will more than likely follow in the footsteps as my coworkers who have found more rewarding careers elsewhere.

It you are looking for any kind of personal or professional development, this company isn’t the place.  That is especially true as far as technology is concerned.  This company is stuck 20 years in the past and seems set on staying there.

The culture is horrible.  There is absolutely no empowerment for you to do anything.  No matter how small, every decision requires a managing directors approval.  Most of your job is spent waiting for that approval.

Schwab is the epitome of a bureaucracy.  You will spend more time navigating audit, risk, compliance, governance, review boards, and any other committee than you will spend actually engineering and building things.  Schwab loves to blame the Federal Reserve for all their problems, but in actuality it is the company culture.

Morale is low across the board and the disengagement is very high.  It’s difficult to be inspired by a bunch of people who are more focused on limiting how much impact the company has on their personal well-being than they are about their work product.

My advice to any engineer with an ounce of self respect that is considering an offer from Schwab is, don’t do it.  Spend a little extra time looking at other opportunities.

Do not work here if you want growth, transparency, or empowerment. Plus, their benefits suck.

headline: Great Company - Limited Mobility
pros:
- Company culture: It'd be tough to find a better group of people to work with, both inside of internal audit or within the business. Very diverse team of extremely competent folks, with a big focus on work-life balance.

- Reasonable workload: Very few instances of serious crunch below the manager level. I worked at Schwab for three years and can count the number of times I had to work significantly after hours on one hand.

- Breadth of experience: As a new auditor, you get the opportunity to touch a lot of different areas of the business and make a meaningful impact. Critical thinking is encouraged and audit managers are highly receptive to ideas coming from the Specialist/Sr. Specialist-level folks.
cons: - Limited advancement/mobility opportunities: Raises are generally based on company performance rather than personal performance, and therefore are usually pretty small. Quarterly bonus payouts help, but don't make up for it when you're losing out to inflation. Additionally, the requirements for advancement aren't particularly clear. Having and continuing to acquire new certifications is the only way to gain any sort of chance at upward mobility, and while the company will reimburse you for the cost of exams/course materials, it's caused a lot of attrition.

headline: Terrible
pros: The company pays for your series 7 and 63 license.
cons: This is a 100% a call center job! You take between 30-60 calls a day with complicated task. You have to meet ridiculous call metrics but the company tries to make it seem like a client first job but wants you to get them off the phone if it over 9 minutes. Everything is heavily monitored, from your calls, your breaks, and lunches. Don’t even think about taking breaks in between calls it is almost prohibited. You get verbally abused by some clients and you can’t react or even hang up they just want you to sit there and take it and right back into another call. This job is mentally draining. I really can’t comprehend how it’s rated so high. It is temporarily remote but they are constantly pushing to get back in office. This job made me hate being in the comforts of my own home. Very high turnover rate job from the entry level positions to management! Low pay considering other companies and work load.

headline: Good pay but very stressful

headline: Financial Consutlant
pros:
The culture across the company is strong they have shown they have more of a pulse than other banks I’ve worked for
Products are competitive in a marketplace driven by fee compression
Tech is getting better
cons:
In my time at Schwab I worked at 3 different branch locations. Every branch felt like a different company though under the same leadership. Tenured FC’s would set rules and as a newer FC your weren’t suppose to question anything. As an FC you are at the mercy of branch support assigned to you. You are assigned a practice with hundreds of clients - if your CRS is not motivated to be an intergral part of sales and ops process and looks to just be there to collect a paycheck, eat company paid snacks and hide from any work and operate like this is Schwab of the 90’s ; it’s going to feel like quicksand and every year you sink even more! It’s pains me even more when I hear about FC’s getting support by younger more motivated CRSs out of call centers that want to move up in company and have a strong desire to be part of sales process. Branch leadership is missing in action/ has not clue about branch moral
At the moment. So much of the metrics don’t tell the complete story how some of the CRSs spend their time. We are small teams in the branch - one bad Apple can spoil and entire operating model. Managers need to find out who really wants to be there and who is just an actor

headline: Mediocrity can be bliss
pros:
Very supportive culture 
Everyone is friendly 
It’s very predictable 
Expectations are well understood 
Benefits are decent 
Not that much is really expected of you 
Work life balance is pretty decent
The people are so nice and the ones that made it off the phones are all brilliant
Schwab is a wonderful “I am tired, I could use a very steady retirement job” with no real responsibility, accountability, or meaning
cons:
Expect things to take years to change, if you’re lucky. Expect a meeting for every possible thing - including what the next meeting will be about. Expect to sometimes have more meeting scheduled than you do hours you are expected to work (most of which you will not actually be required to be at)
Expect your management to not really know products 
Expect their management to not really seem to know much of anything except that they have somebody higher up than them who also doesn’t seem to know very much 
Expect ceremony and to be agile in name only. You can have 4 hour quarterly sprint planning meetings. You can have weekly PPI meetings. You can make up KPIs to your heart’s content! It doesn’t matter that they don’t really tell you anything, simply put it on the confluence site and attend the meeting, dutifully giving an update about this meaningless KPI.

Once I told somebody where I work. They asked me “don’t you want more than this?” - and the truth is that the bureaucracy and ceremony here will beat you into accepting mediocrity. It’s not terrible, it’s just the sound of slowly dying.

headline: Corporate Environment
pros:
Schwab Management is inclusive of everyone and strongly advocates that everyone is involved. We have ERG (Employee Resource Groups -- that promote an inclusive environment for 11 different groups i.e.WIN- Women Interactive Network at Schwab, BPACS-Black Professionals at Charles Schwab, and MVN- Military Veterans Network). 

I have worked in the industry since 1996 and this is my second time working for Schwab (1997-2003 & 2018 - Present). Schwab has always been a great employer...except for a blip when Dave Pottruck was the President, thank God he is gone. 

Schwab is innovative and strives to treat clients and employees with respect and to the right thing for everyone involved.
cons: New reps need more training, it would cut down on the attrition, transfers to second level support groups and overall hold times.

headline: Metrics
pros: I can't think of any pros
cons: They set up your metrics goals to purposefully make it difficult to get bonuses and they intentionally calculate the employees reviews to make it as difficult as possible to get a raise. It is practically sheer luck if you have good enough metrics to increase your salary. Everything is timed so don't expect any down time. Its just call after call of toxic customers who are upset because their card doesn't work or any number of things. These customers are angry by the time they are talking to you so prepare to be called some inappropriate names. They don't give people promotions based on merit. You will be on the phone constantly.

headline: The best employer I've ever had!
pros:
-This company genuinely cares about you as a person. 
-Creativity and outside the box thinking is encouraged. 
-They go above and beyond to make you feel valued and appreciated. 
-There is SOOO much room for career growth! Whether it is vertically or laterally, the world is your oyster so to speak. 
-The pay is typically among the top contenders in most fields. 
-Growth is encouraged in all aspects, ranging from certifications to further education, to promotions within.
-Annual pay/merit increase
-Yearly bonuses
-Paid sabbatical every 5 years
-Great PTO and sick time benefits
-paid maternity AND paternity leave! 
-Access to special resources like counseling. 
-Free access to brokers through the Employee branch.
-Perfect work/home life balance!
-Roughly 2-3 skip level meetings where you get to meet with your 2nd, 3rd, and sometimes 4th tier leadership without your direct leadership involved. These meetings allow any opinions, questions, or concerns to be heard and addressed by upper leadership. Your voice matters.
cons: It sounds staged to say this, but I genuinely cannot think of any cons. Maybe the fact that Schwab doesn't trade cryptocurrency and as an employee, you can't be an account holder with competing traders could be considered a con? Honestly, that makes absolute sense though because it would be a huge conflict of interest.. Outside of that, the pros really outweigh any possible cons....

Schwab has a great corporate culture
Really does care about the client experience

headline: a company that says what it does and does what it says
pros:
This is one of the very few places I have been where the company vision is a integrated, supported, and part of the entire company. "Through our clients eyes" is a part of every employees day to day tasks. 

Security, and compliance, are not only at the top of the companies priority list, but security takes priority, no security issue is ignored, we live our work through our clients eyes, and I could not be more proud to work here!
cons: As with most large companies, things tend to move more slowly than people would like, that is really the only thing I can think of that may be a con.

headline: Throw you to the wall and see who sticks. Lengthy cautionary review for folks...
pros:
-Good work/life balance. When your shift ends you are absolutely done for the day. You bring nothing home with you
-Paid time off for license preparation (S7/63/66/etc.)
-Majority of managers are really solid individuals that care about you as a person. Honestly, I can't speak highly enough about my first manager.
-Decent benefits
cons:
Here is where things are going to get lengthy. First of all I want to start with some background...

I was a COVID-19 hire right out of college. Had no background in finance, but needed a job (when nothing else was available) so I applied at Schwab. Other reviews are exaggerating regarding the training process. There are 2 weeks of standard training, followed by 2 weeks of hybrid training/easy phone calls with clients (not just 1 single week like some people have mentioned). After that you are assigned to your team and thrown to the wolves. That is where I actually want to start this review.

People need to realize this is 100% a call center position. Schwab doesn't do a great job of explaining that to you during the interview process, or even on the application. I had numerous coworkers during my tenure that applied/accepted the position with no knowledge that they would be on the phones for 8 hours a day. Because of that, there are a lot of things you need to know going into the job. I will list some below.

-Your calls are HEAVILY monitored. You will have coaching once a week with your manager and you will basically randomly review calls with them. They can also pull calls at any time and listen in if they would like. Basically, whenever you are talking to a client, there is a chance someone in management is listening in the background.

-There are very strict metrics you MUST follow. You must hit your breaks on time. You must take a certain number of calls a day. You cannot take too long in between calls. There is a report sent out every morning that shows your specific metrics. They are not easy to hit and I saw numerous people (who I would consider bright) struggle to even hit the low end of the metrics.

-OSAT. Basically OSAT is the survey they send to clients regarding their phone call with you. They are absolute garbage. If a client gives you a 6 out of 7 on the survey, they counts as a ZERO. You must get a perfect 7 out of 7 in order for it to benefit you. Also, Schwab has a zero tolerance policy regarding these. I received a negative survey where the client had mistaken me for another rep (they had called in numerous times so it makes sense that they were confused as to who they had spoken with). That one "fake" survey is the reason why I missed a quarterly promotion (one of the final straws for me with Schwab). 

Now those things mentioned about aren't really "complaints". Pretty standard practice for a call center, but I think it's important for people to know what they are about to get themself into. Now let's talk about the real gripes I have with Schwab.

The pay is ATROCIOUS. After my first year with Schwab I had....

-Exceeded expectations every quarter
-Passed the SIE, S7, and S63 all on my first attempt
-Been nominated to the advisory counsel
-Taken zero sick/vacation days
-Was the highest performing individual on my team, even beating out tenured reps that had been there for decades.

At the end of my first year I was making $22 an hour. Absolutely ridiculous. I had friends teaching preschool making significantly more than me.

The time off process is a nightmare. Because it's a call center, they need a specific number of reps on the phone at all times. Goodluck getting off around the holiday season. You basically have to put in PTO requests months in advance. You're better off just taking sick days than dealing with their PTO system. Oh one more thing I almost forgot....you are required to work 2 holidays. Say goodbye to your labor day or memorial day weekend.

Their "professional development" plan is fine. They walk you through how it works from day 1, but actually moving up in the company is a nightmare. For the life of me I can't understand why there are individuals that have been there for more than a few years. Seriously, if you are a top performer and have been there for years, your pay will max out at around $30 an hour unless you go down the management route. If you think that you can "work at Schwab for years and slowly make your way up into the 6 figures range" that is NEVER going to happen.

Now for the big stuff. Their website and systems are TERRIBLE. Things break probably once a month, so when angry customers call in guess who has to deal with them......YOU! There was a period in 2021 where we had over 10,000 people on hold at once because our systems broke. People were waiting hours just to speak with a rep. It ruins the client experience, it makes the reps job basically impossible, and us call center reps were the ones who got penalized for that with all the terrible survey scores. There is nothing worse than hopping on the phones at 8AM only to see there were already 1000 calls on hold. I knew reps who literally broke down in tears on a call because they were so overworked. 

Finally, attrition and manager turnover is a nightmare. Within my first 3 months of working there every single person on my team had left and was replaced with new employees. During my tenure (of around 18 months) I saw probably 20 people come and go, just within my small team. The manager turnover is also insane. I had 6 different managers, some were great, some shouldn't be employed by Schwab. There is no consistency which makes the team dynamic really difficult.

Overall, if you are wanting to get into the financial services field I would recommend avoiding Schwab (or any big firm) like the plague. Go find a small advisory firm near you where they'll actually care about your growth and pay you an actual living wage. To Schwab you are just a number at a call center. They are constantly hiring for this position because people are constantly leaving.

They higher some great people, although support teams in phone centers seem to lack dedication and accountability.

Company has good offering for clients.

Company is among the most ethical in the industry.
cons:
Upper level management does not care about employees. They care about checking boxes and meeting quotas to help Schwab's share price.

Like mentioned before, support teams in phone centers don't follow through. I worked in the phone center as well, some great people there but management only cares about you being on the phone and nothing else.

This company pays less than most in the industry. They barely give raises.

Turnover is atrocious across the whole company. Stems from things I already commented on. Clients dislike this a lot.

headline: Industry Leading Company
pros: Schwab is big and getting bigger, but the people are a definite strength. Very conservatively run company with good pay and benefits, as well as solid financial products. Gorgeous new headquarters building.
cons: Typical problems you'd find in a huge company beholden to shareholders: profits seem to come first, with lots of reshuffling of people in past couple of years that resulted in major layoffs and restructuring. They talk a lot about the importance of culture, but I didn't find this to be true ... In all honesty, I felt more like a number than a valued team member.

headline: Good entry but very poor career
pros: You are afforded the opportunity to work with large clients whether you are truly ready or equipped to handle them. The clients will become the best part of the job. I would say this is a great place to learn but you will quickly realize at some point if you really want to expand your skill you will need to leave.
cons:
- lack of internal support from partners and managers. Everyone is bursting at the seams in work loads and try’s and defer work off to each other. 

- I regularly hit top 20% in the company but was consistently asked to do more and never recognized. I actually led my branch multiple times. 

- it becomes apparent this is a place to come learn but not a place you can build out a career as a financial consultant.

- micromanagement and lack of empathy or care to employees you are looked at as replaceable and a dime a dozen 

- lack of work life balance. I am not sure how someone can start a career here and have a family at the same time due to the unrealistic work load and lack of support. 

- turnover at all levels will cause you to train your fellow coworkers and will limit your own personal progression of knowledge

When I was with Schwab they were also pushing mandatory overtime, and making it part of your annual review.

headline: Strong company but has room for departmental improvement
pros: Overall company has great benefits, offers transparency, and frequently shows appreciation to employees. It feels like anything is possible in your career here.
cons: Project Services needs to be better aligned. Project managers are not prepared to lead coordinators looking to learn about the field. There is a culture of fault-finding as a path to being viewed as a leader amongst project teams and it is easy to feel incredibly isolated while working remotely as many teams don't even introduce you on calls. Program Directors are not as available due to heavy workloads and this role falls between the cracks until something goes wrong. Lastly, because all projects vary, your onboarding will vary if it is provided at all. If you don't know what questions to ask to prevent errors/issues, you will be held accountable despite expectations rarely being set.

headline: We're almost there
pros:
The company is here for clients, first and last. I feel empowered as a fiduciary on behalf of clients to be open and honest. I never feel like I'm selling to clients, or offering products/services they don't need.
Good benefits - insurance is decent, HSA is great, PTO/sick time and sabbatical every 5 years is wonderful. 
The collaborative environment is perfect to learn, grow, and develop your career. The options are almost limitless (for corporate). Once you get through your two years on the phones to doors are open to progress to wherever your ambition takes you.
Schwab offers $5k/yr reimbursement to complete your degree (undergrad or masters), or towards professional designations (CFP, CWS, etc.).
I am encouraged with the various Employee Resource Groups to actively volunteer in the local community (paid volunteer time!). The company as a whole is conservative corporate America, but I still feel seen and heard with the sponsored LGBTQ+ group and support from my coworkers and management. I'm proud to be a Schwabbie.
cons:
The FC comp structure is fairly standard but it still feels like I'm getting shortchanged. The inflation adjustment from 2021 to 2022 was minimal at best. 
The feeling of cranking the hamster wheel is real. If I'm not working I feel I am missing out on opportunities. Its part of the gig, doesn't make it any better though.

headline: Financial Crimes specialist
pros: Pros: partnering business units are very helpful; workshops hosted for financial health; employees are nice/helpful (for the most part).
cons:
Cons: training/on-boarding; career advancement seldom happens based on meritocracy; tied to your role for a year (unable to swap departments). 
Leadership strongly emphasizes hierarchical approach. Managers are unable to cover for their subordinates. Time off has a number of stipulations before you can actually get any time off. IT issues frequently, systems crash; play catch-up/fire drill.

headline: Not a great option for right out of college
pros: They are fixing the program to be more competitive, so they don't make you move to Texas anymore and you get hired with the branch you will work with rather than being randomly allocated to one.
cons: They call it a "rotational program" but its just customer service. They pay you the same as every other customer service rep even though you have more experience so you are grossly underpaid and they are profiting off of cheap educated professionals. The training is only 3 weeks and then they throw you in blind and its terrifying since you are moving a ton of money around and can easily mess it up. They don't tell you that you wont be working a 9-5, you work one of the schedules that's available, such as 4 days a week for 10 hours a day. It is so emotionally and physically draining, and they are always understaffed so you don't get breaks for your meetings like they say you will.

headline: Great Culture and Many opportunities for Advancement
pros:
I’ve worked for Schwab for 2.5 years and have had three salary raises/promotions and one job/role promotion into a new department. 

There are dozens of colleagues who are only willing to do the bare minimum, so management highly recognizes and rewards those individuals who go the extra mile. 

I entered the company as a Financial Service Professional (customer service line) with zero finance background and am now on the fast track to make an advisor role in their proprietary wealth management division.

The company will sponsor and pay for all materials for you to obtain security licenses. They even paid for my CFP education program at full reimbursement.
cons:
If you start off in the customer service line it can be very mundane and boring, but sticking it through pays dividends. 

Starting off pay initially is lower than competitors but in the long run Schwab does offer quarterly raises with no cap.

headline: Good company, role not so much
pros: Charles Schwab takes care of their employees, they do seem to care about how you are doing and want you to succeed.
cons: The role was really boosted up during the interview process, when in reality it is a call center job. You are tracked for every minute of the day using a detailed status, timed to the minute for everything you do. Your calls are tracked by the second, and constantly reviewed and picked over to choose what words you are using/not using. Also, although there is a very generous PTO package, the volume of business that Schwab is experiencing makes it so that getting PTO approved is much more difficult than it should be.

headline: Unethical, Monopolistic Company with an Abrasive Culture. Absolutely avoid if you work in UX or technology
pros:
- Pay and benefits are higher than the industry average. Schwab has more revenue and capital than they know what to do with.
- Schwab is massive company and there are many benefits that come with that, including opportunities to collaborate and learn.
cons:
Schwab's MO is "if we can't beat them, we'll buy them." They've bought dozens of companies over the years. Even though they're experienced with acquisition, they are not fair to the employees of the companies they buy. They bought my company and then did not provide any communication about lay-offs for months. They were silent on basic questions. As the merge started, they walled my colleagues off from their digital tools and infrastructure even as they required us to take on work. At every turn during the acquisition, they were either silent and confusing. They didn't take feedback from their newly acquired employees even though my department and leaders were much more knowledgable than theirs.

Schwab has a culture of passive-aggressiveness that is so widely known within the company that it has a name: "Schwab Nice." This is when colleagues are polite to your face and provide vaguely positive feedback, and then later demean and criticize in closed doors. Direct, honest communication is discouraged which undermines collaboration and productivity. 

Schwab is obsessed with share-outs, presentations, and other forms of superficial collaboration. If you need to give a presentation, plan on giving it several times over the course of a week. It's tedious.

Schwab likes to pretend that it's a technology company but Schwab is a financial company first and foremost. Because their MO is to buy up companies and then ignore the acquired companies' expertise, they don't have a culture, vision, or knowledge on how to effectively build digital products. Their process is waterfall, tedious and slow. They're stodgy. If you work in technology, you will be very frustrated here. 

Schwab is a stuffy, boring, unethical, toxic monopoly. I would highly encourage you to work at their competitors, at least until Schwab buys them.

headline: Wonderful role for people who are sales focused
pros:
Working at Charles Schwab provides opportunities to grow, work alongside like-minded people, and be a part of something bigger than yourself. From the top-down, you can feel the dedication that everyone plays to always be better and hussle to provide the best client experience. 

As an employee, it is expected that you perform at the top of your game. With that comes many perks and awards for your achievement. Whether it's being acknowledged for a year-long excellent service award or be recognized for an exceptional client experience, Schwab does right at making sure we feel special. The culture and expectations are to always put the client first.

This is a sales role. If you like sales and getting paid for it, this is the perfect role for you.

The pay is about average in the industry. As a financial consultant, you get a base salary plus sales pay. The base salary stays the same or fluctuates depending upon your level. The company offers 401k, healthcare, discounted employee stock, and other perks.

Through the pandemic, the company was accommodating to changes at home and was gracious in making sure employees were taken care of. 

The company has a high growth projection over the next 10 years and is amazing to be a part of an organization that started as the "small guy" back in 1975.
cons:
A financial consultant is a sales role. Plain and simple... With the high pressure from the top, you are required to perform based upon new assets, advice enrollments, good survey responses from clients, and planning. With these expectations in mind, financial consultants are at the mercy of our internal partners to make it all happen. In order to be successful and be congratulated by the company, you have to transfer the ownership of being a financial advisor to others all while doing as little planning and service as possible. This is compounded by the fact that Schwab started out as a discount broker and every client expects their assigned financial consultant to provide them with top-tier service. Even if the self-directed clients in your practice ignore all your emails/phone calls. When these clients call the 800 service line and get a bad experience (which happens often with lots of employee turnover), you get hit hard when they reply to a survey badly which counts negatively towards your numbers. Overall, this role is a grind and requires a lot of mental juggling to prevent you from getting too angry or upset.

As a frontline worker, there is a lot that goes into keeping the employees informed. The problem is that management/corporate are very disconnected from the client at this time. I'm not sure what information corporate is getting or what branch managers are feeding to the top. There is a lot of negativity in the branch environment right now. With that, I often find myself confused on the corporate conference calls because it's often regurgitated material from the news and/or conferences in prior quarters. What is also infuriating is that the company spends a lot of time talking about how good the company is from a performance and financial perspective while folks are being laid off left and right.

Another thing is scale. Schwab is so focused on the scale right now I nauseate from the word as it's seeping into a toxic work environment. The expectation to grow is good however now it is coming at the expense of cutting the client experience away with their dedicated financial consultant and letting high performers cut corners. As a result, employees are treated unfairly by management when they do not perform. From a pay/promotion perspective, your growth as a Financial Consultant is subjective from the branch manager which is not easily defined.

The one main gripe I have about the company is financial planning. They have stripped everything from the financial consultant role down to talking to clients and documenting the conversation. It's like stripping a chef from his kitchen. Now I sit on the outside while silently looking at the cooks as they try to put together a meal. It's a disconnected process entirely that often leaves the client with a bad experience. This is incredibly infuriating as many clients start tasting the half-cooking plate of slop and immediately leave to walk down the street to a competitor. Financial Consultants are on the hook on this and are incredibly stressed.

One last thing I will say is the incredible pressure from management. If you cannot deal with an ounce of stress or anxiety, DO NOT GO INTO THIS ROLE. After your initial training, you better have a pipeline ready to go and click the mouse, or else you will be getting a call from the manager who.... looks at numbers and tells you what you probably already know... "your numbers look bad, DO BETTER." With that being said, there is a little coaching and too many managers who have no expertise or have little experience being an advisor themselves.

headline: Pretty Typical Corporation
pros:
- If you get a good manager they can have a lot of pull in terms of raises and promotions
- In certain cases, you can rise quickly if you prove that you're talented
- The company has grown large enough that most recruiters/prospective employers will recognize the name
- FTEs tend to be good at their job
- Work/life balance tends to be good even at the non-OT exempt levels
cons:
- The tech stack is outdated (as other reviews have mentioned). This can make it difficult to find Sr. positions with other firms after you've been working there a while
- Heavy reliance on contractors; on many projects you will be brought in after the contracted portion of the team has already defined the architecture, leaving you to either limp along with painful design choices or redesign from the ground up
- The shift to remote has not gone well. There have been several well-meaning attempts to reward employees for their loyalty to the company, but it seems like no one truly looked at the cultural impact of staff working from home to determine how it could be mitigated
- Your yearly raise and bonus are highly dependent on your relationship with your manager and director. If they like you, the raise/bonus will usually be good. If they don't, they won't fight for you in the roundtable discussions and your raise/bonus will suck

headline: Technology needs a top down culture transformation
pros: There are some very talented individuals in the organization. There is access to an extensive amount of training material and online courses and funding opportunities for external courses.
cons: Schwab needs a top down culture transformation in the technology organizations. The existing leadership is not capable of delivering that. They are 15-20 years or more behind industry peers maturity and capabilities and that is largely unacknowledged and unrecognized amongst leadership. There is a complete absence of engineering culture, product management, and leadership. There is a preference to reward firefighting and completely ignore fire prevention. Management culture also prefers to subjectively talk and PowerPoint problems to death instead of using data analysis to help drive faster decision making and movement toward resolution. Nothing Schwab is doing with technology is groundbreaking or innovative. The majority of the work is to address problems many other larger enterprises already solved 10-15 years ago. Schwab needs to learn how to listen to and use this experience and knowledge from the individual team members who bring much of this experience to the table. Much of the problems are people and process issues and not simple technology gaps.

headline: Tough-on-people environment, Poor match of leadership “say” vs. “do”
pros: There are some truly smart, thoughtful people who want to make the company stronger and more innovative into the future. I have worked with a truly stellar team of people that I would wholeheartedly endorse.
cons:
If not for others experiencing similar challenges, I might be questioning whether things really are so bad, but unfortunately, this has undeniably been among my worst experiences with an employer. The quote, “Culture eats strategy for breakfast,” rings true here.

I came to Schwab via its acquisition of TD Ameritrade, and what anyone might expect to be a challenging integration of two large companies was made so much worse than it should have been. In terms of the work itself, I was unable to garner the level of respectful engagement, active leadership support, or tangible resources within the organization to effectively do what I needed to get done – the work I’d been tasked to lead. There were a lot of jokes among Schwab veteran employees about how slowly things move – even adopting a new piece of software can take months or even upwards of a year. 

I communicated with my direct manager regularly about the persistent barriers my team was facing and the decline in morale that came with talented people not being able to make meaningful progress. The conclusion was that I, personally, was the problem, because they knew that I was not feeling a fit with the role and the organizational culture. This has been frustrating on a very personal level, and I have plenty of painful anecdotes I could share. But more importantly, in an organization facing a very high attrition rate overall, and with mental health of employees front-and-center as a major issue, having leadership say that the problem resides with individuals and not in the system strikes me as dangerous. In my final few weeks of working at the company, my manager talked both about promoting me and about potentially terminating me, which illustrates the lack of clarity about what the organization (or perhaps my manager) wants or needs – even when asked directly and repeatedly.

headline: Stay Away From Advisor Services - It’s a Parasitic Department
pros:
- The Company itself is great. No complaints there whatsoever. 
- Absolutely no Pros about Advisor Services right now. 
- Somewhat promote getting additional FINRA Licenses. 
- I have a job and my bills are getting paid.
cons:
- Advisor Services is a Port-a-Potty right now, especially Premier Wealth Group. 
- unrealistic expectations
- leadership takes no responsibility/ownership 
- leaders don’t take the time to learn, not even a little, and nor do they even remotely understand how you add value to the business in your role or what you even do on a day to day (working with Billion $ Advisors). Such a crappy feeling being told to do more and more and what we’re doing is not enough. 
- all metrics and quality of work are subjective
- can’t get work done in your 8 hour work day, so be prepared to work weekends if you want to hit your numbers and get a good annual review/bonus 
- TOXIC work environment 
- technology sucks
- company does not invest into its employees
- SEVERE micromanagement 

Take a lower paying job with none of these things listed above. If you value your time, your sanity, and your patience, until this department is under better leadership, you might want to think twice about making the career shift to this area.

headline: Project Services is a Toxic Environment
pros:
A focus on the customer and relationships. 
A culture of 'Schwab nice.'
Benefits that encourage saving.
cons:
An overwhelming lack of project management knowledge and maturity at the VP level.
A gross misuse of the experienced PM's Project Services says it wants with a consulting background.
A good ole boy network with a belief they are fine doing what they are doing.
PM's do not drive anything; only report status; no ownership at all.
60% of my projects, where PM's are not allowed to manage the budget, were fiscally reckless by large magnitudes.
Only the chosen few get their bonus or get promoted.
Schwab boasts it will not tolerate retaliation, but if you speak the truth in a lessons learned session, retaliation will be real and imminent.
The VP's are a kind of a thug mafia, and their lack of competency is costing Schwab tens of millions of dollars every year - which could easily be avoided.

headline: Really nice people, really slow adoption of needed strategic change
pros: The ethical culture is very strong and most people are honest, competent, and easy to work with. Offices are new with great amenities onsite. Certain technology teams (Cloud implementation, data science, data modeling, digital products) bring in great people and do great work with the best-in-class tools and mature delivery processes.
cons: Many people management policies are antiquated and don't reflect the majority technology focus of the current organization (e.g., requiring everyone to work in the office even when the entire team was disbursed across time zones and would never be in the same space; offering very limited PTO except for a 6 week sabbatical every 5 years; rarely supporting continuing education and certifications). Quarterly layoffs following each merger and acquisition are demoralizing. Many critical technology functions are bogged down by middle management bloat and supervisors with more business than technical skill. Feedback from employees is collected often but not implemented. Management is rarely transparent about major changes within the organization and teams are often in a reactionary state to recover from impacts rather than being able to plan along to minimize disruptions.

headline: Best in class work experience
pros: A strong culture of respect, support, and kindness provides a foundation for every employee at Schwab. I appreciate the thoughtful way Schwab approaches all aspects of employee development and care. I feel like my manager is an advocate who thinks about and works to secure my future. Schwab ERGs allow me to be involved in things that matter to me, including supporting equity for Black and LGBTQ Americans. Schwab demonstrates the best of what corporate America can be.
cons: Schwab is working towards more diversity at the executive committee level, but, objectively, it's not there yet. I would love to see Schwab further commit to environmental responsibility--and demand it of vendors (like the Schwab Cafe). There is some good effort there, but this is an opportunity to lead that aligns with Schwab's orientation toward planning and preparing for the future. I would like to see only organic gardening practices on site (no damaging herbicides or pesticides), re-use of our own composting, reliance on reusing dishes and silverware (removal of plastic options), and investing in renewable energy infrastructure (solar, wind, geothermal) on campuses.

headline: Big culture changes needed
pros:
- Schwab has multiple programs you can enter to explore career pathing and leadership skills.
- Schwab is attempting to make a culture shift away from the financial services “boys club” at a grassroots level
cons:
- There is a deep lack of diversity on the board and C-suite so the decisions made typically cater to the male workforce who are not primary caretakers. The CEO regularly positions bettering our clients in opposition to bettering our workforce.
- If you are in a role that is client facing, you do not have the autonomy to disconnect a call if a client is being verbally abusive, including using racial slurs. Your metrics that your career progression is based will suffer if you have an accent or name that sounds foreign to a client because you are scored on what the client thinks of you and never an objective and educated reviewer, such as a manager. 
- Sexual harassment is typical in entry level roles in Client Service and Support, frequently being perpetrated by managers and overlooked by directors

headline: Politics run rampant... it's exhausting
pros: Decent pay. Some really good people to roll through the punches with. Attempt to accommodate work-life balance for lower-level employees.
cons:
Execs are extremely out of touch with the reality of their workforce. They don't have the time to address or consider lower level desires to be heard (unless of course it is a benefit of the client) 
The idea that a happy workforce will take better care of clients is completely lost here. 
Instead how "Through the clients eyes" is enforced is by a cutthroat political environment driven by titles and personal agendas. Progress is accomplished by enforcing fear of mistakes. 
If you don't have Managing Director or higher in your title, don't bother expressing an opinion or contributing in any meaningful way. (Also, if MD or or above is in your title, do not expect to ever unplug during time off. You WILL have to call in for important meetings). Instead put your head down, keep your mouth shut, and do what you're told. Straying from this will likely be a political misstep causing you to be blacklisted for eternity.
Oh and if you need something from a partner dept. be prepared to throw around an SVP's name to get any sort of response. 
The benefits and time off are also pretty terrible until you've spent 10 years at the company. Sabbaticals are the carrot dangled in front of your face as a reason to not improve, but by the time you get a sabbatical you are so beyond burnt out, that it is a saving grace to return your mental state to semi-coherent.

headline: Great Place to Learn

headline: A cult-like experience with many pleasant people
pros:
The compensation is good. Many Schwab colleagues are very nice people. It can be a strange environment for outsiders and newcomers, but many Schwabbies have figured out that if you keep your head down and do your job, you can have a long, fruitful career here.

As long as the cultural issues don't collect on their debts, the company will likely continue to remain profitable.
cons:
This is an arrogant company that truly believes it is humble. A lot of people who work at Schwab have only ever worked at Schwab, and since they love Schwab and think it's the best company, they truly believe that everything Schwab is doing must therefore be perfect. Many Schwabbies have no outside experience against which to judge this assessment. I value continuous improvement and vigilance against stagnation, but I have been told many times that Schwabbies don't like to hear that they aren't the best, so be careful about implying things could be better. 

Meanwhile, there have been many new hires in the past year, plus thousands of people who came in from the TD Ameritrade and USAA acquisitions. So there are the career-long devotees and then more than 10,000 relatively new employees who don't understand the peculiar culture they've arrived in. There are significant cultural disconnects as a result.

Our employee technology is woefully inadequate, but since we have to pretend we are the best at everything, leaders tell us how great our tools are. If you have ever worked at another company, or have a spouse or friends who work at another company, or if you are even aware of other tools, you know this is not true. So which is it, are our leaders lying to us, or are they that out of touch that they believe they're telling the truth?

Looking outward to our clients, our technology and product offerings lag behind our competitors, yet we praise ourselves for being innovators and disruptors.

I don't know how this say-do gap changes. Middle-managers behave in a manner that suggests they are terrified of senior management. This is not a culture that tolerates managing up, because the most senior executives are perceived to be infallible. It is common for Executive and Senior VPs to not speak directly with employees below the VP level; those employees must go through a VP intermediary. Consequently, the middle layer is bogged down through relentless bureaucratic complexity and the illusion of collaboration and productivity.

Leadership comes across as very arrogant and out of touch, but they will constantly tell you how humble they are. They avoid direct interaction and stifle opportunities for direct feedback. Recently the company mechanism for asking questions of leadership was taken away because questions were perceived to be too negative.

headline: It's a big place, your results may vary
pros:
Good opportunity to learn about fintech.
If you're smart you eventually become mostly "irreplaceable".
Plenty of opportunity to engage in a lot of different aspects of the business side if you're good at inter-networking. 
There are quite a few truly brilliant folks who have longevity with the company.
cons:
Heavy dependency on visa-workers means subject matter expertise can evaporate on legacy systems, leaving someone holding the bag.
Innovation through automation is celebrated in conversation but won't manifest outside *your* personal jurisdiction of concern.
Distrust of their own development staff leads to wonky procedures that ultimately get rubber stamped but cause significant overhead.
Introduction of new pay tiers that ultimately resulted in a pay cut for (some) staff.
When something doesn't make sense, it's probably politics.
When you are now blocked today after getting the green light on yesterday, it's probably politics.
The manager-led-forum that us schwunderlings receive their bonuses/compensation lends itself to the public speaking ability of their immediate manager - basically if your manager isn't good at it, you won't get a good raise.

headline: Rose colored glasses
pros:
Good on boarding process. You will retain relationships that you make during that process.
Depending on your team you may find some genuine friends. 
There are flexible with Holiday and Sick time.
The Opportunities to obtain any FINRA Series license imaginable is available.
You will look forward to signing on for work everyday if you have a good bond with some of your colleagues.
cons:
Putting for Vacation for the Prime Holidays like Thanksgiving and Christmas is Virtually impossible to book PTO during Thanksgiving or Christmas so family will be disappointed. 
You have to be an emotional punching bag for clients that have a high net worth.
Lunches are only 30 minutes with two 15 minute breaks. 
Overtime is few and far between and is taken up quickly.
Team members MAY through you under the bus if it isn't a tight nit group.

I say all of this with Rose colored glasses as this is my first real job out of college so I have been "burned" yet. But I would still consider the things I listed as Cons to be valid points never the less.

headline: Terrific people and culture, but not at the cutting edge of technology
pros: The work culture at this financial institution is comforting and just about everyone I've worked with wants to help and collaborate instead of fostering a competitive and selfish environment. There's a lot of ERGs that were actually nice to be a part of and there's a sense of community across several of the teams. In general, teams are laid back and work isn't stressful. Pay is decently competitive.
cons: The lax working culture at Schwab comes with slower rollouts of breaking edge technology and platforms. Employees are on MS Teams and using agile but it's definitely a few years past it's due. Several of the internal applications and services haven't been updated in what feels like over a decade. Upper management pushes for newer working models but they are implemented much slower than they should.

headline: A large cargo ship made in the 1990s
pros:
Competitive Pay - Salary and perks can be above average under the right conditions
Acceptable benefits - Average benefits compare to any B/C tier well-known companies but sits far behind from FANG
Time-off policy - time off balance builds up fast and you can cash out at departure. 30 day sabbatical for every 5 years(subject to change)

Overall, this is an old fashioned Fin(not FinTech, there is a difference) to stay and coast. You can comfortably sit and ride the wave for a long time. It is suitable for anyone that doesn't have a good amount of ambition or drive to change.
cons:
It's important to say this upfront: Schwab is extremely silo-ed by large business units. This means the head of the BU will directly impact the experience you are going to have with this company as a whole. Pay attention to what type of comments are left and their positions. There is an overwhelming amount of negative reviews from folks who worked in IT field, which I can personally attest to. 

keeping it real and simple:  Schwab IT brings you back to the 1990s and the management is proud of it. Senior management, middle management and so called "tech leads" are so busy keeping up with the image while simple tasks can't be executed smoothly. You will be stopped and challenged every step of the way for bringing in new ideas. The reason behind that is simple, fake image is more important than actual productivity. 
Not many of us wants to be a hero, I get it. This is a great place for anyone that just want to sit and chillax. Nobody does anything effectively anyways, and it's the norm.

headline: ok.

headline: Growing by acquiring
pros:
Giant company. Incredibly profitable.
And, yes, of course they are hiring (because if any company posts even just one job opening, then technically they are "hiring").
cons:
They keep swallowing other companies whole, to where it now feels like we are all bogged down by far too much. This is during unprecedented times of record market activity. Client accounts, assets, data centers, technologies, products = all need to be migrated over. They plan to accomplish this by way of: far too many meetings, and entirely too much bureaucracy, and review boards. Everything feels top down, with way too many layers of management. But seems they have a solution to too many people... so,

The worst part is they have been doing, and are committed to continue with: Quarterly cuts! - this is mostly to legacy TDA, but also legacy schwab staff as well, this will be for the next few years! They have repeatedly communicated that reductions will continue until a little after the TD Ameritrade conversion is completed. So, likely until ~ 2024! Really horrible atmosphere, and feeling overall. If you seek any sense of stability, or being valued by an employer as more than just some $$ number to them, then look elsewhere.

headline: Horrible management! Slow processes!
pros: You will get a paycheck
cons:
I was working on building a product that they decided to de-prioritize. (Fair enough, it happens.) My team and I were moved into a new position with no discussion around our interest in the work or any overview of the scope or new expectation. It was clear that instead of treating us like individual we we’re just resources to the firm. The new product had 3 “owners”... getting alignment on the goal took 4 months! No work was done for month while management very slowly debated the politics of how this work would get accomplished. In the meantime about 8 of us sat around with no work. And when we asked how to be valuable we were told we were being too needy! When they finally decided to kick it off they assigned so many ppl to the team and several additional layers of management. Schwab loves process and hierarchy, but these teams are so bloated. I worked for a different financial services company previously doing the same work with half the ppl bc they actually empowered us to do our job. No one at Schwab is empowered to make decisions except leadership so it takes forever to get buy in. They’ll tell you it is because they are “nice” so they need to be “inclusive”. But you can be nice by being fair, trusting your team, and allowing them to efficiently do their work - none of this happens at Schwab.

I’d suggest anyone who is considering joining Schwab should interview the team to understand how decisions get made and what process you’ll be required to follow. If you are looking for a fast past exciting place to work this won’t be a good fit. If you want to put client needs first and think about innovation you’ll get frustrated quickly. Most of your time is spent in meetings telling ppl about the work you’re doing than actually doing any work.

headline: BEWARE
pros:
- Moderate healthcare and dental benefits. 
- 401k matching. 
- HSA with health rewards/contributions
- Ability to opt into company stock plan
cons:
- If you’re not a kiss-up, you won’t be promoted.

- The organization's leadership has no grasp of work-life balance nor any real openness to true innovation. Whether it is as a broker, tech support, advisor services, SPS, global, operations, etc they burn everyone out to the point of quitting. There is spectacular mismangement and horrible non-existent planning on every level and in every department.

- Misogyny and double standards is very much alive here. Many women colleagues encountered sexual harassment here and had to file claims against these men. What I learned - HR is clearly there to protect the company and not the employees.

- The executives and "leadership" pretend to care about their employees, and it is shocking that any employee actually buys that BS. Schwab underpays compared to every other company whether you're in wealth management, information systems, product management, cyber security, etc.

- Weak, out-of-touch, cringey company who were one of the last financial companies to go remote when COVID hit. Constant emails "regretfully" telling all employees that they are expected to come into the offices despite Covid, because "current technology can't support us all working from home at the same time" - which of course was a lie. The following week everyone was working from home, because of the enormous uproar and pushback. They are itching to send the company back to the offices.

- The sales pitch often told is that "there are SO MANY departments to advance into and Schwab will support your career pathing!" Don't be fooled, career growth is met with so much resistance. You're expected to remain in a role for at least 1-2 years even if you express that the job is not a good fit and you're miserable. Expect to be pigeon-holed and not genuinely helped to move into a more suitable role. You will likely be stuck working on a team or product where you don’t get to use your full skillset and will stagnate.

- Cafe is expensive, parking sucks, out-dated systems and no autonomy. You are treated as a order taker, not as an adult with a brain. 

- The cheap chinese food, pizza and kid-sized candies are the common choice when trying to elevate the company's morale or to celebrate a massive achievement. We're not college students, put more thought behind your gifts and rewards. 

- No retention bonuses nor company profit-sharing bonsues.

headline: Ok job for financial professional
pros: Not forced to push annuities. Breadth of solutions to recommend to clients. Flexibility of advice. Really a great suite of investment options for clients.
cons: Some sales goals aren’t the most realistic with an older client base. Probably easier role in a metro market or near large employers with many employees. Pay is fair, not fantastic. 3-6% of ongoing revenue goes to FC. IE 6% of 71bps in management fees on $500k account or $213 per year for 1/2 million managed acct and $1k sales pay. At the time sales pay for new conversions was $2k per million in assets in managed accounts. For things that are more outsourced and lower FC time such as robo-advisor or 3rd party RIA it was 1/2 to 1/3rd of that for ongoing pay. Sales pay was the same assuming you correctly checked all the boxes to qualify. Definitely want emphasis on sales vs retention. Mostly variable Comp. Newer products reflect margin compression of roboadvisors and subsequent pay reduction for robo-advised funds. Benefits ok, not fantastic. Ok 401k match, 6% I believe. 15% discount on some stock purchasesup to 10% of your pay.

headline: Great place to grow.
pros:
Sky is the limit when it comes to personal growth. If you put your best foot forward and you are serious about your own development you will have many opportunities to grow. WLB is great. Resources are available and at your disposal. I went from intern, developer, grew into a sr. engineer, technical lead and now I lead several teams.

 

Went through leadership program we offer among other trainings and it really helped me succeed in my current roles and future roles.

 

I recommend Schwab at any level in your career.
cons: There can be some process overhead with the amount of red tape but we are working to improve and automate.

headline: Great Place to Work!

At Schwab, you can chart your own career path based on the things that you're interested in. Leadership is always willing to help you towards your goals and provide their support.
cons: I wish there was more flexibility in working from home.

headline: Great opportunities with supportive management
pros: Great culture, people here are smart, talented and take pride in what they do. I've enjoyed working here for 5+ years now. It's a growing company and opportunities are there for those who want and put in the work to advance. Really friendly and inclusive work environment.
cons: Like any company this size, there are bad managers/people in every group. Certain organizations are better than others and your experience here will largely depend on which organization you are a part of.

headline: Prepare for some angry clients
pros: Experience speaking with clients, paid study time, training, support thru academy, direct path to becoming an FC, coaching, community, culture
cons: Constant website malfunctions, often resulting clients to not having access to funds and volume spikes. The customer service line is understaffed, leading to long hold times and angry clients. Difficult to communicate with branches when clients want to make an appt. Performance based heavily on client rating, which is not in your control if they are frustrated with company. Timelines for testing and bonuses also delayed heavily. This job is incredibly taxing on mental health and only leads to one career at the company- being an FC.

headline: The worst financial services company I ever worked for
pros: You will get a paycheck, and there are benefits. However, if you are a single parent with young children, and high medical bills , think twice. The Medical Plan is an HSA with a high deductible. Schwab did contribute $1,000 / year, but that is still way below the out-of-pocket max ( $5,000+ for family) . I personally saw several single moms struggle because of this. However, for a person who wants to reduce their taxable income, and can afford to max out the annual contributions, the HSA would be attractive.
cons: Ever since the present CEO took over, salaries , and benefits, have been under constant attack year after year. Don't be fooled by a seemingly decent starting salary, and talk about a big bonus. You will quickly find that no matter how strong your performance is, your raises will be below par, and you never get the max bonus that was mentioned during the interview process. It is a classic "bait and switch strategy". The only way to truly get ahead is to keep getting promoted to higher paying positions. To get a true perspective, read the negative reviews, and avoid the one or two sentence positive reviews, they are planted by management, and the talent acquisition people. They truly know how to work the ratings system, and make this horrible company seem appealing. BEWARE!

headline: DON'T WORK HERE!!!!!
pros: Good benefits and pay similar to any big company.
cons:
This is a micro-managed sales position and not a career. Branch Managers put immense pressure on reps to SELL to clients awful products, when the clients don't want it in the first place. Every day you have meetings to discuss how many contacts you made, how many buttons you clicked, etc. You are constantly in a negative environment and the Rep turnover his huge. One rep will be fired every year, and the rare 1% of reps that have been there more than 10 years are favored and fed the best leads.

You will be forced to SELL product to clients and not develop good relationships. Once you are FORCED out by branch managers you will have nowhere else to work because they have a strong legal team that comes after you. They care more about their Branch Managers and upper management than they do clients or their reps. 

You will likely not last more than 3-5 years and then you will have to start all over building your client base anyway. Just start somewhere else and never do business with Schwab.

headline: Have an exit strategy
pros: Good benefits. Due to company marketing, it is easy to get new clients.
cons:
Goals increase EVERY quarter. You will NEVER stop selling. It is a "bait n switch" where you tell clients how bad other firms are and how much they charge... then once they are at Schwab, you try to sell them on a Schwab service where they pay a fee. 
Now that the TD merger is complete - Management plans on laying off 1k people every quarter for the foreseeable future. Many of those that will be targeted will be older FC's that have sizeable practices. The goal from management is to "manage those FC's out" and then take their book (which Schwab owns) and divide it amongst the younger and newer FCs.

headline: Great company on tech side, if you can avoid the management politics
pros: Good pay, good benefits, paid sabbatical after 5 years, good work/life balance and generally laid back work culture on the tech side. Great campus, but is also offering expanded work from home post-COVID
cons: Upper Management is bloated and often times ineffective, seemingly at odds with each other at times. Will go through layoffs fairly often, and they seem to always layoff some of the best team members when they do, while toxic ones linger or worse, climb the ladder. The company is also constantly waffling on how much development they want to be offshore, and often times the agile team structure breaks down due to missing support or a team that is simply too large.

headline: The Worst Culture I've Ever Seen
pros: Healthcare Benefits are better than some smaller companies.
cons: Overworked. Since I joined a year ago, we've lost at least 25-30% of our group. The culture is terrible. Something as simple as an database update takes 5-6 months because other groups within Schwab are incredibly slow and inefficient. The culture is so much a blame culture that it is sickening. There is no ownership, even among leadership. Everything is someone else's problem.

headline: Cisgender White Men are welcome to apply
pros: Get your licenses, get something that looks impressive on a resume
cons: This place is an HR nightmare. If you wear pants and you are a woman, you get reported. If you turn down someone's advances or report them to HR when they become extremely unprofessional, you get retaliated against. I was repeatedly sexually harassed by clients on a recorded line and nothing was done about it leading to more conversations in the future with that person. Women can only get so far before they are told they cannot advance because of their "brand". They hold you to impossible call center standards and push corporate BS like "World Class Service" down your throat. Abusive clients get to stay depending on how much money they brought in. Ever since budget cuts we saw hardworking, loyal coworkers get laid off and benefits/ treats in the office went away. They couldn't even afford to give out Chuck's book to everyone. WFH was a disaster and they gave you equipment that made it impossible to work, but you got reprimanded for not doing your job with said equipment. Forced OT, forced overnight and weekend shifts, forced working holidays. People are promoted to manager roles based on their personal relationships. If you speak up on something that is not right, you get retaliated against. I and several other people who have worked there are literally traumatized. They even pick and choose who to give 2 weeks pay to when you put in your notice. I was immediately let go without pay for that professional courtesy, and others in my exact position were let go with pay. They make it seem like if you are at the call center, you can advance to any department you like but the reality is that there are few departments hiring and they mostly pick internally. You don't get your own desk and have to compete with your coworkers to get a desk to work at. If you get sick for more than 3 consecutive days you have to file for short term disability with Sedgewick, who are highly unorganized. Programs are archaic and crash surprisingly often for such an established company. Most of your time at the job is helping the elderly work their computer. This is an actual high school. 100% don't recommend past getting your license and if you're desperate for money.

headline: Great Employer
pros:
I work in the call center for help with 401k plans. Pros include:
-No prior experience required (truly none, I had zero experience with call centers or finance before being hired)
-Friendly Staff
-No pressure to make sales
-Generous bonuses
-Very little over time required (1-3hrs of OT is typically mandatory each year), but if you want more overtime, it’s available.
-Great career development opportunities (they prefer to promote from within and there’s a ton of departments you can jump to)
-Lots of work schedules to choose from (IE 4x10 shifts available, early morning teams, closing teams, normal 9-5 also available)
-Career stability (Schwab is a smart company, they manage their operations well. I am never worried over potential layoffs, even when the pandemic first hit).
-Corporate culture is the best I’ve ever experienced. Management is down-to-earth and realistic. Goals are never absurd. Communication is open. They actually make the improvements you recommend.
-If you’re not great at managing your finances now, you will be after working at Schwab for a few months. Financial literacy is a side effect of the job, which can put you in a much better place for your own retirement goals.
cons:
-There is a steep learning curve in the beginning. If you have prior experience with retirement plans or even call centers in general, you’ll likely adapt pretty quickly. For everyone else without this experience, expect a few difficult weeks as you take it all in. Initial training is around 4-6 weeks. They can’t cover everything that will come up, so after training, the first 4-8 weeks on the phones can be a bit stressful. Once you’ve acclimated to the environment, the job becomes pretty simple after that.
-Various technology systems need improvement, but they aren’t unmanageable.
-It’s a call center, so you’re busy most of the day. There are slow hours for early morning teams, and closing teams.

headline: Good for a large company and if your goal is to be a financial advisor in the branch
pros:
They try to be engaging 
They have various employee groups
Will pay for you to study and get licensed
Great if you want to eventually become a financial consultant in a branch 
Opportunities for overtime
You never have to work beyond your scheduled hours on the phone, and if you do you get overtime.
cons:
In this role taking inbound calls, it can be very stressful and monotonous to just answer call after call
Way too strict about clocking in and out at times (taking your lunch from 12:06-12:38 instead of 12:00-12:30 is frowned upon)
Not a lot of upward opportunities if you don’t want to work in a branch 
Pressure to try and “sell”, get people to bring in more money or sign up for managed accounts.

headline: Overwhelming
pros:
Schwab will pay for your licenses and give you paid time to study. 
Some of the people are very friendly and care about you
cons:
No time for development. It is constantly canceled due to call volumes being high. Some of the managers and coaches only see you as a number. They dont want you to quit cause it reflects badly on them. 
Since the minimum to open an account at Schwab is 0$. You will have clients calling in with 100$ screaming at you because they have a restriction on their account.

headline: Growth opportunities

headline: Not for young professionals
pros:
- People are generally nice 
- Decent work life balance 
- Good place to be to retire
cons:
- Very outdated technology stack, decades behind, many legacy systems still around. No long term roadmaps to get on with the times, only band-aid solutions, reliant on many manual processes that should’ve been automated a decade ago.
- Old school culture with little flexibility and the leadership mindset is stuck in the 90s. 
- Poor PTO policy and a high deductible health plan 
- Limited opportunities for growth, difficult to move internally, switch teams or departments 
- Cheap company when it comes to everything including paying market wages.
- Constant layoffs and re-orgs. Once you settle into a new org, it’s time to change management again and re-prioritize everything, nothing gets done
- Company growth through mergers  rather than any innovation 
- No resources dedicated to growing employee skillsets (no budget for training courses, conferences etc.)

headline: Great Place to Hone Your Leadership Skills!
pros:
-Schwab has provided me the opportunity to learn a new industry. Not everyone hired at Schwab comes from a background in finance.
-I have had the opportunity to grow industry and role knowledge while also receiving coaching to develop my brand and refine soft skills such as coaching and communication skills.
-A huge investments was made into me by having the opportunity to get my FINRA Series 7 and 66 licenses, and later the Series 9/10. 
-I was offered opportunities to refine my coaching skills, which peaked my interest in Schwab's Aspiring Leader Program (ALP).
-The ALP program helped me dive head-first into the philosophy and practice of service-oriented leadership.
-Shortly after being accepted into the program I was offered a leadership position in my department, and I frequently use the information I learned through ALP to drive strong results with my team.
cons: This is not the company to apply to for people looking for a job that is laid-back with minimal role responsibilities. People at Schwab work hard and are challenged to leverage their skillset and strengths to drive positive results for our clients and customers.

headline: Overall very positive experience
pros:
-It's a great brand and the company operates with its clients' best interest in mind. Schwab has been a positive force for retail investors since its inception. There's a lot of pride involved with that, and low-level employees all the way up to Chuck himself really do care about doing what's right for clients. 
-Interesting projects to work on, depending on where you land 
-Most managers are very engaged and encouraging when it comes to career development
-The vast majority of people at Schwab are extremely nice, down to earth, and helpful people
-Competitive benefits, including 6 weeks parental leave for mothers and fathers
-Since covid, there seems to be a very positive shift in the outlook for ongoing remote work opportunities
cons:
-Given the size of the firm and reluctance to take on risk, the company tends to move extremely slowly when it comes to enacting change.
-Difficult to get anything done without executive buy-in and project funding
-The company takes risk-aversion to another level, which makes it difficult to get things done
-Working in silos tends to be the norm
-In a zero-commission, zero interest rate environment, the company is extremely focused on expense management. Job security isn't what it once was.
-Very focused on managing quarterly earnings. Expense freezes pre-covid were commonplace (hiring freezes, travel freezes, etc.)
-The company is oftentimes penny-wise but pound-foolish

headline: Great company to work for but lacks innovation
pros: If you do your job and meet your metrics, they take care of you. Plenty of opportunity to contribute and make a difference within team and center, but it’s up to you to find the opportunity. There is a lot of overtime and incentives so you can work as much as you want. I have worked for several different finance firms and Schwab is the only one that is actually diverse.
cons: It’s so busy with no signs of stopping or relenting and it is incredibly draining work. Upper management is slow to adopt changes and slow to hire additional reps. Often times it feels like they are just putting a band aid on a problem instead of fixing it. Schwab as a whole is very slow to adopt new tech or implement changes, and the clients/reps feel the brunt of that. Slow to update ridiculously outdated procedures. It’s pretty hard to move from CS&S to another group. Some groups within CS&S know much more than others, and chat reps are expected to have much more knowledge and be more adept for similar pay. Other brokerage firms offer much better benefits.

headline: Great place for career exploration
pros:
Great people and collaborative culture.
Our work are client (internal and external) focused. 
Large organization that enables career development through training and different roles.
cons: Things can take a long time to build.

headline: Great culture for growth
pros: There is a strong emphasis on learning and development and even encouragement to disrupt yourself and grow into new roles. I have found strong support for training, gaining experience through project exposure, and 'owning my tomorrow'. The workplace is inclusive and a lot of effort is going into resource groups and acting to diversify the workforce further. Compensation is good.
cons: There are some growing pains in integrating TDA into Schwab. With client, asset, and employee growth somewhere around 50%, challenges are expected, but there are a lot of changes necessary until we get through it.

headline: Great place for Vets!
pros: I was hired to Charles Schwab directly after retiring from Active Duty Air Force. Schwab's commitment to the philosophy 'Through Clients' Eyes' is lived out every day like the Air Force's core values of Integrity First, Service Before Self, and Excellence In All We Do. It was an easy transition from Air Force blue to corporate gray at Schwab.
cons: I had to learn an entirely new set of acronyms (wink, smirk)

headline: Walk the walk
pros:
1) Client first is more than a buzz phrase, we mean it . We live it. 
2) Try to balance responsibility with innovation: conservatively on the cutting edge.
3) Openly inclusive and diverse - taking the time to understand difference in culture and point of view and using the strengths found in being inclusive.
cons: 1) Balancing agility with regulations and the conservative nature of a financial company, lead to some challenges in process. However the culture of the company encourages constant improvement and innovation, so there is always someone or some group working on making it better.
