headline: Top-Down management means broken promises
pros:
1) Good benefits 
2) Great co-workers 
3) Job security
cons:
1) Work style: nature of Financial Services means most available positions are front-end client facing: vast majority of positions are call-center focused as the industry evolved out of "trading floor platform". Promotions simply mean a fancier title and better pay: nature of the job largely remains the same
Roles are 70% Service -30% Finance: Does not recommend for those seeking a more research/analytical focused role 

2) Micro-Management: nothing you do is ever good enough, there exists performance metrics for almost everything, and your growth opportunities are heavily limited by client satisfaction, which often times have little to do with your own individual performance. In your daily work, it is up to you to find the perfect balance amongst the myriad of metrics given and do so consistently 

3) Rigid schedule: schedule is not flexible-even taking bathroom breaks at unscheduled times will have an effect on your metrics, see point #2

4) Pays below industry average (excluding paid training/benefits) and lackluster incentives: incentives often, if not always, fail basic cost-benefit analysis

5) Schwab currently faces a bottle-neck in its ops. Taking on too many clients with recent mergers (USAA, TD-Ameritrade, etc.) without enough trained professionals to resolve issues in multiple departments (Asset Transfers, Account Operations, Brokerage, etc.) resulting in incredibly high hold times for clients-employees alike, leading to massive degrees of inefficiencies and disillusioned clients--which directly impacts your performance metrics (see point #2)

6) Clients: you are guaranteed to encounter extremely rude/unprofessional ones and there's very little you can do about it: the ability to keep calm, have a high EQ often times will be more important than your financial expertise (refer to point #1)

headline: This means Call Center employee
pros: Good Benefits, Work from Home (during Covid-19), nice facilities in Austin.
cons: The pay is $42k per year, plus bonus - this is hard to obtain. When you subtract what you earn from what you contribute for the benefits - you end up with not enough money to live in Austin or rent a one bedroom apartment. Your every second is managed - 15 mins exactly for 2 breaks and 30 mins for lunch. As there is no time to read your emails or try to learn the job effectively, you must do this on your own time. The phone time matrix is extremely tight and a few bathroom breaks with cause you to be out of adherence - which will cause you to lose your bonus. When hired you're told you'll be paid for time to study for the license(s), but there is never time for that. There is no future career opportunities, unless you leave the company.

headline: Good Employer
pros: Overall Schwab is a good company to work for. The culture is very team oriented and something I have never seen in my career, it is very refreshing actually. They are a company that cares about giving back to the community by offering volunteer hours per year to employees. Chuck himself is absolutely amazing and most executive leadership resources are extremely personal and approachable. I also love the fact that leadership includes women.
cons: Pay is average, benefits are ok (can improve health insurance), PTO is average. Company needs new blood, too many old timers not willing to change. Very old school in thoughts surrounding work from home and changes to process and policies. The Project Management organization reporting model should definitely be changed as Program Directors run the organization and have too much power

headline: Great place to start
pros:
- Culture: if you’re sick you’re sick, there’s no need for you to worry about coverage (comparing to Jpm). If your relative passes away, the first words out of their mouths aren’t “When will you be back” but “I’m so sorry for your loss” (comparing to BofA).

- decent pay (mediocre raises, so negotiating your starting pay is important).

- decent benefits (the ability to invest in individual stocks or etfs/mutual funds outside your typical 401k but still part of your 401k (brokerage account) is not common and a huge plus, and to do so with Roth 401k or traditional 401k or a blend is even a bigger plus).

- sabbatical (every five years you earn a month (4 weeks) of paid time off in addition to PTO, which is only ok. Gets slightly better the more years you work there.

- Large company (billions in revenue) with a small company feel (you’re able to get exceptions if it makes business sense and actually chat with executive council).

- Mentorships

- Highly encouraging individuals to get more licenses, certifications like CFP, etc.

- Work life balance is stellar for the financial industry.
cons:
- Little to no training which leads to another con:

- Inconsistencies with their policies & procedures. You have reps who will state one thing when it’s another. You will also find yourself needing to rely on other reps to accomplish one piece of a much larger puzzle because of lack of training. And it’s not even you don’t know how. The company literally limits you to what you can do.

There are amazing individuals that work within the organization, however its: 50% wtf, 30% ok, 10% great and 10% amazing and hope they never quit despite average pay.

- Pay

headline: Great career starting point
pros:
Schwab is overall a great company to work for. You can really feel that leadership cares about their employees. One example is that they like to promote within (crucial). They are also constantly asking their employees how they can improve the company and the employee experience. Benefits are solid too. Some of the highlights would be immediate 401k vesting, stock options, HSA, as well as a sabbatical every 5 years (paid 1 whole month off on top of your vacation days). Leadership has a strategy not to micromanage, which actually works out pretty well. Employees don't feel pressurized, but instead motivated to do their role more effectively.

The CRS role is a great role at branch network that can open many opportunities. You will get licensed and learn a whole lot about industry. If you want, Schwab will even pay for your school/professional designations. I would certainly recommend this role.
cons: Not really a con per se, but you kind of have to go for what you want. Nothing will be handed to you. If you are looking to advance your career within the company, you have to really show you are advancing. There's also many resources available for employees that are being taken advantage of simply because employees don't know about them.

headline: Only do it if you love customer service
pros:
Great start to financial career. 
Improves communication skills. 
Employees are nice, but some are robotic and give in to generic business jargon which is never enjoyable.
cons:
Metrics very stressful, they control your day. 
Might get a wacky schedule. 
Very stressful when busy. 
They said 3-6 months until you start studying for the Series Exams, it’s been 9 months and still slaving away on the phones. 
If you’re thinking of applying, do yourself a favor, and keep swiping.
I’ve dreaded waking up every morning to a 10 hour shift, and it’s taken a toll on my mental health and relationship with my girlfriend.

headline: Glorified Call Center
pros: Health insurance, semi-flexible scheduling, they'll hire anybody with a pulse for the entry-level Associate phone center positions.
cons:
Worked here briefly several years ago but I left after a only few weeks into the orientation class. 

The class composition from the get go concerned me - primarily very young fresh college grads, stay at home parents getting back into the workforce, and bitter retreads from local competitors and from other walks of life. 

The first days of training seemed like indoctrination into a cult. Hearing the continuous virtues of how "incredibly awesome" Schwab was further made me weary that they're trying to hide the truth about the company's true culture. The classroom training felt like I was back in high school - very immature and juvenile behavior ("If you're "good," I'll let you leave 5 minutes early today!). 

I was told during the recruiting process that I would be allowed to immediately sit for SIE and Series 7 exams; however, two weeks into the new hire classroom training, we were told that we'd only be permitted to sit for exams once approved on a schedule by management and that could be four to six months later.  

The final straw for me was when new hires were told to sit with an experienced FSR for an hour. The kid I sat with totally botched every single call he took. It was clear he had zero understanding of his job or the financial services industry in general. 

I realized I was wasting my time here so I packed up, went home, and have never regretted leaving it since.

pros:
benefits

cons:
MICROMANAGING
lower pay compared to other banks (expect 40k)
You are just a number, and they only care about the numbers to make their team look good

CALL CENTER ENVIRONMENT: every role is trust me.  The job was extremely misleading and the turnover is HIGH. One person left after two days! Many people do not last past 3-6 months

cons: While Schwab puts clients first, they put employees last. Salaries for experienced, licensed professionals are not even remotely competitive with similar roles at big banks or private wealth institutions (I know this from my own experience). 12 days accrued vacation a year plus 2 float days is sad. Schwab spends a great deal of effort telling employees and the community that Schwab is a great workplace in the hope that people who don’t know better will believe it.

headline: Review

headline: A big business with principles
pros: I'm generally skeptical about corporate mission and values statements, but from what I've seen, Schwab actually lives theirs. They don't just talk about acting with integrity and putting others first--that's how the company seems to operate from the highest levels down. The culture is supportive and inclusive, and management really seems to care about employees' wellbeing.
cons: The size of the company can make it difficult to feel plugged in and involved in the core of the business. As an employee, finding a smaller niche, like a business division or local team, is important.

headline: Clients First!
pros: Schwab put clients first - we see through clients eyes which drives everything we do. Schwab has an inclusive culture and provides so much support for career growth within the firm.
cons: Schwab is going through multiple acquisitions which is exciting, but it can bring a lot of uncertainty and change, but ultimately should bring even more opportunity, not only to our employees, but our clients too!

headline: Limited growth
pros: The pay isn't the worst. You get a sabbatical after 5 years of service (paid time off about 28 days). If you are interested in getting your licensing, this place is for you. I will say it was a great place to work back in 2011. If you are willing to follow without question, adapt to changes on a regular basis, If you are a numbers person & competitive,this company is for you.
cons: The technology is terrible & interrupts productivity which....you still get held accountable for. The training for the newer reps is a joke. They have this term called OJ L which is on-the-job learning, meaning they throw the newbies on the phone with little knowledge, these newbies call my department for help with training, however we are still held to keep our metrics and to serve our clients. Something is very wrong with that. For the hotline teams, management is out of touch & makes decisions that creates bigger issues for reps working on the front lines. Promotion seems to be based on what licenses you have and how long you been at the company, not if you are actually qualified/skilled for the job. If you are a creative, think for yourself, are not robot, this is not the place for you. Micromanaging, 30 minute lunches, having to fill out 2 reports daily on what you are doing any time you are not on the phones, being treated like a child. Passive aggressive expectations from our leaders, who want you to go above & beyond for clients, then caps you at 4 mins per call. 1 call could literally cover 11 different tasks, including trading. We are told to put the client first, but clearly it's the metrics that are first. Employees are clearly not happy but fill out surveys w/ fake positive feedback out of fear of losing their jobs. We are seen as numbers only , "butts in seats" as one of the directors used to say in regards to attendance. All work , no play & it IS a very dull environment. The most fun I have is with the clients, who mostly are great BTW. The overall morale in my department is at an all-time low even when we were in the office, it is a very stressful environment. Schwab used to treat employees so well, times have truly changed.

headline: Schwab is a good place to work for a solid amount of time
pros:

- Sabbaticals every 5 years (unless you're a VP or higher)

cons:
- Low number of company holidays, so you burn through more paid vacation (corporate remains open with markets and our branch offices)
- Not enough remote work flexibility (changing for the better during pandemic)
- Some benefits could be better (e.g. high-deductible health plan covers little until deductible is met)
- Not enough advancement opportunities to retain high performing talent

cons:
-Scarce opportunities outside of customer service.
-FCA is very much prioritized over you if you’d like to go the advice/sales route and nothing you do in CS&S will translate into roles not in customer service.
-It’s a call center.
-Micromanagement is an understatement. Metrics include taking your 15 min breaks and 30 min lunch on schedule, average duration of your calls, and how long you are not actively talking to someone else on the phone.
-Most people are actively looking for opportunities elsewhere.
-Pay isn’t too bad but slightly lower than other broker dealers.

headline: Where Is Walt?
pros: Great exposure to the industry and a way to get an understanding of the industry.
cons: Schwab is not a place to build a career. It is a great place to get started and gain experience by not a place to stay. FC comp is cut monthly to control the EPS of the company. Schwab is an expense controller to meet shareholder expectations. Marketing and reality do not align. Branch Lead flow has fallen to 0 as Schwab looks to maintain the revenue on clients. Any lead flow you may get will come with a potential risk and headache where a call center representative was worried about the risk of a client and decided to pass that risk to you. Financial consultants are micromanaged down to their every phone call and notes in the system. If your dashboard does not look right to them you will be told several times a week. I watched my predecessor get pushed out after dedicating over 20 years to the company and having clients who raved about them. There is zero loyalty to Financial Consultants. We continued to become less skilled at the FC position thus the errors are increasing rapidly on clients. There is no coaching or development you will have to do this on your own. Walt has been missing in action for over two years and I worry we are going fast down the wrong path and unfortunately it will be clients that suffer the most.

headline: Actively encouraged to have a work and life balance
pros:
Totally supportive that I need to pick up my daughter from school during this WFH pandemic 
Meetings are more like collaborations where ideas are openly discussed and decisions are made after everyone's input
Encouraged to ask "why" before accepting a new task. For example "Is there a legal reason for this task, or are we doing it *this way* because it has always been done like that before? Can we try something new?"
Focus is on solving problems, not releasing features.
cons:
Some managers are slow to make the transition of servant leadership. 
Some developers are still in a traditional Agile mindset, and not a flexible when it comes to progress over process.

headline: Charles Schwab is Phenomenal
pros: Charles Schwab is the best place to work because they promote a healthy work/life balance, your team feels like a family, and their benefits are amazing.
cons: There is nothing I would change about my experience at Charles Schwab.

headline: Lots of interesting work
pros:
* Company is financially solid, making major investments in new technologies.
* Co-workers are generally helpful and want you to succeed. 
* While not always positive, Leadership decisions are usually well-thought-out - balancing scope, time to market, and strategy.
* Lots of interesting technology work, depending on what team you're on.
cons:
* Consensus building culture often slows things down -- often for the better, but sometimes its frustrating.
* Silos. Different teams duplicate work. or move in opposite directions.
* Sick time and Vacation time are tracked separate.

headline: Very ethical but bureaucratic and hierarchical
pros: A very ethical company, always puts customers first and that tone comes from the very top (very refreshing and sadly, surprising in today's world).
cons:
Very bureaucratic and old school culture, where hierarchy matters a lot. Likely depends on the team, but oftentimes smart and experienced people will not speak up in meetings if they have a different opinion than their manager.
A lot of micromanaging on some teams.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Good product mix with competitive fees. Nice coworkers. Private offices. Given book of business to work. No cold calling. Strong marketing support.
cons: It's a sales job.  Big producers get support. Mediocre numbers get mediocre support. Goal is to sell managed money. Financial Planning is a way to convince self directed investors to move to managed accounts. Given a book to sell. However, if clients withdraw funds to buy a house for example, counts against you. You will lose money on many clients.

headline: A Company with a Conscience
pros:
I enjoy working at Charles Schwab because the core values are echoed throughout the firm and in presentation. Seeing the world "through clients eyes" has shaped the trajectory of the firm. I have worked for several firms where they want a client, but only Schwab advocates for the client. 

The firm was very responsive during Covid, and has made every effort to make continuing business during these times as productive as possible. That meant taking a 95% onsite, in office, business and turning it into a 75% work from home environment. Providing subsidies for home technology and sending work kits to ensure people can work successfully.

Also during the pandemic, the firm has had one voice about self care, and work-life balance and providing additional resources related to physical and mental health. It is nice to know that a firm is concerned about its employee's well being as much as the bottom line. This has been very important during a time when so much uncertainty is surrounding us. If I were to separate from the firm, and the opportunity presented itself, I would absolutely choose to work with Schwab again.
cons: No company is perfect. There could certainly be more diversity in management, but I see proactive efforts to change, which even if not immediate is better than no effort.

headline: A refreshing place to work
pros:
It's great to work for a company that actually believes in the core values that they advertise. Everything is done Through The Clients Eyes and to their benefit.

Lots of internal movement and opportunities

Great pay, benefits, and perks such as Employee Stock Purchase Program, stock grants, and annual bonuses.
cons: Schwab's extremely polite culture can be challenging to navigate on the occasion when a more firm approach is needed.

headline: Huge Corporation But it Feels Like "Family"
pros: Even though Schwab is a giant and continues to grow even bigger, three main PROS stick out for me: (1) the focus has always been and will always be on the client experience; (2) the focus is also on the employee experience; (3) the culture is inclusive, supportive, and collaborative. I have been with the company for just over a year, but have worked in the industry for many years. My experience at Schwab has been comparatively the most welcoming, genuine, supportive, and motivational. Not every day is perfect, but I feel respected and valued, supported and heard. That's pretty huge.
cons: The "general" email load is crazy, with multiple communications daily from leadership and different departments. But then, there's a lot going on!

headline: Balancing Good with the Bad
pros: Who you work with matters, and culture is key to that, but culture is often a buzz word that most companies talk about. Schwab actually lives this in a way you can feel every day. There's a consistent focus on client experience, driving change at every turn and recruitment of decent talent to push it all forward. The day-to-day is appropriately challenging, and there's rarely pressure to work late or on weekends. It's very balanced, making Schwab particularly well-suited to working parents who don't want to compromise on professional development.
cons:
Schwab funds most of its activities on a project-by-project basis, so you not only spend significant time pitching instead of actually delivering, it also results in a lack of "big picture" thinking across the organization and spotty talent. Pick your team wisely!

Compensation and benefits are nothing to write home about; pretty middle-of-the way, and sometimes not competitive, but keep in mind that it's work/life balance that's the real reward.

headline: Top notch leadership with a focus on personal development
pros:
Best leadership/management experience I’ve ever had. Multiple managers across business lines and always consistent and development focused.
Own your tomorrow is not just about clients but also about employees and what they’re looking to do.
Have learned so much about financial fitness for myself and have been able to help others.
Very focused on clients and what is best for them.
cons: Large company, risk averse, takes time for changes to occur

-this job is a glorified call center with the added benefit of embarrassment when others ask what your job is.

headline: Great experience for the education... if you thrive in conservative corporate America.
pros:
If you have at least a Bachelor's degree and some service experience, Schwab will train you to be a licensed stockbroker and financial professional, and help you on the pathway to becoming a financial consultant. I was able to attain my Series 7 and 66 through them, and it was a great experience after overcoming some ridiculous oversights from their end.
1) They'll train you for any license you'll need (they determine if you need them)
2) The people who aren't corporatist boot lickers are incredibly talented and amazing to learn from (I still have several people I stay in touch with from there)
3) You learn how to quickly uncover a service need, and collaborate to solve it, which transfers to other professions (because after a few months of this role, you WILL want to leave, if you are able to do so)
cons:
The majority of Schwab jobs are service-related, which makes sense because they are a financial services firm. What they don't tell you is that the Academy is an excuse for Schwab to siphon bushy-tailed and bright-eyed energy from recent college graduates and career switchers in order to staff their call centers with high-level talent for 2 years. Don't believe me? Ask a recruiter.
1) They treat you like a line item in a spreadsheet or an input in a machine (metrics are used punitively instead of constructively: You can have a 98% Client Satisfaction Score and earn you no earnest recognition, but if you take 15 seconds longer per call than the average person in your department because of difficult clients/calls , you aren't promoted. 
2) "Clients are prioritized" in the sense that employees are treated like fast-food workers to ensure availability. (minimum legally-required break and lunch time, PTO, sick time. Blackout periods for time-off during half the year because of end of year and tax season volumes)
3) Terrible volume prediction for staffing resulting in canceled training classes, team meetings, and pressure to "get them off the phone fast" (They say they want to "See through clients eyes", but frontline workers are coached to get clients off the phone as quickly as possible, and limit real-time assistance, instead choosing to deflect service needs to online self-service options. This is not great for older clients who prefer phone-based walkthroughs, which is the majority of people who choose to call first before looking online)

headline: Draining call center
pros: none. slow growth opportunities for individuals.
cons: Metrics change every year, they get more strict and unrealistic each time, You're expected to go above and beyond and deal with upset and disrespectful clients and in return you have disproportionate compensation. It's a call center, so you'll take calls all day long for 8 to 10 hrs per day depending on your shift. Systems are often down, and technology is unreliable which increases calls, which means more angry clients. There is no flexibility, meaning your vacation requests hardly ever get approved because call volumes are so high, they can't afford to have people off the phones. It's not easy to get a raise because it takes only ONE bad client survey over something completely out of your control to cause you to miss quarterly metrics, and sets you back. Turnover was high, even during COVID!

headline: Good Place To Start But Not A Place To Stay
pros:
Schwab is a great place for a new advisor to gain experience. And if you can survive, you can make a good to great living. 

Essentially, they assign you a large book of clients and it is your job to service them and try to sell them Managed Money. You do get to work with a large group of sophisticated clients who have a lot of money. And you will get exposed to High Net Worth and Ultra High Net Worth Investment and planning topics.
cons:
I should note that, I worked in down town Boston office and the management style from office to office differs to some extent so this may not be applicable to Schwab as a whole but it was my experience. 

As an experienced Advior, I found it difficult to be micro managed. Essentially, you meet with management every 2 weeks for anywhere from 1/2 to 2 hours . The reviews could be quick or they could involve reviewing every single opportunity you created. As a Financial Consultant, my expectation going in, was that I was going to be tasked to help clients by utilizing the products and services on their platform. This was partially true but ultimately, it seemed to me that the ultimate goal of the role was to sell managed money. 

Turnover: Overall, except for a small group of long timers, the turnover was high. During my tenure the turnover was just over 50%. As a result, the long term compensation packages may not apply unless you are able to survive. Also, the Boston and surrounding offices seems to be all Male and very few minorities. During my tenure there was a good representation of women but they have all since left. 

With respect to goals: They were always much higher than the average (it seemed). It almost seemed that they took the performance of the top 1% and wanted everyone to perform at that level, regardless of tenure . Just keep in mind, when someone gives you a large group of clients, the demands are going to be high.

Ultimately Management has their agenda and you will be a cog in the wheel. Every 2 months there was a new focus, and the last topic of focus seemed to be forgotten.

headline: Meh
pros: Breakfast Quesadillas are a great plus.
cons: Culture, disconnect from actual issues, “open door (but don’t walk in)policy”, unethical practices related to comp structure and tenured FC’s. Accommodation denials for known disabilities. 2 Toilets for an entire floor. Very Static and way too big. Job security is crap.

headline: Fear and power over logic and function
pros: They pay is decent if you fight for it.
cons: Lack of leadership, integrity, empathy and technical understanding in the security and technical org . Multiple layers of middle management that are non technical or do not know anything about business. Most folks who stay on for several years are because they are in the “schwabbies” click and part of the “good old boys” club. No innovation with legacy technologies and poor directional leadership. Same problems have existed for years but cannot seem to get out of the vendor carousel to focus on a solution to make it successful. Multiple teams doing similar job functions but stepping over each other to see who can show off the best to the CISO.

headline: Stagnated tech environment and complacent leadership
pros: Easy work life balance, solid work benefits, friendly atmosphere.
cons:
* Tech stack is specific and lacks the widely used programming languages, CICD, and cloud technologies.

* Very hard to have an impact due to cookie cutter project design and an anti-exploratory work environment.

* Salary ranges are well under what competing companies are offering, and new hires with less experience are generally make as much or more out of the gate.

* Very slow to change.

* Not many opportunities to move around orgs.

* Still no long-term remote work plan.

* Forced to use internal tools and technologies that are usually inferior to open-source solutions and are often buggy with little documentation.

headline: Lack of opportunity
pros: On average, good culture that isn’t toxic (ie Wells Fargo). Sabbaticals are great. Will pay for licensing and professional carts.
cons:
Lack of opportunity. More of a patronage system than a merit one. You’re not really expected to ‘apply’ for a position but instead recruited, so progress can be slow. Main drive of promotions seems to be networking and connections more than anything else. 
Lack of development - Theyre not very open to to training or growing you but will expect you to have tons of experience or training even for entry level positions. 
Lack of flexibility/freedom - No alt schedule usually, with the exception of Covid no WFH opportunity. Instituted work tracking apps so your productivity is closely monitored

headline: Get ready for non-stop calls with a lot of unhappy clients. A lot will get dumped on you from other reps.
pros: Good team atmosphere. Fast-paced, something new and never boring. You will deal with alot of experienced clients who know how to trade and a lot that don't. But can be fulfilling at times knowing you're helping folks out.
cons: Management won't always have your back when you need them in a tough spot. You are expected to do whatever it takes to make the clients happy which is fine, but at what expense? Sometimes realistic expectations need to be set with people and that can lead to a bad survey which can ruin your quarter bonus.

headline: Classic corporate job, but the people are friendly and you’ll get good work experience.

headline: Program HAS* potential
pros: They pay for your licensing and meet some good people.
cons: They try to down play the main job duty: being in a call center. It's an over-glorified call center position. It was never explained from the beginning there is different shifts. FCA use to have real priority until new management came in. Even though they give you a timeline - it's not set, meaning you do not know when your next rotation is and you do not know when you are studying. Some cohort starts studying 6 months in, some start 3 months. It's based on business needs (the calls). Executives make unreasonable decisions and it affects the employees in the call center negatively. It's mentally draining to take calls 7/8 hours. If you're not on the phone when your scheduled, it's hurts your performance which hurts your raises. Many employees place clients on hold to use the bathroom just to not hurt their performance. The metrics are ridiculous to meet and it's even harder during COVID. The pay is based on being a call center and not a development program and Schwab is known for low pay in the industry. If you decide you no longer want to be in FCA, they only give you two options: stay or quit. They are not a fan of having employees leave the academy to a different department besides the branch. Not only does the salary have a cap while in the program, it also has a maximum when you go to the branch for the first few years. Also the locations available at the end of the program are not "ideal" locations. Instead of Los Angels, NYC, Miami, etc. being on the list, it's MiddleofNowhere, USA. Some of the managers are micromanagers and some don't lift a finger. You are doing the real work. Everything I said was before COVID.................and now it keeps getting worse.

The work I'm doing makes me excited to get up in the morning, but I dont feel pressured to work 60 hour weeks, like I've experienced in other growth environments. I feel very stable- leadership does a good job of communicating about upcoming changes and what to expect, most of the time. The people I work with genuinely care about me and that has helped me navigate through this trying pandemic era we are all living in right now.
cons: Schwab's culture is so reliant on relationships, that the previous world focused on in person interaction at the office. We have big, beautiful new office campuses and I'm not sure how we will react to the new remote work era as a long term reality.

headline: Own your Tomorrow and Get out
pros: Pretty stable company with decent benefits. Overall, nice people work here
cons: The company culture promotes privilege and an overall elitist mindset. I've worked in three different departments in my time here and have seen the same behaviors in each one. People tattle on each other, make up lies, and try to stab you in the back to promote themselves and steer people away from their incompetence. Many people are bad at their jobs but get promoted or receive opportunities they're not qualified for because they've been there for so long. The Executives pretend to care about their employees, but they don't. We were one of the last companies to go remote when COVID hit. They were actually mandating that people keep coming in when other companies mandated you stay home. Yes, the CEO actually sent a firm wide email telling all employees that we needed to come in because technology couldn't support us all working from home at the same time. They also instituted COVID pay for the first two months of the pandemic which entitled you to paid time off (that didn't count against vacation or sick time) if you tested positive for COVID or came in contact with someone who did. But they cut this right before the cases spiked and numerous employees got sick. Did they reinstate it? No. Why not? Because it was all for show, like everything they do at this company. Fake it til you make it is the Charles Schwab way.

headline: Good, but could do better
pros: The financial compensation is good, depending on where you are located. The future outlook is bright as well. Inclusivity and diversity within the corporate culture.
cons:
There are a few things that will frustrate you beyond belief.

1. Meeting management here is horrible. This company is a meeting factory. Calendars are full of them. Meetings are not managed properly. Many meetings don't have clear agendas, they allow attendees to go off on tangents, they aren't held to their expected time frames, etc. I've been on meetings scheduled for 30 minutes, which turned into working sessions that lasted up to 2.5 hours. It's unprofessional to expect someone attending a scheduled 30-minute meeting to stay on for 2.5 hours. Chatty-Cathy's (those people who never shut up) are also a major issue during meetings. To learn, you must be willing to listen, and you need good meeting management in order to ensure meetings start/end on time, and cover the required information pertaining to the meeting.

2. Communication needs to be improved. Emails and Instant messages are not returned in a timely manner. I've waited 3 hours to 3 days for people to respond to an instant message. I've waited 3 weeks for people to respond to an email. Sometimes people never respond. Communication is essential, and non-communication kills productivity. 

3. Pushback on improvement. There's a sense of "we've always done it this way", which impairs the ability to innovate and improve. When improvements are offered, perspectives turn to why it can't be done, rather than looking at the value of the improvement and attempting to determine how it can be done. Unfortunately, some don't see the value of improvement even after it's demonstrated.

headline: Toxic environment, cultish culture, no accountability. (Broker Service Rep review)
pros:
- Job security - no one ever gets fired unless you literally don’t show up to work
- Ethical - you never have to do anything shady to a client in order to be successful
- Random (discretionary) bonuses or extra pay throughout the year - though this has become far less common now that interest rates have been cut
cons:
- Corporate culture is very cultish. You’re constantly told about how happy everyone is to he there, how they never want to leave and have been there for a long time (10-20 years for some people, though notably these people are usually middle managers or salespeople and not phone reps), how Schwab somehow wins high employee satisfaction rewards, etc.

If this is true, then why is it you never seen anyone smile in the halls? Once management gets a whiff of dissent, their manners towards that employee completely shift. Four of my colleagues over the years were victims of this.

- You are not a broker. You are a service specialist. Majority of your calls are a skillset they push on you, such as “ID Theft” (unlocking online logins and enhanced verification when people forget security questions) or “Bank” (assisting with debit cards). You also frequently get tech support calls that you are expected to handle. Support departments often give you pushback and do not want to take the call.

The broker calls you do get are simply glorified order taking. You cannot give advice. Schwab’s website does not have any advice capabilities, so you are placed in an impossible situation of needing to “fulfill the client’s need” while not being able to actually fulfill this need. Of course, this is your fault. No accountability for others.

- Training is terrible. It mostly consists of you being given a new skillset, thrown on the phones, and hopefully figuring it out. If you mess up, again the blame is on you. No accountability for others.

- Lied to about opportunity. They tell you there are so many places to go and Schwab will support your career growth, but career growth is absolutely non-existent. It is not a meritocracy. It’s about who you know. And it’s a good ol boys club. Minorities and women need not apply to these higher positions. And if your director doesn’t like you, good luck doing anything but phone calls.

In my 2 years on a top-performing team metrics-wise, I had 5 managers, 2 people actually move on to a new role (1 was a lateral move), and 4 people leave the company. There was no accountability for the incompetence of management, or for their empty promises that were walked back for a previously undisclosed disqualifying reason, lack of support, etc.

- Management dodges accountability from top to bottom. There were always excuses for not getting basic things done like U4 paperwork to be able to sit for a FINRA exam, pay increases, reimbursement requests, etc. There were also excuses for not coaching, not educating reps, not communicate changes resulting in reps making errors, etc. Some managers were on top of this. The ones who weren’t shifted blame all around, but it always ultimately fell on the powerless rep who could not push the blame elsewhere. Directors supported this blame shifting because they themselves did it, and management culture always is learned from top down.

Excuses, excuses, excuses are all you ever hear from management. There is no accountability in this company whatsoever and, as a phone rep, there is not a single thing you can do about it.

This leads to a culture of dodging accountability firm-wide. Calls are blind transferred to you so people don’t have to deal with a difficult call, and you will do the same to others. After all, if you give wrong information, you will be “coached” or otherwise disciplined. If you pass the call off however, literally nothing happens to you.

- Frustrating new metrics. The metrics for 2020 are designed against you. A survey that is not a perfect 7 out of 7 counts as a 0. I have received “0’s” with comments full of thank you’s and appreciation. It doesn’t matter that it doesn’t add up. And thanks to the good ol boys culture of promotion that is rampant here, these metrics are often used to keep people on the phones and promote management’s favorites.

But they’ll tell you: “We don’t care about metrics.”

There are many many other things but hopefully this gives an idea of the disconnect between what you are told this job and company will be, and what this job and company actually are.

pros: All my managers have been super friendly and approachable. Generous pay, but after working there for a long period of time.
cons:
The lack of preparedness to the Coronavirus outbreak is very concerning. Only a very small portion of the company has the ability to work from home. We are told that the remote servers can't even handle just that small handful of people working from home all at once. While other firms are mass working from home those of us with the capability to do so are being told not to.

Front end client UI is shiny but lacking. Internal technology has constant issues, crashes, multiple systems work in only one varying web browser (need two web browsers open at all times).

headline: Good Culture and Corporate Values
pros: All employees seem to take the corporate values seriously. It is a very inclusive culture and everyone seems genuine and open.
cons: It's a corporate environment so it takes time to get things done, which can be frustrating. The worst part I've experienced so far is, Schwab does not appear to have many people who can properly perform meeting management (i.e. having an agenda, staying on it, and deferring tangent conversations offline). I have regularly been on calls that extend far beyond their scheduled time frames. I was on a recent call that was scheduled for 30 minutes, but it went 1 hr 45 minutes, on a Friday afternoon! This makes getting work done extremely frustrating.  Healthcare coverage is frustrating to move from one employer plan to another and discover certain medications are no longer covered and getting everyone (doctors, prescription benefit manager, etc.) on the same page is unnecessarily complicated and time-consuming. Additionally, I've been here over a year and still have no idea what the organization structure is regarding roles/titles/pay grades. I engage with people everyday and do not know where they are in the hierarchy based on their title, because there is no clear structure, and have no idea what my future opportunities/titles could be because I have no idea what the career path is here.

headline: Don't start with a phone job, you'll be stuck forever
pros: Good benefits, culture is ok if you're not in an inbound phone role, view of the mountains from the 5th floor!
cons: It's all who you know around here and who likes you the most. You won't get promoted unless you schmooze with the right people and they pay MUCH MUCH less than the industry average. Zero training, awful communication. I've never been lied to so many times in such a short period of time with a company. They claim to be supportive of moving between departments, however once you start applying out to other departments your managers hold it against you. Seems to be great in other departments, but stay away from the phone jobs! They have to force people to stay in this department with 12-24 month commitments because turnover is so high.

headline: Micromanagement

headline: Not a career, know what you're getting yourself into, take this job as a last resort
pros:
You'll work with great people you want to work hard for and who will share your frustrations with you. 

The checks clear.

401k and stock bonuses are decent.

The Denver campus is great. Good cheap food options. Can be hard to get to in the snow however.
cons:
I cant emphasize enough that this is not a trading or broker job. It is basically a nursing job at this point. Schwab has scared away all of its real trading activity through a botched merger and refusal to fix the numerous issues on the site. Your job on a daily basis is mostly to hold hands with people who are some combination of helpless, lazy, entitled, incompetent, and/or incapacitated. Many are also mean. It is a miserable job that will break you and make you hate people. There are some nice clients you will help that occasionally feels good, but a majority of the work is soul-crushing. So many people you talk to arent suitable for trading but your're still supposed to take their money. 

You're rarely taking thlrade calls at this point anyway. The routing is a mess and you are expected to do the other department's jobs. Sometimes you'll try to transfer to the right desk and they'll refuse to take the call.

There are regularly issues with the system and sometimes you will spend your whole day as a punching bag for clients. Schwab will rarely fix anything because trading doesn't make money anymore. Your job will be to clean up Schwab's mess and get nothing back for it. When they horribly botched a merger recently, they would give you gifts like stress balls and forks (seriously) for the trouble.

Schwab recently installed metrics on the phone services that make your career prospects infuriating and close to a waste of time. Your career lives and dies by surveys. Schwab knows the surveys are often irrational (angry and/or elderly clients) but they dont care as its an easy way to not pay people and the people who came up with the system won't admit it's a mistake because they attached their name to it. 

Apparently, it's now gotten even worse as my friends still there tell me they installed some system that controls your bathroom breaks and they feel like they're in kindergarten again.

The red tape at the company is completely debilitating and nothing gets done because of it. It became a running joke that if something was announced to be fixed or released on a certain date, add six months.

A few weeks before I left, Schwab had mass layoffs because they bought a company with money they didnt have; this after having executive photo op meetings at all the offices where they would shove you into conference rooms so execs could read you a prepared script about how well Schwab was positioned for the future. That was kind of the last straw for me. It was insulting. 

They've done it before in the past only they have some event or celebration [they did this for the abomination of a merger with optionsXpress] and the phones are so backed up with pissed off clients mad about the exact thing they're celebrating that they tell the phone desks that they can't go.

Nobody outside of Schwab (probably even in Schwab) will take you seriously. They know what the job is. I had 2 recruiters roll their eyes at me when i tried to play this off as a trading job. I was extremely lucky and had to exhaust all my resources to get out when i did. 

Take this job as a last resort.

If you do, spend at most 2 years getting every license up to 66 then either move to sales/adviser/marketing/product side or just bounce.

cons: Metrics Metrics Metrics. The statistics are all that matters. At first I was told to “take all the time I need to take care of the client”. Then I was told that my average Handle time should be 5.47 minutes. Also, if I take my time to take care of the client I might go over my scheduled break and that affects my “adherence” metric, which will prevent me from “career progression”. Also, they speak of diversity and inclusivity but it feels like if you are a woman you’re already at a disadvantage.  In addition to that, if a client is rude or disrespectful, your managers will find a way to make it your fault.

headline: A developer's nightmare
pros: Pretty solid benefits, which would be especially generous to someone starting out in an entry level job (less so when you're already at this salary level.)
cons:
Shockingly non-existent onboarding or documentation. Every thing you attempt to do present some new challenge you can't overcome without esoteric knowledge that only one person that's now in another department knows. And no domain knowledge either, so you'll have no idea what the work you're accomplishing actually does or is meant to do. Some of these knowledge transfer meetings were also grueling, 3+ hour endeavors, where the employees who were teaching you their platforms would just work silently as the trainees watched.

Recovering from some really bad practices, such "include precompiled binaries of the libraries we use" instead of "reference our internal package server."  Which made my job of porting our code an absolute nightmare.

Cryptic and unflexible. When I was hired they did not tell me the location of the office (or any details at all, I had to reach out to find out when my first day was,) and I assumed it was at their campus. It was a branch building, where my commute was over 2 hours long each way (instead of the 7 minutes to their campus.) I asked and they explained that work from home was only available for medical reasons.
The first pay period I was dinged for having an inconsistent schedule, due to the effect of traffic on our bus routes.
The second pay period I was dinged for staying in the office too long, due our commuter bus schedule running 15 minutes later than the end of the day. I  was told I could take flex time and leave earlier on Friday to prevent from accruing overtime.
The third pay period I was dinged for not working enough hours on Friday, and was told they wouldn't pay me for the hour I owed (which was fine, as I was also dinged for working overtime on Monday through Friday, for which I was paid extra.)
I gave up after that.

For security reason the office internet is highly locked down, which make absolute sense. But there's also no guest network and no cell phone reception in their offices, which means you will slowly go insane at the lack of human communication.

I spent over 3 hours in a meeting where the culture committee derived the rules to Pictionary, for a game that lasted us 20 minutes. This was not an ironic exercise.

cons: The health benefits are horrible some of the worst for a large company, once your in it's extremely hard to move up, it's all about who you know here and not what you know.  Most of the people here don't say good morning or even hold the door for you, it's a pretty toxic environment and feels a bit racist at times, upper management is very unprofessional, they talk crap about the employees i witness this as part of upper management.  Work life balance is ok depending on the department but you hardly get to take a lunch or breaks, unless your in customer service. I say get trained here and head for the door, their are better companies.

The customer can get nasty on the phone and they expect you to take verbal abuse. I’m an advocate for Richard Bransons philosophy, take care of your employees and they will take care of your customers. Schwab is the worst place to work for. The have discriminatory practices when it comes to raises and promotions, they don’t value advanced degrees, and the pay is trash.

headline: Culture, Value's, What Happened To This Great Company
pros: You are surrounded by some of the most amazing, talented sales people in the industry.  Think about it.  Schwab clients do not like paying fees, that's a big reason they come to Schwab.  Schwab FC's are tasked with moving those self directed clients to a fee based platform.  By the way, they are incredibly good at this!!!
cons: It's like quicksand.  You feel like your slowly sinking every year.  Incredible complacency within the FC ranks.  A culture of  the Have's/Have's Not has been created within the FC ranks.  You feel stuck.  Sabbaticals are great but they always threaten to take them away.  Compensation is always changing.  If your here long enough, you become numb to all the changes.  FC Comp is our #1 expense.  Firm loves to spend money on initiates that have little to no impact (ie. UOP).  Leadership is always changing.

headline: Great company culture

headline: If you're a senior manager, you'll be frustrated
pros: Schwab is an incredibly client-first firm. Everyone is very nice - in fact, everyone refers to the culture as "Schwab-Nice".
cons:
Yes, people are nice, but it definitely comes at the expense of getting things done.  It's an incredibly meeting heavy culture - mainly because people meet to talk instead of getting things done. Very few people take and distribute notes so there are often follow up meetings to discuss what occurred in previous meetings. If you're ambitious and like to get things done, ensure you go in as an MD or above. Senior Managers are not respected or given any authority.

It is also incredibly difficult to move around or get promoted, especially as a senior manager (which is the lowest level). So many people are vying for very very few positions on the Retail corporate side.

headline: Young professionals, do not work here if career growth is your goal.

-Pay is below industry average 
-Innovation is lacking (MGMT focused on automation over innovation) 
-Old tech stack and questionable methods 
-No mentorship (expect to feel siloed)
-Benefits are poor for the industry 
-No support for career development
-Inflexible work environment 

If you are young and looking to grow your skillset (especially in a technical/quantitative role) absolutely LOOK ELSEWHERE. You will likely be stuck working on a project where you don’t get to use your skillset/will stagnate. 

Come here to retire not to grow.

Also, it’s even more ridiculous as most of the day you’re on video calls anyway. 

If you’re looking for a flexible employer due to, oh I don’t know, life, don’t work here.

headline: Bigger is not always better.
pros: I do not have any pros for this Company.
cons:
Very unfriendly atmosphere. I was there for weeks before people even attempted to speak to me. 
No training. I was told by my manager that Charles Schwab was too big to train. Instead they have you read material that is not pertinent to what you need to do to be successful at your job. No one makes the time to actually manage.
My manager was not qualified with proper licenses to manage me.
The council that I was a part of had no direction. The Chair was not really interested in his position.
It is true what the Industry says about Schwab and their meetings. The managers were in meetings all day everyday. They never had time to actually manage and run their departments.
I was told by my manager that I could not speak to her or her boss because they were too busy.
Her boss met with us several times in my 5 months with the company. His only concern was his approval ratings from these surveys filled out by staff. The problem is that they know who you are and if you do not give the great marks then they know who you are and things will become difficult.
I was threatened by a manager that I would not be there for very long due to the fact that I was not his choice for the position. That threat was followed through with by my manager.

headline: Schwab values new hires over internal employees.
pros: Pay and benefits are designed to make you stick around. Most people are nice to your face.
cons:
Be prepared to be hired for the skills you bring to the table, and to have them sucked dry and left with nothing new. Schwab doesn't value its current employees. This is evidenced by it's layoffs that occur at the same time as it's acquisitions. 

The firm makes a big deal about promoting the health of it's employees, however not one of it's multiple massive campuses nationwide has an onsite workout facility. It's all show and talk at Schwab.

Senior Management is now all coming from a banking environment due to Schwab's business model, and we are now seeing the results.

cons: It's a very demanding environment. There are constant calls from advisors that are asking questions that require research consistently everyday and it just never stops. It gets mind numbing how busy it can get so the workload is excessive. The pay is really low given what is asked of you on a daily basis and they've "stiffed" me on a raise several times while still asking me to do more work.

headline: Mediocre Corporate Risk Management culture
pros: Pay is a bit above market range
cons:
- Backstabbing and very weak leadership in Corporate Risk; some have been in their roles for 15+ years and avoid change like plague. They are afraid of looking incompetent and very good at self preservation,  spending a lot of time thrashing the work of  newcomers to discredit them.

- Lots of talk about transparency but it is anything but. The moral compass seem to be missing: it is not uncommon for leadership on Corporate Risk to outright steal your work and present it as their own.

headline: Only take this if youre 100% certain you want to be a Financial Advisor
pros:
-They'll License you immediately
-Some of the managers are top quality
-Great benefits and salary is OK
cons:
-They dont tell you this is fully a call center job. 
-For 75% of the time youre there youll be doing password resets and helping people log onto their website.Even once youre licensed the most common call you will get will be someone needing help on the website or a paperwork issue. Its almost a tech support job
- They will consistently adjust your timeline there at will and call it "a business decision". You may be there 14 months, you might be there 25 months.
-Cutthroat Culture. You can only pee on your break or it will screw up your metrics.
- You have very little control on what branch you actually end up at. There were people who asked for the east coast and got Michigan
-Expect to take 50 calls in an 8 hour shift
-The performance metrics will change at will
- They expect you to wear a suit to answer calls in a phone center
-They subjectively track performance and play favorites
-If you dont like it, they wont let you transition to other departments
-The average person lasted 8 months

headline: Used to be great
pros:
- Work/life balance still better than most companies
- New Austin campus has lots of amenities like yoga and chair massage (unless you're stuck on the old campus)
- Most of the people are pretty cool
- If you get on the right team, it can be fun
cons:
- Software arm of the company is way behind, so you'll be working on outdated methods and tech stacks, and there's no education budget
- No appetite for risk, even though they say they want to experiment, so theres pressure to be like a startup without actually being able to do things that startups do
- People with no actual experience are put in charge , lots of politics, the "Digital Transformation" isnt really transforming anything its just a buzz word

If you're thinking about taking a job there, maybe wait a year for the economy to even out, it isnt stable work right now and everyone is freaked out about layoffs

headline: Good but not great

pros: Very supportive of quality of life

headline: Overall Positive Work Environment
pros: The atmosphere at Charles Schwab is about the same as every financial services corporation. People are generally positive, the benefits are solid, and there are a lot of different opportunities. Most departments have a generous bonus pool and the campus is very nice.
cons: If finance is not your forte and you are just in Schwab for a job, its a grind. Management has the same problems as many organizations. Sometimes communication is lacking and the direction of the team is changing constantly. It feels like one thing will be proclaimed, and then it will be forgotten a month later.

headline: Toxic Culture in Risk
pros: *Great peers across the business that are willing to collaborate and help even with the horrible situation with management.
cons:
*Backstabbing management in CRM (MDs and up will use your work as their own while disparaging your work). This leads to a toxic environment where there are no promotions unless you're the favorite (even if you get glowing reviews).
*ERM in particular is led by clueless leadership and very different from industry peers. There are individuals that have great external experience and therefore give competent guidance, but the overall direction is creating additonal more overhead and pushing busy work on other groups.
*Audit does not understand the business (they are in-sourcing the function) and repeats exams continuously.
*Management horribly planned for a macroeconomic and rate environment without considering possible risks to that plan (ie., rate cuts).
*Cost cutting has put a damper on what was a good learning environment, if you don't need licensing for work, you are no longer are allowed to sign up for the review course and take the exam.

headline: Daily Grind
pros: Lots of overtime opportunities. You need overtime to make up for the small base salary.
cons: Call after call after call after call. It never ends.

headline: Too brittle
pros:
Good benefits.
Good work life balance.
cons: 600 people are getting laid off this week merely because interest rates are falling. If you enjoy career uncertainty and being on an emotional roller coaster that depends on the market's constant fluctuations, then this is the place for you.

headline: Place to Learn, Not Grow
pros: People are "Schwab Nice." Pretty professional environment in general. Benefits are pretty decent and in line with competitors. This is a good place if you're nearing the end of your career, but young people are unlikely to stay for more than 5 years.  Lot of good management up at the top. Many of the VPs and SVPs are very personable and willing to help. Problems start at the MD levels.
cons: Old school company and slow to change. Promotions are usually done level by level and it is difficult to move up quickly. Much of middle management is only concerned about their own career growth and afraid to challenge the status quo.  There are certain areas of the company where sexism is rampant. Not a bad place to be early in your career, but not if you want to be in the fast lane for growth. Managers do not really care about your growth, so you have to be proactive about what you want, which can become exhausting. You'll find yourself asking for the same thing three or four times before there's any movement.

headline: Great starter career
pros: Schwab offers great benefits and they will pay for licensing.
cons: Pay is lacking for college degree candidates, departments are divided greatly, management has no sense of direction or game plan, and difficult to move within the company.

headline: Good place to work

cons: They outsourced most jobs out of SF

headline: Business Process Analyst

headline: Not a career - just a stepping stone
pros: The pay is ok, not impressive but enough you will at least survive.  If you worked hard for a CFP or CFA designation, you might pull in 150K / year.  You will also learn a great deal about the industry.
cons: This is a financial planning firm.  Even though your clients may want deep investment conversations regarding the market, management actually discourages this.  The culture has shifted away from investments  and more towards insurance and financial planning.  For large clients looking to navigate through the markets this focus away from investments can be a problem. Key metrics for your success are how many financial plans did you run and how did you score on client surveys.

headline: Zero Career Development
pros: Decent benefits and they will pay for your 7 and 63.
cons: Toxic culture, managing directors are hardly personal and only seem to be concerned with their own career. There has been a lot of reorganization happening mainly because peoples are getting fired or leaving. There is no incentive for going above and beyond, people manager play favorites.

headline: Good culture

headline: Good starting point but not a place to grow
pros:
- Very hard-working people 
- Nice and modern campus
- The company is growing 
- Decent vacation and sick package
- You get sabbatical 
- The pay is decent compared to most companies. 
- It is a good place to work if you are easily satisfied. For those who have a growth mindset will jump after a few years  for the reasons below in the “Cons” section.
cons:
This is based on my personal experience at the company in the STS organization.

- Make sure you negotiate your starting salary because it’s very hard to get a raise. Even if your manager rated you “exceed expectations” two years in a row for your annual review, it doesn’t matter. Upper mgmt will downgrade you to meeting expectations. 

- Promotion is not based on merit. It is based on available budget and relationships. Having a good manager matters.
If you take on more responsibilities and go beyond the scope of your role, it doesn’t mean you will get a raise or a promotion. Your manager can request for it but it goes up to VP/Sr VP for the decision. There are certain orgs you do not want to work in.

- Once you are an employee, internal transfer is not that easy to get. Hiring managers tend to hire external candidates. For internal jobs, it will be a lateral transfer. 

- It is not really an agile organization. The company wants to move in that direction but it’s very slow. Yes you have scrum teams but that is just a shell because mindset is not there yet. Management is resistant to making changes. They talk well BUT no actions.

- Based on who is your organization leader  is (ex VP, Sr VP, MD, etc) the culture can be very hierarchical, controlling and basically a lack of trust.

-

The pay is below the requirements of the job. At times you're a glorified insurance policy for clients. The ways to advance in the company are very linear. headline: Good Company for most
pros: Benefits are good.  The Lone Tree campus is beautiful (though parking is a long walk).   In some teams, there is a supportive balanced atmosphere.   Employee Branch is great; advice on financial planning is super.
cons:
Schwab is a large company, with an even larger company culture.  Be careful which area and manager you chose.  Many groups are great, with happy people.  But many teams in STS (Technology) have issues.  The personality of the VP drives the culture: collaborative or controlling; hierarchical or agile; ideas are welcomed or  seen as challenging.   I recommend you try to find someone in the potential group and ask pointed questions.  

Salary is on the low side; it may start out at 40th percentile, but will quickly fall far behind market.   If you have skills that are highly in demand, you will eventually have to leave.  Don't think you can apply for another of the dozens of open positions in Schwab either: I applied for 4 internally posted jobs, for which I was qualified, and did not receive anything in response.  Nothing except the automated reply that my application was received.  

It makes me sad to leave, but it won't be long now.

headline: Overworked / Underpaid
pros:
Good company culture, friendly environment, everyone is quick to assist if you need it. 

Also, Schwab used to have a program where they pay for you to get your series 7 and 63, and they put you through a 5 week course where they actually pay you to come to work and study. That is no longer a benefit that they offer though, so this is more of a con.
cons: The position is a grind, simply put. It is essentially a call center position where you sit down and take call after call day after day. For the amount of stress that comes with the position, the pay has to be more than it is. There is no incentive to stay in Advisor Services, other than paying your bills. The position is high turnover, and there's no mystery why.

headline: Hard to get promoted to VP
pros: Great benefits, vacation increases over the years, a month sabbatical after five years of service
cons: Too many VP, so they can’t promote a lot f Managing Director.  When a VP role opens up, they look at external candidates.   They are now creating a Senior Managing Director role, which they promote as a career opportunity..but we all know that’s just another ceiling to move up to VP.   Also they have this Average Bonus Opportunity..what they don’t tell you is that you have to be at the top performer to get this.

headline: Doesn't Walk the Talk
pros: - Staff are mostly great people and have made a lot of life-long friends
cons:
- effectively no medical care since it is a very high yearly deductible, which causes many to avoid getting treatment or having to scrimp on medication - basically only good for catastrophic events unless you have a lot of savings
- very fiscally conservative, which causes them to overreact due to possible future market changes & hiring or un-hiring on a whim
- "work/life balance" is entirely at the discretion of your manager

headline: Great place to work

headline: "Participant Services"
pros: Your relationship with your co-workers. No other pros about this department
cons: Pay, stress, constant calls, Quality Incidents (AQ), lack of career development, micro management, trap you in this department for 18 months minimum, 45-50 10 minute calls a day which is an insane amount of work for the pay.  Constant hiring in this department happens for a reason!

headline: Great Company, People, Compensation and Growth Potential
pros: Intelligent, Focused, Driven Leadership.  Good Work/Life Balance.  Supportive management that doesn't micro manage - you are able to accomplish great things and supported in your efforts to do so.  Company is focused on Innovation and Growth.
cons: Very little to say negatively about Schwab.  I feel respected, appreciated and excited for my future.

headline: Good Company
pros: Service-oriented culture.  Great work environment.  Places a premium on diversity.  Deep care for clients.
cons: Large company and takes a long time to do things.

headline: Stepping Stone
pros: Decent Benefits, Ok pay. Some good people that work here. Flexible hours if you outperform.
cons: They say what you want to hear and under deliver with promises. You have to hit at least 12 Financial Plans per month regardless of client needs. Starting to product push FCs. You snooze you lose mentality on pay. The numbers are more important than your professional and personal growth. "Anonymous" surveys ranking the workplace at Schwab. Managers ask you to rank high and discuss the opportunities later. Executive management isn't on the same level of understanding what the client's needs are.

headline: Not bad if you don’t mind being on the phone all day
pros: The company will support you any way they can. Very open communication with upper management. Good benefits
cons: Dealing with clients who won’t listen to you, on par with any customer service job.

headline: Great...if you know the right people

headline: Great Place to work!
pros: Great people and a true client focused environment.
cons: Cost of living in Chicago

headline: Reg Rep at Schwab
pros: Good managers, team-based environment, care for the client.
cons: Heavy phone-based work environment.

headline: Churn and Burn
pros: Paid time to study for licensing exams during normal work hours, 401k match/benefits, good exposure to financial markets if you are new to the industry
cons: This is strictly a call center job, nothing more. Lateral career moves that the the company tries to hype up to make it seem like you’re advancing in your career, when in reality you’re still stuck answering phones in a call center. A single bad survey from a client can ruin your chance to get a 2% semi-annual raise, even if the client has an open Schwab account that has never held a balance. Survey’s are non-appealable. Education is simply not valued, so be prepared to have someone who was an Art or English major as your manager. The clients can be very difficult and many threaten to “take their accounts elsewhere”, and rightfully so because Schwab is difficult to do business with and does not make things easy for clients, mainly because it is an over-the-top conservative firm. Other departments that you have to call out to for help with client issues are not helpful at all and will blow you off just so they won’t have to speak with the client themselves.

headline: good work environment
pros: Close to senior management. Regular meetings are held to communicate with the head of department. You can also talk to the council team about your concerns.
cons: Not friendly to foreign employees

headline: Amazing Company

cons: Very Corporate environment, but the trade is worth it

headline: Great place to grow in the brokerage industry

headline: Okayish Job

headline: Good Company

headline: Great company to work for

headline: Garbage Slave Work

cons: garbage pay, unmotivated coworkers, disorganized management, all about sucking up and stroking ego's. No work life balance, micro managed. terrible place to work.

headline: Great Work Environment. Barriers to Entry High.
pros:
Client base is strong and involved with the company. 
Mangement is the core of the strength of the company. 
Always felt encouraged to suceed and ask questions.
cons:
Series 7 and Series 66 Requirement.
Can be extremely demanding if you work in a busy branch.

headline: Hell on earth, and that’s on a good day.
pros: Sabbatical is a good benefit. They also pay you on time.
cons: This place might be better than a North Korean labor camp, but it is certainly awful. I utterly detest this company and can’t wait to resign. It might be a good fit for those missing the ultra strict rule of middle school, but it’s awful for adults. Love micromanagement? You’ll feel right at home here. This is also a good place if you love 1990s technology held together by duct tape. For all other professionals, run far away from this company.

headline: great work culture
pros: great work place, they will work with you and your situation to succeed. Constantly trying to develop your skills
cons: 2 years locked in before you can move off the phones.

headline: Good company but a changing culture
pros:
Really great people many of whom have made Schwab a career of 15, 20 and even 30 years.
Strong company with great senior leadership. There's a vision, plan and execution to drive the company forward.
Interesting and challenging work with a clear understanding of how it helps the company and its customers.
cons:
Technology teams are overburdened and under staffed.
Middle and lower management are either pressured and unrealistic about achievable results.
Few promotion opportunities.
Lots of losses of solid talent, some with long tenure, across multiple teams.

headline: Great Company

headline: Culture

headline: Charles Schwab Company Review

headline: Advisor Services

headline: Good Company, Great for the right people
pros: The company invests a ton into training and managing employees - the life balance and people are top notch. Learn a ton, and enjoy great benefits.
cons: Working on the phones as a broker is not for everyone. It can be tedious, and very "corporate" as far as time management and breaks go. 2 Year commitment before advancement from the broker role.

headline: Good place to work
pros: steady work without concern of job security
cons: runs lean and can be a heavy workload

headline: Great product offering and best in class ethics, poor planning software, redundant compliance.
pros: A very ethical company.  Compensation paid to employees for offering zero cost robo portfolios is the same as managed services that charge .90%.  Allows Financial Consultant to do what's in the clients best interest.  Best ethical firm I have worked for and would recommend friends and family to Schwab.   Team based approach more than other firms when working with AFC and CRS.
cons: Advice Suite planning tool is embarrassingly archaic and not user friendly.  Even tenured FC's have little confidence in input and outputs of tool and the only way to get help is to email some group and wait 24-48 hrs to get an answer on the planning tool, sometimes not even answering the question you asked.  Compliance requirements for documenting has become a nightmare and a major headwind in productivity for business development.  Lots of duplicate note making and button clicking.  Branch management and FC's are stretched thin and have little time for reaching out to existing clients or prospecting for new clients.  Note taking by phone reps when clients call in is mostly non-existant or notes are located in 1 of 3 places for the FC to dig through.

headline: The Worst Department to Work in Charles Schwab
pros: Good co-workers, sometimes free lunch
cons: You are working in the call center. You are only metrics. Managers micromanage you. RUN!!! Do not work in here. This is the most stressful job and also dreadful. You will only be viewed as NUMBERS. Discrimination happens. Charles Schwab only cares of CLIENTS but not EMPLOYEES. THE WORST PLACE TO WORK.

headline: You take the good with the bad
pros: Ambitious, innovative projects to work on. Friendly coworkers. In-house meteorologist. Great location in the heart of downtown Raleigh. It's motivating and inspiring that Chuck himself is interested in the success of what I'm working on.
cons: All recent hires I’ve spoken to have complained of deceptive hiring practices. Bonus is quoted in terms of a theoretical maximum, not in terms of what’s normal. Time off is provided in terms of combined paid AND sick leave, but in reality taking sick leave is broadly frowned upon (long time staff cynically brag about how much sick leave they’ve accumulated over their time at Schwab, it's sad). I was told everyone works 9-5 but more realistically it’s 8-5. When it comes to parking your car, you're on your own. Expect to pay $1,500 annually out of pocket and to fight daily for a parking space downtown.

headline: Oversold at Recruitment, what was once a family style organization, has turned into a corporate, disconnected mess.
pros:
The company does have a decent benefit package. 
They are willing to work with you to move to different departments if they like your work ethic. 
They pay for your licensing.
cons:
Very Corporate, not a cohesive environment.

I was personally lied to by a recruiter, he over promised bonuses, gave me an abbreviated timeline for my position, and I was not paid as much as promised. 

I felt like a number on a spreadsheet instead of an engaged employee, brown nosers received recognition over people who have the numbers to back up their performance.
