headline: Disappointing......
pros: There are some really talented people who work on the team, that work hard and care about their jobs.  Unfortunately, they are very underutilized.
cons: Compliance Senior Leadership does not inspire or promote the members of their teams.  Environment is very political, promotions based on who you know, not what you know.  No team camaraderie.  Also, there is a severe lack of communication.  Teams get reorganized, but there is no announcement of the change.  This treatment shows sincere disdain for the people who work there.

headline: wow

headline: Great Place to Work

headline: Lots of promise left unfulfilled
pros: The company is much younger inside than people think. Lots of energetic people wanting to do good work.
cons: HR is non-existent. This means that bad managers are all over the place and are not getting the leadership and guidance they need in how to lead/develop people. People are leaving or considering leaving in big numbers due to poor managers and no one to turn to.

headline: A Bad System Will Beat a Good Person Every Time
pros:
Reasonable pay, good bonuses, and strong benefits.
I had a really good manager for the first couple years there and it was great.  I thought we were building something good.
cons:
Politics and cronyism to get promoted (especially in management).

I had the worst manager of my career for my last year and a half there.  It's sad to the department that I helped build be destroyed.  People are leaving in droves.  They're promoting and hiring incompetent yes-men and passing over talented leaders.

Illegal discrimination is rampant in the technical leadership.  I firsthand saw ageism and racism used and attempted to be used in hiring and promotion decisions (oddly enough, the racism was that they had too many Indians in leadership and needed to hire white people as diversity hires).  In retrospect I think I should have reported it, but HR was clearly there to protect the company and not the employees.

Micromanagement is the theme with Engineering leadership.  EVPs and SVPs are on tech-lines trying to control chaos instead of empowering teams to do good work and getting the systems to work for them instead of against them.  My leadership would hardly ever promote someone into management.  Would hire 10 new managers for every 1 they'd promote.

Hiring process is a joke anyway.  I was hired for a Sr. Manager role with a 2 hour interview and then a several week wait for the background check.  They don't know how to consistently hire good talent, so if you go there you'll be working with a mix of good people who got duped, incompetents who can't get a better job, and a ton of contractors from India.  Some of the contractors are really good, but they're typically looking for new jobs outside this drain-circling Titanic once they get to the US.

headline: Charles Schwab is the perfect employer to both begin and build your financial career.
pros:
Job security
Overtime opportunities
“Guaranteed” quarterly bonuses 
Dollar-for-dollar 401(k) match up to 5% of salary ^IMMEDIATELY 100% VESTED^
Licensing opportunities
Room for growth
cons: Slightly underpaid compared to similar financial firms, I think this is mainly due to the REAL dedication to Schwab clients.

headline: Branch Consideration
pros: The breadth and depth of solutions available is great for the overwhelming majority of investors
cons: Location plays a big part in your success as well as if local management plays favoritism in allocation of leads. Additionally, if you are looking to engage in comprehensive financial planning yourself - this is not the firm for you. The volume required does not lend itself to being able to spend the time required to do that successfully.

headline: Broker

cons: On the phones way too much

headline: Intern

headline: It felt like "1984"

cons: It's not a meritocracy! If you know the right people in management you get promotions and salary raises. If you only focus on working hard and delivering good quality and on time then Tim Heier and his people will destroy your career.

headline: Great company for employees and clients

headline: Employment review
pros: access to industry knlowledge that can be used for personal growth

headline: Sweatshop - Great for Clients, Brutal for Employees
pros: Respected Company in financial industry.
cons: Workload is insane all day long. Metrics are competing against each other so creates bad blood among co-workers as everyone is fighting over chicken scraps.

headline: Customer service associate

headline: Human Resources
pros: Lots of opportunity for advancement.
cons: Salaries can not always be negotiated.

headline: Work at a branch
pros: Most team members were great.
cons: Other team members get ahead through friendships instead of skills or production

headline: Software Applications Engineer

cons: There really are not any cons!

headline: Phenomenal Company
pros: The way clients’ and customers’ needs are placed as top priority is amazing. Great culture and great people.
cons: Can sometimes run too lean as an organization.

headline: Content Strategist
pros: Great place to work, people are nice. Work/life balance is real.
cons: None. This place is what you make it.

headline: Estate Relationship Specialist
pros: Above average compensation and good cafeteria onsite.
cons: Management in the Estate division lacks people skills, plays favorites and could care less about developing its staff.  Call center environment where reps are micromanaged and treated like children.

headline: Great Company, not so great program
pros: Charles Schwab is a great company to work for.  The people are very friendly and nice to work with and the company holds true to its values. It’s a collaborative environment with a team focus.
cons: The recruiters need to know the role better so they can explain it more accurately to prospects. I was told that there was some time answering phones  but there was a big focus on development as a financial consultant. We had one hour meeting once every two weeks if the phones weren’t busy. It takes a year in the position to start even discussing financial plans. What the position really entails is answering phones 8-10 hours straight each day. You rotate through the program but each rotation involves answering phones for rude clients. I know I am not the only person in the program that felt the position was not described accurately.

headline: Great company, great culture
pros: Caring responsive culture, great career path.
cons: salary can be on the lower end of the industry

headline: Associate Relationship Specialist
pros: The cafeteria in the building makes lunch convenient. Learned a broad spectrum of information in finance, but no depth.
cons: Call center environment and the managers are competitive to get ahead any way possible even if they do not want to be there. Minorities do not get very far with the company.

headline: Scrum Master
pros: Good culture, I was fortunate to work with multiple teams of great people.
cons: For my path, the migration of IT staff out of San Francisco was a show stopper.

headline: Change Passwords for a Living
pros: Schwab Nice is legit. Somehow Schwab has really nice people working for the company.
cons: Pretty much everything. The majority of the time on the phone is changing passwords for clients. seriously.

headline: Good Company
pros: Good Company with solid values.  Client-focused
cons: Could pay more to employees

headline: Great culture
pros: Good benefits, friendly people, useful market information learned on a daily basis. Management is transparent about career progression.
cons: 30 minute lunch, pay, sometimes feel micromanaged

headline: Great place to work
pros:
- Projects are interesting 
- Work life balance
cons: - Hard to climb the ladder

headline: Bad place for serious IT professionals
pros: Pays the bills and has a decent bonus structure
cons:
1. Nothing gets done quickly.  Many redundant layers of approvals and 
     structured in silos that promote finger pointing.
2. Too much bureaucracy with various interpretations of the process.
3. Big brother watching you in everything you do.
4. Depending on which group you work for you may end up with little to no 
     Work life balance.
5. Benefits are expensive and below average for a financial company.

headline: Great Company, Just not for IT people
pros:
Great Pay
Discounts on Banking and Trade Products
Fun Team Builders and Parties
Amazing Co-Workers
cons:
Management is Not very LGBT+ Friendly, but colleagues are.

Management tends have no knowledge of how things works in their own departments.

They will not hire the needed internal people to solve issues, but only use vendors and apps. 

When things go wrong because they decided to invest in vendors and temps instead of skilled workers, Management will point fingers at whoever they can instead of getting things fixed.

They are behind tech wise in every possible, I mean seriously they haven't figured out how automate the most simple tasks. There are way to many employees who's jobs should be automated and by doing so would reduce costs and processing time.

Everyone is scared of asking questions.

Business Attire at all times if you work in the corporate area eve if you will never see a customer, vendor, or anyone else who is not a Schwab Employee.

Meetings about meetings, and about 80% of them most people don't need to be in the first place.

headline: Killing you slowly with delays and kindness
pros: Full of smart, honest, and ethical people that care about customers.
cons:
Honest feedback and direct communication is extremely rare due to the "Schwab nice" but dysfunctional culture which leads to a lot of passive aggressive communication and back channel deals. 

Extremely slow adopting new technology and methods.

headline: HR
pros: The spirit of giving is real at Schwab. There are many good people who care about giving back.
cons:
The HR Org is run top down with a lack of creativity and far to few people who can execute. Ideas and innovation are pushed aside for efforts that are focused on only the executive team. Significant waste of money at a high opportunity cost.

Identify attrition within Sr. Mngt and how many in middle managers are in the process of looking when considering a position within HR at Schwab.

headline: Entry Finance
pros: Great benefits and bonuses are given
cons: Alot of power is given to managers

headline: Risk Ops - Identity Crisis
pros:
Nice Campus
Friendly People
Decent Pay
Ok Benefits
cons:
Thou shall NOT Communicate  & Collaborate
Thou shall NOT ask questions or be empowered
Thou shall NOT  streamline or innovate
Thou shall NOT step out of your lane
Trying to turn a processing group function into a micro managed call center, typical attempt to shove square pegs into round holes.

headline: Associate Financial Services Professional
pros: Flexibility and promotion opportunities
cons: Low pay and location choices

headline: Sr Manager

Schwab treats employees well
Bonuses are great
Pay is on par with other large companies

28 Day paid paid sabbatical every 5 years in addition to vacation days
Company leadership is amazing with an incredible CEO
cons: It can be difficult to break into people management without Schwab management experience

headline: Alternative Investments
pros:
- Sabbatical
- Time off

cons: Poor leadership. You're better served working in a different department.  Nepotism runs rampant in department as you will only benefit if you are friends with the director.

headline: Meh

-onsite dining with great options
-people who challenge your thinking
-range of work was varying
cons:
-horrible leadership who had very poor communication skills
-promotion of mediocrity
-"Schwab nice" is an excuse for not providing feedback

headline: Comensation managers
pros: good place to work, friendly people
cons: Moving jobs outside bay area, never know when you'll be laid-off

headline: Do your research
pros: There was a nice cafe' on the campus.  Nice desks that raise and lower. Thorough training and paid for study for the licensing exams.  Decent company match in 401k.  Street Smart Edge is nice to utilize.
cons: Poor schedule.  I was told I would get one out of my top 3 choices...nope got to choose between 2 that were not in my list.  The technology is lacking!  There are around 11 different sites or programs to use on any given day.  This needs to be incorporated into a better user interface.  They say you need to get your Series 7 in 5 months, but during training they said "we will get to that soon enough".  After 3 months of answering phones to reset passwords and no idea when we get the opportunity to study and take the series 7 was absurd.  No timeline or communication.  Just change passwords for clients all day.  The phone system is very stringent.  You have to abide by the schedule very close.  Constant 80-100 calls a day..... just changing passwords..... lol

headline: Financial Service Professional
pros: Decent training, attainable performance goals, ongoing career mentorship, clear expectations, opportunity for overtime
cons: Very little downtime and time is very structured, direct managers are often unavailable, most offered shifts are 10-hours long,  opportunity for career growth with the company may be limited, depending on willingness to relocate.

headline: Gem of a culture
pros:
Work Life Balance
Good Benefits (6% matching, instant vesting)
Culture
Empowered Workforce
cons:
Unclear expectations
High Turnover of entry level roles

headline: Solid Corporation
pros: company reputation, focus on clients, company stability
cons: total compensation, variability of experience and culture depending on business unit

headline: Turnover,  churn over, employees are tools
pros: Competitive advantage, strong Corporate suite, brand recognition
cons: Schwab burns through employees with little regard for their well-being.  In less than five years, I had four managers.  There was no support in the branches.  Much is said, little is done.  Work loads are unending.  Clients receive little attention.  Employees receive less.  Management cares about management--nothing more.

headline: Great org
pros: Great culture, everyone is very helpful
cons: Highly over engineered processes in HR and TA

headline: Not for People with High IQs

cons:
Outdated everything - technology, work environment, knowledge base.
If you have a very high IQ, but are more focused on ability to achieve then patting others on the back - look elsewhere.

headline: Financial Consultant Partner
pros: I do not have much good to say about this company except the that there are many good people who work there.
cons:
Terrible place to work!!! Think twice before working here!!!!There are good people who work there. But they are extremely overworked and underpaid!!!  Also, customers don’t value the relationship with the consultant largely because of the $4.95 Commerical that the companies constantly runs resulting in the consultant not being valued as an advisor. Clients look at the firm as a commodity to be compared against competitors. 

Also,managers has favorites which alienated other employees. 

The amount of work you are given is insane!!!

No matter how Schwab replies, I have no other motives than to warn unsuspecting potential employee of challenges they will encounter. 

Seriously consider another company. 

GOOD LUCK

headline: Abandoning their roots.
pros: Good pay. Good benefits. Telecommuting options for full-time employees.
cons: No great leadership for the online portion of the company. Everything is segmented. Its like you're not on a Schwab ship, you're just part of the fleet and you're not sure who is steering. Not allowed to give online feedback on coworkers until you leave the firm.

headline: Estate Services
pros: Consistent hours, Cafe, free valet parking, HSA plan
cons: Everything else. This company does not care about any department that is not revenue generating. They decided to make licensing,  a condition of employment  for employees who have been there for years. They bring in new people for more money than they pay their current employees. They also are very secretive. when someone leaves the company, the team members do not know until the person's last day, which leaves the team scrambling to cover their workload. They don't care about their employees but try to smooth things over with an occasional pizza party. There is no structure for procedure at this time and it is just like the wild wild west because everyone is doing their own thing. There are very little checks and balances. Management sticks together when the employee has an issue creating an US vs Them mentality

headline: Director

headline: Interview
pros: pay is decent and most folks are friendly
cons: very disconnected, unorganized infighting and no team work. Does not seem like IT department knows what it is doing

headline: Polite, Courteous, and  Passive Aggressive
pros: Bankers hours; low stress; a cube to call your own
cons:
-Travel back to 50’s style management styles -leave your aspirations of autonomy, mastery, and purpose at the security turnstile.
-Clinging to the outdated org structure and mindset of  “business” people and “tech” people.
-Arrogant and pompous old school  boys club-not a progressively minded company at all.
-Good ol’ lifers club protect their own and only welcome in those who are willing to play their game their way.  
-Passive aggressive tactics towards anyone who brings a different perspective or tries to break the lifers out of their stale trenches.
-A collection of the most polite, courteous jerks as they passively undermine your career goals.
-Do as you are told-don’t challenge authority or the hierarchy of the org structure and you could have a job for life. .
-If you have worked in a modern tech or product company, be prepared for severe culture shock and schedule your lobotomy today.  You will no longer need the logic and reasoning portion of your mind.

headline: Financial Specialist
pros:
Licenses
Random bonuses 
Overtime Availability
Dress however you want
Some managers are competent
cons:
The list is long...
You're micromanaged to an extreme. There's a required contact percentage to be hit on a quarterly basis, which means if you work 4x10's, you're on the phones for at least 32 hours a week, minimum. You're told life gets better once you become a "broker" but truly, you're just an "order enterer". You continue to reset passwords on a daily basis and deal with the most uneducated clientele possible.
There's an 18 month commitment to the role that now turned into 24 months... why... some please explain. This is exactly the reason people get licensed and jump ship. 
Sure work/life balance is great, but you hate your job and once you go home, you're exhausted from a crappy day at work saving the passwords. 
They praise all this "culture" but you barely have 5 minutes to have a conversation with your colleagues. It's truly a nightmare. 
Also, their talent acquisition team is first to hire absolute garbage.

headline: Financial Consultant Partner (FCP) role is a trap
pros: The biggest benefit of working at Schwab is being able to get licensed. There is potential to advance your career if you know the right people too. Benefits are okay but are not keeping up with the rest of country, especially San Francisco. There are opportunities to learn about the industry and work with great clients and coworkers. The work life balance for most roles is great too.
cons: If you are considering applying for the Financial Consultant Partner (FCP) role with the expectation that you will become a Financial Consultant (FC) you will most likely be disappointed. Of the many FCPs I know across the country, only 2-3 have made direct transitions to become Financial Consultants. This role has an obligatory 2 year commitment period as well. As the role is so varied in scope, there is often disparity between FC expectations and expectations of branch management which leads to inconsistent performance reviews, especially considering that these decisions don't involve input from your FC. I found myself "stuck" in this role with little upward mobility after my commitment period. If you are serious about working in the branch location and becoming an FC, you are much better off applying as an Associate Financial Consultant (AFC) at Schwab. As an AFC you received mentorship from your branch FCs, the Branch Manager & your AFC peers and typically progress to FC within 1-2 years. If you are passionate about service and administrative work, then the FCP role could work for you.

headline: Manager - Sales and Production

If you are looking for an excellent company to build an life-long career, Schwab is the place.  Co-workers are very dynamic and engaging.  I've worked for several large investment firms and Schwab has the best culture by far!  If you like to challenge yourself and stay engaged, then this is a great company to work for.
cons: Work is very fast pace and hectic at times.  If you are looking for a "mellow" environment that does not change rapidly, then you will not enjoy working here.

headline: Bad culture in technology
pros:
Good benefits.  Pay is OK.   

If able to create  your own emergency and be the hero and you'll be rewarded a lot (bonus, stock, annual increase).  You can really engineer yourself some great financial rewards.
cons:
Terrible culture with a lot of politics in the software development organization.  Management stack ranks employees and takes money from the lower ranked people to give to their far exceeds.  Instead of working together people are working against one.  No collaboration and a lot of back stabbing going on. 

If you don't get in the right click early enough you're pretty much always going to get "Met All" or below rating and your bonus and annual adjustment will be impacted.

headline: No promotion after 2 yrs as a team lead.  Department VP/MD manipulative
pros: Great benefits and overall culture is client oriented.  Colleagues are generally helpful and pleasant to work with.
cons: As the corporation grows larger, some department heads are either poorly trained (don’t know the job grade structure) or simply cutting corners on promoting and paying their top performers fairly.  Seeing more often managers ask top performers to lead a team without paying them more or on track for a promotion.  Manipulative tactics to talk their employees into believing they are given an opportunity to learn to lead, but in reality they just pile on more responsibilities (also alleviate work load of MDs) and save $$$ on compensating for the work the employees perform.

The pay is not good and there is so much turnover that the people brought in are very uneducated. Getting paid the same as someone with little to no finance knowledge is not good. They have shifted to a new efficiency system that emphasizes numbers over helping people. Doesn’t matter how smart you are, they only care about numbers and brown nosing.

Lots of people have been laid off with no option of relocation to other developing locations.  They are heavily investing in other new offices in Denver, Texas and elsewhere, but sadly cutting back on their longtime SF presence.  As a result, room to grow in SF is very limited.

headline: Poor training environment
pros:
Good Benefits and nice cafeteria but really expensive 
Nice co-workers
Beautiful campus inside and out 
There’s no other Pros to say
cons: Where do I even begin to start? First of all, the training is not geared to different types of learning. The trainer is rarely in the room and all you do is read and do Wbt’s. There wasn’t much training to learn how to use the systems. Never prepared you for the calls that you really take. When you have your one on ones with your boss, there is NO positivity. It’s always about what you did wrong. When I had questions that I put in the team chat, my boss would tell me that I should already know the answer from what I learned in training. I tried telling her that people learn differently but she always compared me to other peers and made me feel stupid. She had no confidence in me. There were other peers in my training class that also had difficulty understanding concepts of the job. I think her main goal was to get me out of there. She didn’t like me from the start. I plan to call HR to report her, regarding inappropriate things that she has said to me. I Do NOT RECOMMEND THIS JOB TO ANYONE ! She was the worst boss I ever had and the rest are like her too! Don’t let the name Charles Schwab fool you!

headline: Managing Director Technology
pros: Does what is really best for the clients, very ethical.  Every action we do is focused on what is best for the clients. Has good products to support clients needs.
cons: Technology work culture is changing very fast in some areas thus losing the true Schwab value. With infusion of Visa folks at tech Management level, promotion is happening at a rapid rate. They are brought on as MD and quickly  promoted to VP role even if they are incompetent to be Schwab officers.  The newly minted VPs lack people management skills let alone understand employee engagement, their  only focus is pleasing their bosses and literally does not care about the employees. It is very sad to see erosion of true Schwab culture which embodied and cherished employee growth and career but now employees are  treated like worker bees.  HR has become very incompetent, only thing they are good at is investigating complaints and afraid to take any actions after. In spite of record Schwab profits, an employee with Exceeds Expectations is paid below bonus opportunity which makes us wonder if management is reaping all of it at the cost of employees- just so unethical. Overall morale is so low, we need to constantly encourage our employees to stay motivated.

headline: Great team, only getting better
pros: I can only say the previous rating is a disgruntled former employee.  While, there is accountability to exceed your targets, coaching from the manager and other team mates is high.  This is a competitive environment, so if you are willing to work hard, it will pay off.  Not an easy job and not for everyone, but you will be challenged to grow in your career.  What other place gives you a sabbatical after 5 years of employment. so for those that state the company is not committed to Work/Life balance, they are wrong.
cons: The volume is high, but with proper time management skills, shouldn't be a problem.

headline: Call Center-College Students and MBA's Avoid
pros: Good benefits and 401(k), not much else
cons: The pay is mediocre. Make no mistake, you are working in CALL CENTER. Every minute of your time is micro-managed. You can make many lateral moves, but still are in call center position. There is no regard for education-many managers are simply uneducated.

headline: Investment Consultant
pros: Great way to start learn the business, Schwab is dedicated to developing your knowledge of the industry
cons: The pay is one of the lowest in the field, typically you will be looking for something else within a year or two.

headline: I loved my time at Schwab
pros:
- Smart, caring, passionate driven, people all around you
- Constantly investing in technology
- Excellent communication from the top down
- Investment in individuals

There isn't much that I didn't like about my time at Schwab (and it was a lot of time).  I worked on many exciting projects, constantly expanded my knowledge/skills, and grew my career via promotions.
cons: This one is a double edged sword and that is the size of the company.  Schwab is very large and you have to work to stand out.  Understanding the mechanics of how work and business are done in a large company are necessary to progress.  That said, being a large company there are plenty of opportunities to grow if you are paying attention.

headline: Are you part of the IN crowd
pros: None at all haven’t experienced one
cons:
This place is worse than high school.  Treatment from management is based on your band level. This is not just your manager this treatment comes from other departments managers, directors as well as VPs and above. They act like you are not worth their time and look at you as though you don’t have a right to speak to them. 

Work life balance is a joke when it comes to lower band employees.  Never have I been able to utilize this so called balance. I feel sorry for anyone who wants to work here that has children. An employee Having children is more a burden to the company. 
Now th Insurance is great for those with higher bands and higher pay who can afford an office visit  based on their  salary.

Special treatment for the IN crowd, sure they can work from home, came in late and they can leave early.  Go to doctors appointments without using sick time, take 2 hours lunch’s and no one is to say a word. All you can do is sit and keep your mouth shut. They don’t want you talking about it. If you do be prepared to lose your job.

As said managers treatment is beyond micromanager.  I hope you can hold your pee for your next break.

The friend game so you want a promotion will you better hope you really befriended your management because they already are looking to hire a good friend of there’s

headline: If a good culture is what you are looking for, you can find better.
pros:
-Stability: It would appear to take a LOT to get let go, but only for full time employees and not so much for contractors.
-Decent place to get started maybe as a first job in the field, but only for a year or two.
-People managers: they seem pretty awesome.
-Very much a 9-5 job. Most people are actually asked not to work any more than that.
cons:
Unfortunately I agree very much with many of the other reviews I have read for the same position at this company.

-Technical managers: very inflexible, and not actually open to doing things in different ways. I have witnessed too many examples of people doing extra work outside of paid hours to present a POC that is clearly better than the prescribed approach and accomplishes the same thing, get shot down for no apparent reason.
-Highly politicized work culture. Many internal employees will openly acknowledge that decisions are clearly being made for political reasons, and not the right reasons.
-No mentorship, no investment in employees education/learning/development in any real sense. You are on your own, and your growth will stop.
-Relatively high turnover, at all levels.

headline: Great Place, Average Pay

headline: Sr. Manager

headline: Participant Services Associate
pros: Management is helpful, depending on your manager. Some managers may breathe down your neck though. People are very friendly and easy to work with. Semi-relaxed atmosphere. Lots of overtime available if you're looking to increase your pay. Learned lots about 401(k) and retirement plans. Good starting position (if you can survive). Good training for series 7 and 66.
cons:
Pretty low starting salary. Micro-managing can be an issue depending on your manager. The interview was very misleading. If you are thinking about applying for this position, it is a call center. You are on the phones your entire shift. You are expected to do extra work but a typical day doesn't even allow you enough time to look at your email. You have to adhere to your schedule by. the. minute. Seriously, if you don't clock in the exact minute you're supposed to, it can add up to trouble. Work/life balance for this position is a JOKE. You have to request off at least 2 months in advance in order to have a guaranteed day off. Something comes up in two weeks and you need a day off? Not gonna happen. Unless, of course you call in 'sick'. You start with zero vacation and sick time. You are only seen as a statistic. You are all numbers. Your handle time, call time, survey scores... all numbers. The turnover is crazy high because mostly everyone is looking for a way out. You have to commit to 18 months, and it's a LONG 18 months. Oh and you only get a half an hour lunch with a scheduled 15 min break in the morning and afternoon, strange I know. Again, don't think about being a minute late back to your desk during those breaks! 

Also the company clearly doesn't invest in technology. Computers/systems are very dated. Get up to speed, it's 2018.

headline: Schwab is the best company to work for hands down!!
pros: Great atmosphere, Great management, Flexibility, Great benefits
cons: Low pay. Some of the managers are not so great and show favoritism

headline: Not the 'Best Place to Work'
pros:
- Salary is good.
- Bonus is good.
cons:
- Specifically to IT...Some good management, but also some very bad.
- Management has little interest in employee development.  Focus is entirely on what employee can do to help achieve company goals.
- Management can be extremely unprofessional.  Not truthful.  Empty words.  False promises.  Manage by intimidation.
- Management unfair and discriminatory.  Do not be surprised if all opportunities go to same person in group.
- Management looks the other way...when there are problems.
- No open door policy where you can bring a grievance to management without repercussion.
- Very individual environment...not team oriented.
- Large on/off-shore presence...and growing.

headline: Not what know but who you know in IT
pros: Decent benefits, sabbatical, Walt is still strong leader.
cons:
Internal promotions from Staff to Sr or to Manager is zero because VPs bringing in their friends from other companies.  These new line of managers lack knowledge and skills but can spill out buzzwords a mile a minute.  Combined with hiring power-monger staff eager to dominate the team, we now have this toxic cultural mess.  Used to be a courteous professional setting but now it is blatant power mongering and self promoting.

Rating the Sr Management higher because our top leaders are doing a good job still.

headline: If you like working in a culture of management clicks, then this is the place for you
pros: The people are great, benefits are decent and include a sabbatical every 5 years, The new campus in Lone Tree is nice, lots of opportunities to network outside of you daily grind.
cons: Management, management, management. As in most large organizations it depends on where you work. This company does not value workers over 40 unless you want to work part-time sitting on a phone. The technology management is a Visa click-club at best. The culture wasn't much better before all of the changes occurred with the real estate strategy that was implemented over the last 5 years. Hiring only those that they know and devaluing anyone who has worked there over 2 years. Diversity is quickly going out of the window unless you are from India. Getting forced out is not unusual it's part of the normal culture if they think you are not a fit. Don't bother trying to jump through any hoops to please, the effort will just be ignored. There is absolutely no career path and unless you are a golden child, plan on staying in the same role for your career at Schwab, especially if you are at management level.

headline: Participant Services
pros:

- My manager was solid. 
- Can move across departments

I enjoyed my team members and my manager. Overall I like the culture at schwab.
cons:
I interviewed for this role and I thought it was going to be a great position for me. A few weeks into the job I knew I made a mistake. I lasted 2 years but should have left before then. You are in a call center. You are chained to your desk. You must adhere to your schedule at all times. When you start you are training for a few weeks but the training isn't a real indicator of what you're going to be dealing with. Most calls are password resets or distributions. Schwab has a thing called AQ's. If you say the wrong thing you'll get an AQ. You can be spot on 99 out of 100 calls but if that 1 call you mess up it feels like the world is going to end. Even if it doesn't have any impact on the participants financial account. They are handed out for some of the most petty things. Your bonus is affected by AQ's. 

I had a solid manager but it felt like some managers created a poor atmosphere by always breathing down your neck. 

In the end: This role was not for me. I got my series 7 and 66 and left.

headline: Great company to work for or with with as a client
pros:
Excellent benefits. 1 month sabbatical every 5 years. Good 401k match, ESPP, potential for stock options (well, in the past). Interesting technology if that's your area.
Culture depends on location but is overall friendly and inclusive. For a finance/brokerage firm they are not as intense or confrontational as many other finance companies.
cons:
They used to have a saying that they were 'a technology company that happened to do finance'. For a long time they were at the head of the industry in terms of innovation. They are still at the top of the pack, but internally the mindset has definitely shifted to focusing on being a brokerage that uses technology efficiently. Which means outsourcing, offshoring, and moving many of the back office work to external vendors. This is just progress I guess but it was a lot more fun to work as a technologist there in the past.
It's also too bad they have mostly left the bay area where they were conceived. Working in San Francisco when they were one of the biggest employers in the city was pretty great -- you always ran into another Schwabbie in random places. Kind of like college. But SF and California have really forced employers to pay for the talent available here. Perhaps too much. So the past 4 years have been all about moving to non California locations (can anyone say Geo-Strat? ugh - if you don't know, this was the name of the long term strategy to leave CA). The new locations seem to be handing the company fine (stock has tripled in 3-4 years), but it's still sad to those of us who truly loved the camaraderie of the SF environment.

They are very understanding of family and medical needs and try to be helpful in whatever way you can. They have amazing paid parental leave and great opportunities for moving around within the company.

headline: The Schwab Financial Consultant role is NOT a career
pros: Good benefits.  Good place to get your feet wet.
cons:
Management (especially branch managers) love to micro manage.  These days they call it UOP.  
Managers play favorites and in some offices, they do not let some qualified women even interview for the FC job.  They prefer to keep them in the supporting roles.  
You will be expected to work nights and some weekends.  While management can't require it.... it is strongly inferred.  The non-compete is the worst in the industry.  Once you start working at Schwab, it is extremely difficult to leave for another Financial Services company.  I would strongly recommend looking at Fido to TD as better alternatives.

headline: DB Department
pros:
1- Able to dress business casual
2- Some departments do offer work-life balance
3- 1 month sabbatical after 5 years
cons:
1-  No direction or consistent management style.  For a small group (within a primarily 401k company), there is little understanding of the product.  The department has had two managers (and trying to get a third now)  in the past two years.
2- Upper management not interested in what happens to department personnel, nor direction of department as long as tasks get completed.
3-Department treated poorly  by other departments, not acknowledged in any real way  during annual "roadshow', or recognized for merits (managment gives rewards based upon what they think department should get vs. checking in with what personnel may actually want).
4- Department is very "click-ish", and management does not treat everyone (within same job grade or title)the same (i.e. job tasks, communication, etc.)
5- Austin-based upper manager has little understanding of product and work flow, and implements goals in a unrealistic manner.
6- No work-life balance due to the way the personnel and work flow are set up. you wil definitely end up working OT, or you will be told you do not work quickly enough based upon ridiculous/unreliable measurement tools and data.

headline: Good company but I don't see how advisors can retire here
pros:
There are lots of good here at Schwab.  Benefits are what I expects at a major company and it offers a base salary.  If you are new or have limited experiences in the financial industry, it's a great company to start your career. 

Here are a list of pros I can think of:
1. Base Income so you won't starve 
2. Good culture of helping investors
3. Lots of exposure to various solutions and ideas
4. Great client offerings
5. Pays for your CFP or other designations
cons:
With all companies, Schwab has it's cons. Rather or not you can live with it is up to the individual but I don't see how anyone can work here for the long term.  I think the management team knows and expects that.  The biggest issue here is compensation for FCs (or in branch advisors). They want you to work like a ML or independent advisor going out and get business.  However, they don't pay you like one.  The worse is that they are subsidizing the savings for investors on the back of advisors. So we see record earning and profit emails from corporate every quarter, but are told that our compensation is being reduced year over year.  The corporate bonus pool is funded at 120%, but we don't get that.  So investors get discounts in fees, executives/managers gets their bonuses, FCs gets a cut in income.  Ouch.

Second, not all FCs are the same.  Meaning that if you been with Schwab for over 10 years and had your pick of your BOB, you are likely have a solid income ($150k+). So I think Schwab management is trying to address this "issue" by tweeking FC comp.  However, it also hits new FCs so I don't see how or why I would want to stick it out.

Lastly, their bonus structure is a joke.  We all know that the name of the game is for assets and put them into management.  Charge backs are a part of that process. But Schwab took it to a new perverse level.  They require that all clients stay in the solution for 2 years or the entire bonus is paid back to Schwab, no proration.  So if someone stayed in a solution for 23 months, Schwab collected fees for 23 months, but you have pay back you ENTIRE bonus. What's worse is that it also counts gains. So in a year like 2017 where clients made 20% in the market and they decides to cash out that 20% and spent it, that 20% will count against your earnings.  Why would that make sense?

headline: Desperately needs to modernize technologically, technology team is not fully prepared
pros:
- Great pay
- Great benefits
cons:
- Everything in technology is outsourced for cost cutting
- Technology teams are vastly behind in process leaving serious issues in creating and maintaining software
- Cost cutting is the number one priority of the technology org
- Technology management seems to largely get the job from proving cost cutting rather than modernizing

headline: Great company
pros: Great culture, leadership, vision.  It's easy to rally behind the future of the company
cons: I don't have much to share here, other than the businesses can be a bit silo'd without enough cross departmental pollenization

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Excellent benefits and pay, and a wonderful culture.  Management is committed to ensuring you have the support you need in order to be successful.  A sabbatical is provided every 5 years of service.
cons: There really isn't anything that I am not a fan of at Schwab.  The only possible thing is that parking isn't great at PEAK.

headline: The department is a joke!
pros: The only pro's were maybe the benefits. I was there for about 5 years and got a sabbatical, other than that it's not the "Best Place to Work" in my opinion as well as everyone else in the department.
cons: The department is a joke, LITERALLY! Management literally run like chickens not knowing what to do there. The best part is that it's a compliance department but they have you under "operations" not under the AML umbrella which of course pays A LOT more, they do this to under pay there associates. Any other financial institution you would go to would pay (at least) 10-15k more!!!!! The managers love to play the "favorite game" and promote those they favor the most, or if your a good "brown noser" and don't work hard you'll defiantly be sure to get promoted.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Used to be a great place to work and maybe it will be again.  Nice pens in the branch.  The people in the branch want to care about clients.
cons: Upper management care very little about current clients.  Miss management from the very top down.  If Chuck only knew nothing is “from the client’s eyes” anymore he would be very upset.  UOP is a joke!  The structure for FCs is broken.  They don’t want you to care about current advised clients (clients paying a fee for management) and want you to focus on the next conversion into advice.  The compensation is a joke.  Constantly pulling dollars from you via a claw back on assets leaving whether you brought them in or not.  The client has had assets here for 20 years and if they are assigned to you and the client spends down their retirement dollars to live well then you have to pay the firm back and won’t get paid on any new assets you bring in until you do.  Advised dollars are the same way for up to 2 yrs in the solution.  Upper management mismanaged every thing when it comes to finances.  They probably can’t balance their own checkbook but are in control of a trillion dollar company.  So much micro-managing of our time we don’t have any time left for current clients.  Only time we have is to try and bring in new assets and check boxes for their spreadsheets.  Not enough time nor incentive for us to care about existing clients.  Our comp drives us not to care.  I have ZERO confidence in management.  The stock price is up and that’s all that’s important.  CPS (Client Promoter Score/satisfaction) will plummet in time.  Don’t think they care just as long as they promote something different through advertising then how things actually are, get them in and move on to the next client.  Drive that AUM men and women.  Don’t spend too much time on them (clients).  Only way you should work in the branch is if you are desperate.  Upper management made disastrous financial decisions and take it out on the only client facing employees they have.  Not smart.  I say all of this and we still had record earnings but that’s not the whole story.  Management made major errors with the rollout of SIP and SIA but blame the FCs not themselves.  Such a shame, used to be a great place.  Cash sweep?  If you are client ask your FC about that.  Taking money from clients because of management inadequacies. Great job out here in San Fran.  Stock price, stock price, stock price.  Sharpening up Resume as you read this.

cons: Expanding outside of SF home and reducing the SF / Bay Area footprint.   Career opportunities outside of SF, especially Denver, Austin and Dallas are good.  There are a few small pockets of hard to work with individuals.   Equity is limited to the top 5% of performers which is a discouragement to others.

In many cases, offshore resources have more domain knowledge than the full time employee. Do more with less mentality becoming more prevalent. Note: This depends on the organization you are in. Like many large companies, the experience can vary across different departments.

headline: Fund Accounting Manager

cons: Poor organization in management, had 3 different bosses in less than three years.

headline: Risk Analyst
pros: Great benefits with a great 401k!
cons:
Horrible leadership, they don't know how to run a department, doesn't help when there is a new director who was formally a manager that takes over and doesn't know a clue what there doing. They let the manager say and do whatever they want to there associates. So many people have gone to HR and nothing happens, they just tell the managers  to fix it. Also horrible communication skills all through out the department.

HUGE turnover rate!

headline: Charles Schwab is a good company
pros: You have a good work life balance
cons: They aren't the most competitive for pay

headline: Good Company
pros: Great atmosphere and ability to communicate with execs
cons: Cubicles, can be boring, not up to date

headline: Manager
pros: Relaxed culture and great work-life balance
cons: Limited opportunity for movement outside of sales

headline: Senior manager
pros: Good benefits. Good people in Colorado offices. Not pretentious for the financial industry. For the most part you are working among hard workers. Good company culture.
cons: Low salaries. Hard work. Fight to climb the ladder. I got my mba while employed at schwab and they made me take vacation hours for my classes every other Friday. Work/like balance is limited.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Amazing people, great work culture
cons: They are downsizing in SF

headline: Review
pros: Great culture, work-life balance.
cons: Lower pay in comparison to other financial organizations.

headline: Registered Representative
pros: Great Culture, Opportunity for positive attrition, Personal and Professional Development
cons: Inbound Call Center, Mostly Customer Service Calls- only a portion being Broker calls depending on which team you are on.

headline: Great place to work.
author_position: Senior Team Manager | BSA/AML High-Risk Accounts
pros: Truly puts the client first in every aspect of the business. Great employee culture and work/life balance. Always seeking ways to better the client experience.
cons: Pay could be higher across the board especially when transferring within the firm. does not embrace the work from home trend.

headline: Bullying and passive aggressiveness  is fairly accepted here.
pros: The name on your resume.
cons: I have personally been bullied 3 times in my two years at Schwab,  a first time in my long career. One of the VPs is actually widely known and considered "oh that just her".  I have seen vindictive management at a number of levels. When I first started my employment I did recommend Schwab, I no longer woo individuals to come to Schwab. A standard joke is "we don't finger point, just make sure its someone else's fault". Project Management Group is a revolving door.  Sadly I had hoped to finish my career here

headline: Great company with a sound mission
pros: Suite of managed services and other resources. I was fortunate to work with great coworkers and had a good book of clients
cons: No assistant, a lot of service stuff to handle. There are service teams for support but they have no skin in the game to do well by your client. Clients have high expectations of service. Also normal corporate bureaucracy and some managers are micro-managey

headline: Not a bad place to work at all
pros:
- Good work-life balance
- Good opportunity to excel and be recognized for it. If you work hard, they will notice.
- Compensation is very competitive, and bonuses are usually given fairly to those who earn them
- Plenty of opportunity for advancement, if that's what you want, and lots of mentors.
- Most in upper management really care, and want to help, and listen to and appreciate your concerns.
- Most of my co-workers were great people, fun to work with, and very smart. Schwab is very good at hiring good people and keeping them.
cons:
- Managers tend to have one foot out the door as soon as they join  your team. I had a total of 6. However, 4 of them were great! 1 was OK, and 1 was bad. So, overall a positive experience, but there is that chance you'll get a Demon from Hades.
- They claim to want to do agile, but they don't come close. They expect individual teams to do agile development in an environment where all the projects are waterfall. The money is given out once a year and comes with waterfall expectations. "Here's the money. We need a humongous list of features one year from now. Now go be agile!"
- Most managers are great, but some managers are not great, and actively try to destroy your career.  When you see that happening, don't walk away, run away fast.
- Red tape is incredibly dense. I've never done less actual work and more bureaucracy  at any company I've worked for.

headline: Excellent learning, education, training, benefits and team environment
pros: Working directly with clientele and FA to provide financial, banking, and brokerage services empowering financial freedom for future security, growth and retirement freedom.
cons: Management was awesome except for a few micro managers which you will find all walks of life. This creates a top heavy payroll which could be changed by having management keep responsibilities that the team that they manage perform everyday.

headline: Sr. Administator
pros: That you get paid and hourly and maybe an annual bonus.
cons: Plenty. First of all this operations center is what happened when the company tried to save money from the Phoenix Center. They basically created other job titles that paid way below what other people with the same position but different job title did in Phoenix. They don't want to admit that they are a call center but they are. Even their phone system says it. Management doesn't know how to mange employees metrics because they have never worked in a call center environment. Also the only way to move up in this company is to wear a mini skirt and flirt your way to the top. You dont see that many males in the associate section as compared to females but there are plenty of males in management. Horrible CALL CENTER Place to work at. Pay is roughly at $11-$12 per hour although at 12 your at the high end. Also HR policies are a joke. Not very clear on what the policies are and are up for interpretation from upper management who is constantly changing in regards to what a certain policy means. Basically if they like you and you kiss up they wont fire you. But if you do your job and start to question management then they will fire you.

headline: Great place to work  - always reinventing the industry.
pros: Great people and corporate values.
cons: Most IT jobs are moving out of California.

headline: IDT
pros: Great company, culture and training.
cons: I can't think of anything

headline: Good Company
pros: Fast growth in Lone Tree creates opportunity to learn and move up. Good way of getting Series 7 and learning about the industry, especially since Schwab covers all aspects of trading.
cons: Pay seems to be on the lower end compared to other firms in Denver.

headline: Treated Equally
pros: I had an internship over the summer and had a great time. My coworkers treated me as an equal and the company culture really pushed for some great camaraderie between us all.
cons: As Charles Schwab is such a large company there were many bureaucratic aspects of the internship I felt were somewhat fruitless, but being my first internship I assume this takes place in many similarly large companies.

headline: Excellent Growing Company
pros: A great culture of consensus and politeness and positive problem solving
cons: Going through growing pains and a bit chaotic

headline: Awesome
pros: Culture, leadership, work life balance
cons: Compensation, other than that nothing

headline: A gilded cage is still a cage
pros:
The attitude here really feeds off the new-college-grad energy: bright-eyed, excited, and naïve. Most of the center tries to sell the "you can do anything you put your mind to" attitude. The majority of the people here are kind, motivated, and very young (average age is 23 in the call center).

Schwab tries to mitigate the crushing realization that this is a dead-end job by providing the potential for compensation growth. This comes in the form of overtime incentives, 2% raises for meeting certain criteria each quarter, and pay grade increases when certain hurdles are met over a 3 or 6 month period. 

The catch? Schwab will start you off at a salary that is in the lower 25th percentile of salaries for call-center brokers in the Austin area - maybe to leave room for growth? 

But the criteria for pay growth change constantly - often mid-quarter when there's no time left to course-correct if necessary. Coincidentally, these changes happen to leave many employees just short of meeting the requirements for their raises, meaning that they must start over with the next 3- or 6-month performance measuring term.
cons:
It's important to note that the average tenure here is 10 months; about how long it takes for the new hires to realize that this is not a career. This is a call center job with very little room for upward growth. 

The majority of hiring decisions to help someone get out of the call center are made before a job listing is posted. 90% of the time, if a job is posted internally it's because they've already found the person they'd like to fill it; posting the job listing and interviewing candidates is a technicality they must endure to finally hire the person they actually wanted prior to the whole charade. 

If by some miracle you're able to get promoted, Schwab reserves the right to DENY your promotion if they're unable to meet service levels (and are too cheap to hire someone else). So, you could get the promotion and be working your new job, then get pulled right back to the old one if the phones get too busy. Talk about whiplash. 

Management is not concerned with producing real change. In my short tenure, I have witnessed several attempts by go-getters and innovators to approach senior management with improvements for efficiency, employee engagement, attrition reduction, training efficacy, gender equality etc. Each time someone approaches management with a proposal for real change, they are assigned to a committee that literally plans ice cream socials. I wish I was kidding. 

Speaking of gender dynamics, prepare for an environment with an extreme split; there are about 1 or 2 women per 12-person team. These women (and anyone interested in participating with an employee resource group) are required to use vacation time to meet with groups that promote equality and diversity.

headline: Ok if you like formality
pros: I was happy there for a while
cons: Too stiff and impersonal but I survived

headline: Awesome company
pros:
Friendly people
Great culture
Engaged workforce
Good work/life balance
Competitive salary and benefits
Challenging work
Opportunity for advancement
Nice facilities
Effective strategic direction
cons:
Schwab has some of the usual politics that come with any large corporation.
For hourly employees, it would be nice to be able to flex your schedule.

headline: Excellent financial services company!
pros: I really believe Schwab strives to do the right thing for it's customers and employees.
cons: A bit slow to move on market trends

headline: Company focuses on people and innovation
pros:
People focused
Strong salary
All employees in a bonus plan
A 1 month sabbatical every 5 years
Smart leadership
Workplace is open and clean
cons:
Some red tape, if you don't know right level of people hard to grow
Some client facing positions are low pay for the work
Work flexibility is a bit limited not a lot of remote ability

headline: Software Applications Engineer
pros: Great place to work at
cons: No many cons seen here

headline: Sr Manager
pros: Amazing place to work and grow
cons: I cannot thing of any

headline: AFSP
pros: Great culture and workplace environment
cons: Payscale is lower than average than the industry

headline: Little ability to advance or think outside of the box - lack of ethics
pros: Great benefits, time off, etc
cons: The other reviews have it pegged. Management is petty and not very competent - except for the top management (CEO, CMO, SVPs, etc). Lower level leadership is put in positions they are not trained for nor qualified for. Staff is not encouraged to provide ideas to improve overall firm functions or cost savings. Status quo / stay in your lane is the name of the game at Schwab. If you kiss up to leadership, you'll go far. If you have independent thought, you'll be pushed out. Departments don't work together, but chose to backstab and build redundant department functions causing so much overlap that actual work is difficult to accomplish.

headline: Cashier
pros: Pay was good, always on time.
cons: Company culture could have been better.

headline: Associate, Financial consultant
pros: Well positioned to expand the business
cons: Needs to hire more support in branch office to help with work load.

headline: Schwab Review
pros: Show management that you are dedicated and focused, they will help you to move ahead.  Key is yourself.  True to all good places.  Work hard, build your own brand, great networking and training opportunities.  Overall great company culture.  I've had great managers.  Colleagues who perform well are all promoted fairly quickly.  Again, key is yourself.  Fair game.  Company provides great training and licensing preps.  Company is growing fast.  Lots of overtime opportunities.
cons: Only 30-min lunch break.  Too short.  Not top-notch pay.

headline: Customer Service and Support
pros: Good company to work for, good culture. You will be required to successfully obtain your Series 7 license to have any chance for real advancement, but there are a lot of opportunities if you do.
cons: If you are unable to obtain a Series 7 license, they will part ways with you after three failed attempts. Also, Schwab generally pays less for Brokers, etc

headline: Disappointed
pros: Benefits are great...insurance, vacation, sick time, etc.
cons: A very inefficient, passive aggressive culture.  Rather than focus on collaboration and end results, it's more about covering yourself and appearing busy.  Department managers are hit or miss, some are amazing, some should not be managing people.  The brokerage side may be different, but the Bank is definitely treated like the red-headed step-child.  High turnover within certain departments, but no one looks at why that's happening.  Just sweep it under the rug.

headline: Contractor Conveyor Belt
pros: The pay is good. Do the work, go home. Excellent work/life balance.
cons:
No Passion:
Job duties siloed and only apply to their internal corporate software tools-- no learned skills to further career growth. Everyone fearful of being laid off with impending software changes. With so many employees, there's very little to actually be done-- and since the field is corporate finance with emphasis on legal, innovation is met with opposition. Terrible campus at the Domain under LOUD construction at all times with parking constantly obstructed. 

No Culture:
Employees don't even eat lunch together, let alone speak to each other. Full-time employees are treated well and can work from home whenever they want. Managers and directors  do very little actual work. (There's an easy-going mask upfront with lots of politics behind closed doors.) Both salary and contract employees must log all their time on projects, and project error rates are tracked, which are under constant scrutiny.

No Loyalty:
Contractors are treated as less-than salaried employees, no matter how hard they work-- and they mostly like to hire contractors from overseas and give work Visas until they ship them back. Good luck getting hired full-time, because they prefer to rotate 12-month contracts instead of full-time hiring due to the “economic risk”.  Departments rigorously interview alternatives for months before potentially hiring contractors to become full-timers.

headline: Broker
pros: Good training and benefits. Lots of training
cons: High turnover and burnout

headline: Schwab is amazing!
pros:
Benefits, support system, positive messages from leadership, commitment to excellence and the client experience. It is exciting to be part of a company on the cutting edge of the industry that holds the industry as a whole to a higher standard of providing value and excellent service to our clients.

Schwab listens to its employees as well. Sometimes new policy/strategy implementation takes time, but I have witnessed quick turnaround on matters we've made clear are important to us, such as cost of living salary adjustments for the same role in different markets. Schwab knows that there is room for improvement and voicing concerns in a tactful way has shown to be effective. If something can't change, they always explain why. They seek constant feedback from us and certainly give it to us as well. As someone who has no problem with voicing any concerns I have, I can confidently say that I have never felt ignored or disregarded.

Schwab is generous with its employees, allowing for more than enough attempts at passing licensing exams. I've found that superiors have been willing to work with their employees on improvement opportunities—one would have to consistently flout authority and their directives in order to have corrective action taken against them. 

Schwab places a strong priority in promoting from within, which further shows how they are committed to employees' ongoing personal and professional development.
cons:
Not a true con, but be aware that things are constantly changing (mostly for the better) so it behooves you to not get too settled in to a set way of doing things. If you thrive on change for the better, you will thrive here.

Before I came to the branch/when I was in a call center, it could be difficult to schedule vacation days off if too many people in the network requested off for that same day, which is something that happens often around major holidays. 

Additionally, they have a policy of firing individuals who can't pass their broker exams. They have been tending toward hiring lower-quality workers via temp agencies who aren't adequately trained to represent Schwab well. People with college degrees get turned away during the hiring process, but individuals with only high school diplomas can easily enter the company on a temp-to-hire path.

headline: Charles Schwab Corporate
pros: Great company to work for. Everyone has been there for the minimum 10 years. The industry and company are always stable, solid team players, and most employees are friendly and helpful. The company is eager to try and stay ahead of the times which makes them more willing to try new ideas from time to time. The financial industry is very slow to change in general, so this company does a pretty good job being as opened minded as possible. Great work life balance. Most people come in around 9:30am and leave around 4:30pm.
cons:
Because everyone works there for so many years there is very little availability to get promoted. The hierarchy of level seats is also very few- most people sit as Senior Manager for many years unless a Director or VP leave the company. 
Full coverage of benefits, but with large co-pays. Slightly lower paying salaries compared to other financial industry companies.

headline: Good company, bad HR
pros: Nice benefits, decent pay.
cons: Bean counters in HR run the company.  They outsourced whole departments out of state as they  saw it could save money. But they ended up with much less qualified and experienced people.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Sabbatical is great, interesting projects. Overall a good place to work.
cons: Some politics like any large company.

headline: People Make the Place
pros: The culture inspires employees to be personable. The employees set the tone of your day.
cons: Very metrics driven. If you thrive in a call center environment, then this is the place for you

headline: It's all about the people
pros: Company culture is laid back, Easy upward mobility, Tuition reimbursement
cons: The systems are old. The advice is outdated and the person I worked for asked me to do outrageous tasks daily.

headline: Insurance
pros: Good company culture, cares about their employees
cons: far away from where i live

headline: CEO is spot on, CIO is not
pros: Good comp, benefits, and business vision. They put their clients first, every time. CIO leader is inspiring. They look to treat their people well.
cons: Technology leadership is from VISA and it is a command and control culture. The culture that the CEO speaks of does not transcend the technology space. Schwab is a lost leader in technology. The technology group has a tendency to reward the wrong behavior. It has been come a popularity contest without a serious lack of vision.

headline: Participant services
pros: Great place with great people and atmosphere
cons: Difficult to get vacation approved

headline: Good company with strong culture and client focus
pros: Strong belief in doing what is right for clients and providing exceptional service. People are friendly and easy going. Management is accessible and down to earth. Certain high growth locations like Denver and new Texas offices are seeing lots of job availability. Easy place to work with good work like balance.
cons: Morale in SF has been low due to recent strategy to move jobs out of SF. Lost a lot of experienced and talented employees.  Project funding is challenging unless strategic and high profile initiatives. Working with employees across so many geographic locations means mostly conference calls so you lose the personal in face interaction.  Can be too consensus driven at times. Promotions beyond Director to VP are difficult. Not a lot of career growth.

headline: Desperado
pros: Charles Schwab seems to be dedicated to career development. Networking is easy here.
cons: Pay seems to be sub-par company wide, keeping morale low. Entry level positions are hard to fill, allowing for less than qualified individuals to fill those rolls, increasing workload for the competent workers who then become discontent with pay and they leave.

headline: Ehh it's ok
pros: Nice campus, as a whole the company offers good benefits
cons: Micromanage people to death, always hire from outside the company for higher level positions.  Systems are REALLY outdated

headline: Awesome
pros:
-treated fairly
-upper management is great
cons: -the model is always changing (common for this industry) and sometimes hard to keep up.

headline: The two sides of Charles Schwab
pros: Benefits, general cooperation between groups, nice desks,
cons: The thought police, crappy chairs, coffee, intra-mural cooperation and rivalry among groups.

headline: Associate
pros: Overall a great company and culture
cons:
Terrible management especially when they don't like you
Lots of politics - keep you back

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Integrity of the company and is values.
cons: Must be able to adapt quickly to change.

headline: Senior Staff software developer
pros: It is the best company to work which provide adequate training and management support to accomplish given tasks while providing personal life balance.
cons: Most of the jobs are moving out of bay area to other states.

headline: Great Culture
pros: a lot of opportunities to change positions to find a good fit.
cons: difficult for 40+ year olds to get promoted

headline: Senior Operations Specialist
pros: Great place to learn new things
cons: Not a lot of opportunity

headline: Great Company, Great Culture.
pros: Great people allow for a great culture. Even after leaving Schwab I send people in finance their way.
cons: Salary Bans for internal promotions aren't the best. They promote from within but almost push you to leave and comeback in order to get market rate salaries.

headline: Good Company
pros: Employees feel valued, emphasis on cooperation and mutual support. Good compensation and 30 day sabbatical after 5 years is a good perk.
cons: Slow advancement. Heavily regulated industry, which is not Schwab's fault but just an industry issue in general. Hard to think of any other cons.

headline: Client Service Manager
pros: generally a positive, and inclusive place to work.
cons: little or no chance to advance within the organization, and ultimately the same general brand of corporate schlock that you'll experience in all financial institutions.

headline: Account Solutions
pros: Company looks great on your resume
cons: They hired lots of undeducated trashy folks with low salaries to save on labor costs

headline: Master Manipulators
pros: -Loved the team members, if only management would do the same.
cons:
WARNING-You will be taken advantage of, and worked to death. 

The company is using its employees to run a bare bones operation. They refuse to hire more people and expect the employees to work themselves to death. Don't be persuaded by the talk of "great exposure to upper management" as these were nothing but empty promises to keep the work horses going as long as possible. 

The bank burns through employees with no regard for them as human beings, and cares only about the bottom line on labor figures. This creates an unnecessarily stressful environment, and horrible client experience. 

The gains from this skeleton crew approach to staffing will never be passed on to the employees, and long term could be the source of some serious regulatory issues with the Bank.

headline: Best places to work
pros: Own your tomorrow at Charles Schwab
cons: The financial services industry is highly regulated but that's a good thing for investors

headline: Good Entry Level Job
pros: Company will pay for you to study for your 7 and 63.
cons: Limited growth opportunities in Orlando

headline: Director
pros: Well organized and managed company. Well documented goals, objectives, and career development path with your manager.
cons: Work can  be demanding at times and management can at times expect you to solve your problem and resource what you need without their help.

headline: Conservative, bureaucratic
pros: People are incredibly friendly. I started my career here and I think its a good place to get off the ground. They like to promote internally.
cons: Compensation seems on the lower side compared to peers. Claim to be open to ideas but they are not.

headline: Tax manager
pros: Very positive and conservative place
cons: Not very flexible on working schedules

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Ethical and honest company that is true to their end client.
cons: As with all large corporations, Schwab is also sometimes overly bureaucratic.

headline: Senior Associate Portfolio Consultant
pros: Great colleagues.  The company strives to keep the clients best interest in mind.
cons: Benefits and compensation could be better.   Watched a lot of good leaders come and go.  Culture shifted and not the same I started with.

headline: Client Banking Services
pros: Good team work, resources, support groups. Schwab is a great company that excels in providing great service at a low cost to clients. Great moral between employees and different groups. More than other Financial Service Companies. Benefits are good, sabbatical and flex time provides good balance between work and family. Schwab gives plenty of opportunities to those who want to grow in the company and make career. Non discriminating environment.
cons: Some times in some groups potential growth depends also on your manager. A lot of the positions start as other call center positions, long hours and short breaks, however, there is plenty of support and it gets better as you get more experience. Competition between peers is high. It can make you feel that you are not performing well enough sometimes.

headline: Broker
pros: You are given a fully paid month to sit in a room and study for the Series 7/63. Might look good on a resume because it's a Fortune 500 company but you'll have to fake until you make it from there.
cons: I don't even know where to start. Honestly, if you're college educated and interested in finance then STAY AWAY. They sell the idea that you're "starting a career in finance" which is complete BS. More of a customer service call center type role. If you are looking to work as an analyst or any type of finance related role (outside of wealth management) then you're wasting your time with Schwab. If you're interested in wealth management you're probably better off starting at a wire house and then getting a job in a schwab branch as an FC (I only say this because you can make six figures working 40hr/week dealing with cheap clients). The Broker Trainee program is the pond scum role of schwab and not respected anywhere else in the company. No room for growth. They preach that you can move to another department after 18 months but no one is going to help you do that. Several colleagues of mine were interested in working towards their CFP and management tried to talk them out of it. They want you to stay in the  call center because they need people on the phones. The only people that like it there and/or stay have no other choice (i.e.kids to feed, mortgage, wife, etc.) or they have nothing else going for them (i.e. no college degree). They reward loyalty and tenure. The director I was under was there for about 17 years and had absolutely no leadership or social skills. He would micromanage through an employees direct supervisor. If you'd like to build your resume and get licensed then take the job and move on ASAP after passing. Have an exit strategy from day one or you're gonna get stuck  walking old people through the website and getting yelled at when clients are unhappy with their accounts. I just wish I came across this review when I interviewed. If you decide to pass on the opportunity then good luck with the job search!!

headline: Broker
pros: Great mobility within the organization
cons: Lack of leadership and training

headline: Great Experience
pros: Fantastic hours, people, and work environment
cons: Can't think of any cons

headline: Analyst
pros: Job was easy enough to do.
cons: Job was not challenging at all. Very little room for upward mobility. Management was unable to develop talent.

cons: Sometimes too set in past processes.

headline: Operations Associate

headline: A decent place for a traditional company
