Work Life Balance
Soft culture within most teams - could be subjective
Locations around the US are is pretty family live-able places
cons:
Compliance with Financial Regulations could be burdensome - Not issue if not trading in the stock markets
Software job could be boring based on what your interests are
Less visibility of career progression
Average Pay

headline: Relationship Specialist
pros: Financially sound and stable company. Multiple offices across the country that gives flexibility to relocate. Quarterly bonus advances. Company reimbursement of gym fees as well as company contributions to employee HSA. 401k match.
cons: Don't be fooled by the good ratings.  Expensive healthcare plan. "Good ole' boy" culture, its all about who you know when it comes to advancement. Excessive company spending in certain business units. The company primarily concerned about shareholders. Company DOES NOT value tenure, everyone is expendable. Consistently driving out tenured employees for fresh out of college inexperienced young adults. Inadequate training for new hires. VERY busy phones. STRICT call center production parameters. Limited vacation availability. Reps are grossly underpaid compared to competitors.

headline: Registered Representative
pros: Everything, benefits, pay, support, upper management
cons: Possible odd hours and shifts

headline: Great people and benefits
pros: Great benefits and great culture. The focus is on the clients and everyone works together to achieve common goals.
cons: Not as much PTO as other companies I have worked for - you need to accrue it here. However, a sabbatical of 1 month after 5 years, great pay, and great people make up for it.

Ethical and conservative company
Community Involvement
Training and Development
cons:
Pay

headline: Applications Engineer

cons: Every company has its ups and downs.

headline: Not who/what they hold themselves out to be
pros: Good benefits, people generally nice, corporate environment
cons: Understaffed in most departments. Management cares more about shareholders than employees but pretends to care by things like engagement surveys, an occasional gratis lunch, and "focus" on internal growth and development. Discretionary comp (bonus, etc) are impacted by this - even when employees have worked very hard to earn the compensation. The company holds itself out to be innovative and looking for fresh ideas/employees, but employees must fit into a mold to be successful here. Contrarian opinions/thoughts are not welcome. Middle management is given carte blanche and should have more oversight and training.

headline: Great company
pros: Great environment, strong management, excellent training.
cons: None that i can think of,

headline: Client Services Specialist
pros: Good benefits & paid time off.
cons: Too much focus on stats versus customer service.

headline: Bad Experience
pros: Benefits are excellent and pay was above average.
cons: They talk about the culture constantly and tell you how great it is but my experience was not the culture they were selling.  My manager was a bully and her manager just avoided me.  HR told me I had no options except to do whatever she said.

headline: Diversity Gone Wild
pros: Great industry and they help you with your licenses and hard to get fired.
cons: It is not the time to be a male at Schwab. Every opportunity the company gets to push females into promotions they do. Look at the leadership of the firm. Nothing wrong with strong female leaders. There is something wrong with promoting women over men because you want to appear more diverse.

headline: Great culture! Great opportunity for meaningful service
pros: The company has a great culture, filled with great people. You'll always be learning in this job, but Schwab provides lots of resources.
cons: There are some times, depending on the time of year that the job can be quite demanding. This job will be great at teaching/improving multi-tasking and achieving new skills.

headline: Love it!
pros: Great work life balance and a lot of focus is placed on employee engagement.
cons: Need to work on having more structured development plans.

headline: Innovation is at the heart of Charles Schwab
pros: Being part of an evolution in Fixed Income trading is a fascinating challenge. We strive to provide the best client experience employing our knowledge and skills along with technology.
cons: An everyday challenge is to maintain an evolving momentum in every task that arises every waking moment as well as to staying on top of the latest financial developments is an everyday task.

headline: Opportunity to work with great people
pros: Schwab has always had a very progressive and inclusive culture. I've been fortunate to work with excellent team members and collaborative business partners. The workload is heavy, but there is a focus on work/life balance. Strong support for acquiring new job skills and attending training.
cons: Increased responsibility with little opportunity for promotion unless you look outside your current group.

headline: Project Manager
pros: Nice co-workers. Allow telecommuting.
cons:
IT department needs to invest and keep up with new technology. 
Lots of red tapes so takes a long time to get things approved.

headline: Senior Clearcase Administrator
pros: It was a Great place to work
cons: Not so great to work at in the Bay Area anymore - they have been laying people off and putting their jobs on the market for half the salary in Austin TX.

headline: Very happy and fulfilled
pros: great work life balance, lots of support for mobility around the company and in different geographies
cons: takes awhile to get things done in a large company. Can be passive -aggressive

headline: Talent Advisor
pros: Great people, great culture, good location
cons: Lack of room for advancement, technology was not great

headline: Client Service Associate
pros: Great mentors and culture. Gain good experience in the financial world. Recommended to start as a broker, not as a customer service rep in bank.
cons: The pay is terrible. Needs more focus on the employees, and not the numbers

headline: Great company
pros: Great customer service and overall offering for all investment needs.
cons: The company has become less employee friendly over the years and more corporate in the negative sense.

headline: great perks
pros: benefits are great, pay is great, employees are all great
cons: not a lot of things to mention if anything

headline: FCA Academy
pros: They really take care of the employees and there is tons of opportunity to grow. The program really teaches you and gets you moving towards the FC roll.
cons: The expectations that they set don't always pan out. They might give time horizons for how long certain things are going to last but they end up being longer than expected.

headline: Managing Director
pros: Client experience and employee focused
cons: Many colleagues and staff can be in remote locations

headline: Call Center
pros: There are good people that work with you.
cons: They have many confusing and outdated systems. It is just a call center and the only advancement opportunities are to other call center positions. You are bound to get stuck in a weird shift. They put out a false narrative that we care about peoples financial futures when really all they want you to do is get "leads" so you are just trying to get customers into more Schwab products. It is just a churn and burn operation.

headline: feedback
pros: Environment , culture, safety,brand name,secure
cons: salary, management, timing,work load, stress

headline: Horrible experience
pros: Had zero positive experiences here;  very unhappy and stressful place to work.
cons: The worst 6 months of my life.  Almost daily team meetings where there is little valuable information shared, just a chance for managers and supervisors to remind team members that they are managers and supervisors.  Supervisors, Managers and VPs heavily involved in office politics.  There is no privacy, cubicles are constructed so you are either facing someone directly all day or several people are in your peripheral vision.  Complained about sexual harassment and management (including VP) swept under rug until finally had to notify HR directly.  Poisonous atmosphere;  avoid at all costs there are more ethical companies to get your licenses at.  I have subsequently worked with former Schwab employees who also literally said they hated their time at Schwab (in Phoenix anyway).

headline: Best Company I Ever Worked For
pros: The people and the atmosphere. You are seen as and given room to be the whole person that you are rather than just another employee bot.
cons: I can not think of any

headline: Customer Relationship
pros: Great company culture, values, and people.
cons: Could be stressful at times, but more of a function of the business than the company

headline: Amazing Culture. Will miss Schwab.
pros: Happy Employees. Good mission. Good work/life balance (depending on manager and role). Beautiful lone tree campus.
cons: I would have stayed there 'forever' if there were more growth opportunities. If you're ok doing what you're currently doing for a really long time, it's a great company. If you're itchy for continued growth... You better be really patient.

headline: Schwab
pros: Sabbatical every 5 years, vacation time piles up after being here a few years, nice campus, paid holidays, volunteer time off, great people to work with.
cons: Middle management I feel has become bloated. It's a product of not being able to move up very easily unless you're going to a management position. Difficult to move to a new department, they seem to like to hire externally. Career development is poor.

headline: Senior Software Applications Engineer
pros: Company includes very good benefits
cons: Distributed teams and offshore QA model can create a challenging development environment

headline: Talent Advisor
pros: Resources, Training. Facilities are nice
cons: Perfection is the standard. Plays favorites.

headline: Associate financial service representative
pros: Best managers and great work ethics
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Sr. Marketing Manager
pros: The pay and benefits are very competitive for the market place.
cons: The company used to have a philosophy of "work/life balance" and that was part of the culture.  Now, it is all about work/work and the culture is no longer that as what was established by Chuck Schwab himself.  Unfortunate, as it used to be an amazing place to work.  Community involvement and personal values are preached to the masses often, however, it seems to be more of a box to check vs a true value.

headline: Demanding & Stressful
pros: Good benefits.  Team members are nice and helpful.   Good culture of collaboration.
cons: Working at Schwab is extremely demanding.  The work life balance that is advertised is inaccurate.  I wouldn't recommend this company to someone looking for a long-term opportunity.   Management doesn't care as the business needs of the company come first.

headline: Love Schwab
pros: Great culture, great company. I'd go back any day.
cons: Certain VP level people in Denver have been allowed to create intimidating work environments.

headline: An okay experience....
pros:
- Location
- Brand name
- The mission/vision
cons:
- bureaucracy
- politics
- limited career growth

headline: Relationship Specialist
pros: Always work to do. Growth in the industry.
cons: High turnover. Many employees don't strive to be a good employee, just there to clock in and out. Seems to be more sales driven in the recent months. Promotions are only given and available to those that are licensed which aren't necessarily the hardest working individuals. If the rep does a good job, sales benefits and upper management benefits, not the employee working hard.

headline: Schwab is a great company but recent culture shift is challenging.
pros: Transparency, autonomy, culture, values, benefits, including adequate 401k match, DAF match, tuition reimbursement and sabbaticals (even though I've never used mine).
cons: Limited mobility, goals increase 20-30% per year, and management has shifted its focus over the last several years from a employee focused firm to a sales focused firm. People are more expendable than in the past. Your manger may have a large impact on your job satisfaction.

headline: Wonderful Experience
pros:
- supportive and transparent management
- good benefits and fair pay with great bonus opportunities
- amazing company culture
- many development and training opportunities
cons:
- difficulty moving between departments
- very little flexibility with scheduling due to call center requirements
- some technology issues, which can get frustrating

headline: Great Culture
pros: Culture, Recognition, Team Atmosphere, and Advancement Opportunities
cons: The main con is Pay

headline: Broker Trainee
pros: Helping out clients the firm has been well positioned to put the client first.
cons: Management isn't always there to help you, most opportunities are very competitive but not always do they choose the best talent.

headline: 4.5 month review
pros: Quality training, caring management, servant leadership approach to financial services.
cons: Low salary compared to similar companies.

headline: FC Academy
pros: location of training, insurance, benefits
cons: salary, relocation required, relocation to unsatisfactory places

headline: Good company for the public, less so for the employees
pros:
-good leadership
-ethical
-reasonable ability to move up quickly if you demonstrate proficiency and are able to be geographically mobile
cons: They will make promises to service employees they cannot keep. It is not that managers lie, but higher up priorities change the landscape. For example a hiring freeze was instituted last year on service reps and mid-level managers were unwilling to make exceptions. This and repeatedly delaying compensation increases leads to deteriorating morale amongst service employees.

headline: Participant Services
pros: Friendly  and goal-oriented workplace environment. The opportunity to learn and progress through a challenging role.
cons: Much of the role relies on metrics to determine where you stand.

headline: Used to be great
pros: Company is client friendly. Programs such as the Accountability Guarantee are innovative and focused on clients.
cons: Excessive micromanagement. Culture is evaporating quickly as more tenured employees are encouraged to leave (forced out). Sales goals encourage manipulation and unethical behavior. There are "top" Financial Consultants who excel because they know how to work the system.

headline: Estate service professional
pros: You can actually meet some nice friendly people and who are ready to help you with questions especially when you are new. The company's focus is so much on the client. Compared to my experience with other banks sometimes I feel like I would prefer to be on the other side of the phone being attended to.
cons: It's all about being on the phone. The phones ring non stop. You end up speaking to at least 70 people a day. Don't let the big title fool you. It's a pure call center job irrespective of the department you are in or the title you are given. If you are offered the condition of employment option and you are not the studying kind, don't do it. You are required to get at least a series 7 licence working here. So take the regular job offer and not the condition of employment so you are not under immense pressure to pass the exam within six months of your hire or else you will be fired asap. Bottom line if you are ready to be on the phone all day then this is the job for you.

headline: Sr. Administrator- El Paso
pros:
Great culture
Paid sabbatical
Paid training/ career growth opportunities
Opportunities to move/ relocate
cons:
Pay (in El Paso)
Stressful work due to poor set up of work expectations

headline: Great company; would be better if they put supply to demand
pros: Overall maintains a friendly atmosphere; competitive pay; open-door management policy
cons: Maximizing workforce productivity at any cost - the company has set ambitious growth targets but is attempting to keep the support staff (not including front-line brokers) growth to an absolute minimum to please shareholders. This includes a marked reduction in opportunities for advancement and lateral hiring between departments that are chronically understaffed relative to the demand on their resources. Additionally, drastic cuts were made to non-wage compensation, particularly insurance benefits.

headline: Good Company
pros: Very professional company to work
cons: Middle Management has some issues.

headline: High pressure to make sales goals above all else
pros: Can double the salary with sales bonuses
cons: Pressure to meet sales goals

headline: Good company with great people
pros:
-Focused on delivering great client experience 
-Smart, helpful people throughout the company
-Responsive IT support
cons:
-Large, matrixed organization - sometimes difficult to navigate.
-Current senior management frowns on working remotely (this policy has been more flexible in the past)
- Frequent reorgs distracting and disrupt employee moral.

headline: Great Company & Culture
pros: Great culture.  They value their employees.  Great Benefits.  The best place for financial consultants/advisors to be able to service their clients needs.
cons: The culture is amazing but it is completely dependent on the manager that you work with as the branch offices tend to be smaller/closer work environments.

headline: Management run amok
pros: Good benefits, good culture, good work life balance.
cons: Worst management staff I have ever seen.  Incredibly high turn over.

headline: It's okay...
pros: A four day work week makes the job manageable.  The company truly values its employees and has great benefits
cons: Too much regulation - all phone calls are recorded, actions are timestamped.  It feels like Big Brother and can be overwhelming at times

headline: Relationship associate
pros: Grata work life balance! Mostly good leaders. Tuition reimbursement, great people to work with. HSA and child care reimbursement is great too!
cons: Hard to get out of call center. Starting salary can be low for the Denver area. 18 month time in job requirement

headline: overall ok
pros: Great company to learn the foundation
cons: Pay needs to be better

headline: pros and cons
pros:
nice working environment
fixed working hours
cons:
always busy
can barely get overtime pay

headline: Great Culture
pros: The culture in the workplace is refreshing and the ability to "Own Your Tomorrow" is completely up to you.
cons: There are some technological gaps that could be addressed but the majority of earnings are invested back into the clients. At some point, the investment will need to flow back into the infrstructure.

headline: Good for a time
pros: Good people and if you live in the suburbs easy commute
cons: Management is losing direction each year more and more

headline: Salary
pros:
Sabbatical after 5 years
Good team environment
cons:
Annual payraise not substanial
Bonuses not guaranteed

headline: Financial Consultant
pros:
One of the most important aspects of life is everything that isn't work. Schwab knows that and the work-life balance is great.  At 3 years service, you get 3 weeks a year of vacation, not to mention sick time, bank/national holidays and 2 floating days to boot. Oh, and Schwab also cares about community - 8 hours of paid time-off for community service.

The pay-scale is pretty nice. Commission structure is fair and balanced, so if you put in the work you'll have no problem maxing out your 401k each year. 

Great office in Lone Tree - the facilities are top-notch with diverse and flavorful selection of meals in the cafe/grill. Amazing mountain views.
cons:
It can be stressful in a sales environment - some people don't have the drive for the position and burn out. There is a weekly/monthly/quarterly leaderboard and you are expected to not be on the bottom. 

Yearly targets increase year after year. 

You're given a book of leads and that's it. Lots of outbound/cold calls. 
 Hands off from mgmt (though many people thrive in that position). There are slow days/weeks/months so having a pipeline of clients in process is critical. This means the first 6 months on the job your making your base salary only (plus service pay).

headline: Portfolio Consultant
pros: The health benefits are good
cons: Very poor work life balance

headline: Nice people
pros: Friendly culture. Good people. Positive environment. Decent benefit package.
cons: Obsession with cost-cutting/downsizing to please shareholders. Don't get too comfortable because the next round of layoffs are right around the corner.  A bit of a "drink the Kool-Aid" mentality. Highly structured/regulated development practices--lots of red tape for even the most minor changes. Not much flexibility--IT management dictates on-size-fits-all edict and everyone must fall in line.

headline: Inbound Service Center
pros: Great company that truly cares about its employees.
cons: You start on the core line and take call after call. It just was not the right job for me.

headline: Financial Services Professional
pros: Great company, good licensing program
cons: too much red tape involved, smallest things get the largest punishments, and no outlined breaks within the schedule for you to peacefully have lunch or use the restroom with out hurting your Bonus at the end of the year according to adherence.

headline: Financial Services Professional
pros: Great company, good licensing program
cons: too much red tape involved, smallest things get the largest punishments, and no outlined breaks within the schedule for you to peacefully have lunch or use the restroom with out hurting your Bonus at the end of the year according to adherence.

headline: Good Company
pros: ESPP, Overtime pay, Flexible schedule. Amazing start in the finance industry
cons: You make it your own, no one will help you progress. They rather pay you the same and keep you low level. Don't be that person still on the same team after 5 years. Network!

headline: Great environment
pros: Good technology, support for advisors, benefits
cons: Still a discount feel but getting better

headline: Company doing great but warning signs....
pros: The company is built on a client focused, ethical, trusting foundation.  This permeates the culture and drives impressive results.  Most people working here are achievers and want to get things done.  High confidence in exec leadership.
cons: Company has been moving many long tenured employees out in SF and replacing in other lower cost locations.  A good business strategy which is also making Schwab less special as a place to work.  A number of control-oriented leaders added in last few years which will put continual pressure on the "team".

headline: Sr Storage and Backup Architect
pros: Good home and work balance
cons: poor telecommuting policy for all

headline: Alternative Investments Intern
pros: Great learning experience in New York, great team, great networking opportunities and for the most part great intern program
cons: Limited entry level opportunities for actual investment management, poor HR and administrative communications

headline: Good place to work, great environment
pros: Friendly environment with a lot of amenities
cons: very structured schedule with no flexibility

headline: Project Manager
pros: Great Company to work for.  They really care about their employees.
cons: May be relocating headquarters to Denver as they have a big campus there

headline: Great company, takes care of clients and employees
pros: Always does the right thing  by the client and employees
cons: lots of financial industry regulations

headline: Sr Managers
pros: Room for advancement, good culture
cons: Below industry average pay, particularly if you move up within the company

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Good work life balance, pays well, real mission that makes a difference
cons: No cons to list at this time.

headline: Registered representative
pros: Great gateway to get started in the industry. Great way to learn the early stages of ins and outs of being a broker.
cons: And it's a core, You're still a call center rep. You'll be getting hammered with 50 - 70 calls per day. Some are very mundane.

headline: Great Brochure!  Sub-standard delivery.
pros: Vacation time for tenured employees.
cons: High turnover. Aging systems. Lack of training beyond the basics. Pride in customer service which is not deserved.  Promotions are based on positivity and not competence.   The overall philosophy is to create a great brochure, deliver substandard service, and blame failures on those who lack flair.  Retribution for speaking up is encouraged.  Poor service extends to employee accounts, which are mostly mandatory.

headline: Enriching Walt
pros: running water, taco tuesdays, stapler
cons: everything else... three more words

headline: Call center in Phoenix
pros: A lot of free food, good technology, long (paid) training period, good name on the resume
cons: call center environment, tedious customer service work, low caliber environment

headline: Senior specialist
pros: Work/life balance. Engagement. Atmosphere. Facilities.
cons: Employee growth/ development. Promoting from within.  Career opportunities.

headline: Director - Financial Crimes Compliance
pros: Ethical company with strong client focus
cons: none to report at this time

headline: Compliance
pros:
-rare to have a micro manager
-workload is nothing close to FinTech
cons:
-pay is low
-gradually leaving SF
-old culture that won't embrace fintech even as corrrespondent banking is dying off

headline: Work Hard and Get Paid
pros: Great people to work alongside, flex time for the schedules. Base salary + monthly commission. Good marketing campaigns drive a ton of business. Most clients are happy to speak to us if we're calling out.
cons: We are a nimble group in the call centers and can take on new tasks or campaigns at any time. Some leads feel like cold calling and take away from people who want to speak to us. After a while call coaching seems juvenile.

headline: Outstanding
pros: Awesome place to work. Highly recommend it, great team structure and room for advancement.
cons: I have no cons for this coming. I would gladly return.

headline: Employees are treated like garbage.
pros: Decent 401k, but that is about the only positive there is.
cons: Employees are pitted against each other. Managers pick favorites and make in it very difficult for the non favorites. Sales goal change constantly and are raised to levels that many consultants can't reasonably achieve.  If you fall out of favor with the your manager, they will look for any minimal reason to put you on warning and eventually fire you. Management has cut compensation on a regular basis and substituted a "deferred bonus plan". The only problem with the plan is you have to stay at least 5 years and be age 60 before the funds are available. If you are laid off or fired the plan goes away. The suspicion is Schwab is targeting employees that are near the date of getting the plan funds. Morale is to low to measure.

headline: Great company, location going through growing pains.
pros: Great company, compensation is fair, hours are good (M-F), vacation, floating holidays, benefits given early on, annual bonuses paid out in advance.
cons: Executive leadership still trying to figure out forecasting, minimal resources provided for management, constant change in management has demoralized staff.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Nice people, good benefits/comp, great on-boarding
cons: Lots of Kool-Aid to drink

headline: Great Entry Level Company with some opportunities
pros: Great benefits, good opportunities, bonus's are very competitive,
cons: , Kind of hard to move around and move up. Plenty of employees with 10+ years experience in a position one or two levels above you

headline: Active Trader
pros: Good culture, and positive enviorment
cons: They are fixated on negative calls of the 100 calls per day, if one customer is upset with you, it can jeopardize your career

headline: Don't quit your job to come here (CVRC)
pros:
Expect the least from this corporation.
"You'll get a lot of time off after 5 years but will need Stockholm Syndrome to get thru it" is the common joke in the halls.
cons:
The workload was so ridiculous, my former department Client Verification and Research Center (CVRC) actually had coworkers working off the clock after their shift was over to complete their queue for the day. That's so illegal. If people didn't finish their queue for the day they wouldn't get a bonus or raise at the end of the year. In January 2017 the CVRC department only granted 60% of the dept a raise - 40% received 0% raise, and those were the ones who refused to work overtime without being paid. Considering Denver's rising cost of living that amounts to a salary decrease. 
Management was a constantly revolving door. So were coworkers. I worked there a year and a half and counted 17 different faces. Still nothing was done about the obvious problems. Managers freely discriminated and were the rudest, most uneducated people you'll meet outside of a Waffle House.
I left a decent job at Scottrade to go to CVRC in Charles Schwab and was promised the moon and back, promised bonuses, promised raises, promised time off. All of it was lies. DO NOT LEAVE YOUR JOB TO COME HERE!!!!

headline: Client Services
pros: Great place to work. They are always trying to improve their process and work with each employee. My time with them was pleasant.
cons: I have nothing to say on that. Managers come and go. Each manager has their own way of managing which can be a little difficult at times. But you get used to it.

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Good atmosphere and message. Great Benefits
cons: Constantly changing managers, tethered to a phone line constantly

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Good benefits, great people and flexible working schedule.
cons: Uncertainty looms with movement out of California.

headline: Good Management, Strong Ethics, Care About Employee Development
pros:
Strong company with amazing ethics. You feel like you are working for a good cause and the mission of the company is truly to help people.
Great benefits including sabbaticals
Lots of opportunities for employee development including management training
cons:
Not a big growth company, so it takes a long time to for promotion opportunities 
Highly regulated business which stifles creativity and keeps the vibe of the company a little old school

headline: Good Management, Strong Ethics, Care About Employee Development
pros:
Strong company with amazing ethics. You feel like you are working for a good cause and the mission of the company is truly to help people.
Great benefits including sabbaticals
Lots of opportunities for employee development including management training
cons:
Not a big growth company, so it takes a long time to for promotion opportunities 
Highly regulated business which stifles creativity and keeps the vibe of the company a little old school

headline: Stock broker
pros:
Great training & benefits plus bonuses
.
cons: Pressure to constantly move up in company.

headline: Senior Manager - Strategy
pros: Amazing company values and mission. Fantastic work/life balance and wonderful culture.
cons: Benefits, pay and lack of career development

headline: Customer Service
pros: The medical benefits are very good
cons: Being a call center limits flexibility

headline: Solid place to work...10 years ago
pros: some good people. some excellent people. some okay people. on the whole, the people side is good.
cons: However, their tech and sales philosophy is from 1997

headline: used to be good
pros: good pay benefits. upper management seems to care about employees
cons: low level managers are poorly trained

headline: Branch Investment Consultant
pros: Schwab is a great company. They take great care of their clients and they have great products to offer. Far superior to their competition.
cons: Branch comp plan and lead distribution do not match up. Tenured reps get all the best clients. When a rep leaves the other reps pillage the book and replace each client with one of their own unengaged clients deep into retirement. The pay ranges from about 50k - 250k. The tenured reps have some type of secret agreement to sabatage​ the new reps making it very tough to succeed no matter what your skill set. I was in the Jax, FL branch and lasted 2 years before I through in the towel. Not all branches are like this. A good rule of thumb would be to stay away from branch jobs that have 3-4 tenured reps with 10+ years in the same role. Look for branches​ where the manager promotes reps to bigger and better roles. Also, look for equal lead distribution and defined client engagement rules in place that are followed.

headline: Great People but no advancement
pros: Great people to work with: bright, fun and collaborative.
cons: No chance for advancement. Always brings in talent from the outside for new/exciting roles.

headline: Great Company!
pros: Working as an intern at Charles Schwab Corporate office, I can say Charles Schwab is a great company to work for.  This is truly a company that cares about its employees.  Amazing benefits, amazing people and great balance of work and life.
cons: Pay is not as competitive as some other places, however I believe the benefits and work environment more than make of for that.

headline: Managing Director
pros: Great business model. Clear vision/strategy
cons: Limited career growth. Location strategy has been dragging on for 10+ years. Culture is changing , not for the best, as new technology management is brought in

headline: Registered Rep
pros: Top management strong strategic plan.  With the Fed raising short term rates huge help to net income.
cons: Middle management weak.  Don't promote on merit. Supervisors are dictatorial. Most do not know how to communicate with people they work with.  Employees fear losing their jobs if disagreed with supervisors thinking..

headline: It was a great experience
pros: great money, brokerage training and it all
cons: bad hours, very stressful and areas

headline: Associate
pros: Great Benefits, Great Co-Workers, Good Company to start your finance career
cons: Technology is outdated to service clients; Managers are promoted with very little training on handling morale issues on their teams

headline: Staff
pros: Flexible and friendly environment to work. Good benefits, bonus..
cons: Nothing to mention for Cons..

headline: Call Center
pros: The benefits and 401k match were good.  Along with that pretty much  3 out of your first 6 months are training.  And during one of the months they pay you to study for your 7 and 63/66.
cons:
Major downside is the call center enviriment, it's not for most people.  After a few months on the phones taking calls after calls after calls it burns you out.  Most people on my team about 10 people couldn't wait to get moved to a branch or find another job in the financial industry just so they could be off the phones.  

Even after you get your license and become a "broker" plan on most of your calls being service calls such as password resets and questions about their accounts.  Only trades you take are unsolicited so don't plan on using any analytical skills to help the client pick an investment.  

So if you're trying to get into the finance industry this job is a good start but only if you really can't find another job in the industry.

headline: Glorified and spineless meeting schedulers wanted
pros: As a project manager at Charles Schwab you will get to work on a variety of projects and with many people across the organization. You shouldn't get bored. Having worked with a number of teams outside of the Project Services group, I observed a general culture/attitude amongst Schwabies - a proud, driven, team-spirited, get-things-done attitude. I've worked with some highly-driven individuals and learned things from them. Upper management, outside of Project Services, are generally very engaged, supportive and involved operationally.
cons: My rating is based entirely on working as a Project Manager in Project Services at Charles Schwab. The upper management in this group consists mostly of individuals who have somehow made an entire career at Schwab and are now in a position of power. They're toward the end of their careers and care only about themselves, not the people working for them. They've created a toxic environment for those that care and take pride in what they do. The group is a body shop. They're interested in having the personnel so they can bill their clients. The capabilities of the people, the quality of work they deliver and how thinly resources are spread do not matter. It's a matrix organization structure where all the disadvantages of such a structure are playing out very well. The ineffective and poor management has you constantly being pulled in different directions leading to employee dissatisfaction, low morale and high employee turnover. In my experience, it was very difficult to maintain a good work-life balance. Project managers are often allocated multiple projects on the recommendation of project directors who will pull an allocation percentage from thin air, with little understanding or care of what is actually involved or stakeholder expectations. Don't ever question how they arrived at the allocation. The project manager also reports to a personnel manager and has regular waste-of-time one-to-ones with them. The personnel manager knows nothing about your day-to-day work, yet they do your annual performance review. They have no power or influence should you need their support. As a PM, you're also burdened with having to request regular feedback from stakeholders and project directors, something you would think the personnel manager could take on. Only the project director's feedback bears weight so be sure to get along with them. If you want to be a glorified meeting scheduler and don't mind being seen as just that by business partners, then hop on board. If you want to lead teams, add value and learn a thing or two steer clear as you'll be in conflict with Project Services leadership for being in the weeds.

headline: Overall
pros:
Great culture
Company truly values its clients
Solid 401(k) with matching
cons: Very limited compared to other financial services firms

headline: Broker Trainee
pros: Great support by your managers and trainers
cons: Operational issues sometimes are frustrating

headline: Manager
pros: Great benefits (401K, HSA contribution, vision, dental etc.), great culture that supports development and growth for employees, low turnover/ high employee retention
cons: Jobs are moving from San Francisco to Denver

headline: Just depends on your department
pros: Great Place to get your foot in the door. Good benefits. Lots of different areas to work.
cons: Some departments have their "clicks" and favoritism.

headline: Going downhill
pros: Good place for recent college graduates to get started.
cons: Very low pay.  Increased health insurance expense.

headline: High expectations for below average pay
pros: Great Fundamentals of Service, Fundamentals of Trading, and Advanced Broker training. They also do a good job of vetting new managers for their core teams.
cons: Merit increases don't even keep pace with inflation. When you're promoted, you don't receive a pro-rata merit increase, and sometimes you're promoted with no promotional pay increase at all. You have to pay up-front for continuing ed, and reimbursement process is tedious. Misogyny exists; it's still a 'boys club', especially in branch offices. Terrible cafeteria, and only 30 minutes for meal break. Inconsistent selection process for managers outside of the core teams; some have zero leadership skills.

headline: Good Company to work for
pros: Excellent diversity, decent benefits, and good work life balance
cons: Not too many job opportunities in the San Francisco Bay Area

headline: Customize portfolios to meet financial goals
pros: Good offer, great co-workers, good tools, competitive salary. Sincere sense of satisfaction in building client relationships. Offer stimulates client engagement.
cons: Way too much work load and no work/life balance. Too much upper and middle management hired from outside the company.

headline: Participant Services
pros: Great benefits and 401k match. Friendly atmosphere. management concerned with your growth. Good pay for being a call center job. They'll help you get your Series 7 and 66 licenses (it's required to keep the job, but they'll sponsor you and give you 5-6 weeks straight study time)
cons: High turnover rate. This department of Schwab is a call center, so stress can be high, especially because the job relates to finances. The initial training is lacking and most of the important information has to be learned on the job while taking calls, which adds to the stress

headline: Charles Schwab
pros: Very excellent work culture with benefits
cons: There are currently no major downsides.

headline: Lots need to be fixed
pros: Schwab has good talent working there. Have or will be investing in new facilities.  Benefits are industry standards (not pay).
cons:
Pay disparity btw peers and genders is significant 
Business growth is significant however leadership won't invest in people or systems 
Teams are overworked 
Pay for performance is not based on performance but rather strategy
Leaders are bullies

headline: A golden opportunity
pros: A culture of service and excellence
cons: Few to none, a great place

headline: Worst management
pros: Monday through Friday - received a pay check
cons:
I was there 2 years and had 5 managers. 
Training was horrible. This was the job where I have felt the least important- answer the calls - nothing was ever good enough. There are were no written policies in this department. 
Management clocks in and out.  There is no care for people, you are a number just like their customers. 
 Employees speak to each other with the utmost disrespect. 
Reporting issues caused retaliation.

headline: Some areas are great, others not so much.  It all depends on where in the company you work.
author_position: Managing Director, Third Party Risk Management
pros: You get a 4 week paid sabbatical every 5 years you work. Free financial consulting for all employees. There are a ton of really great people that work here. The CEO is the real deal.
cons: Don't work at the Bank (Charles Schwab Bank). The leadership team is driven by emotion. Systems are terribly antiquated with very little appetite to invest further.  Most processes are very manual, but as the Bank continues to grow staffing for those processes doesn't keep pace leaving existing staff to pick up the  slack by working longer and longer days.

headline: Some areas are great, others not so much.  It all depends on where in the company you work.
author_position: Managing Director, Third Party Risk Management
pros: You get a 4 week paid sabbatical every 5 years you work. Free financial consulting for all employees. There are a ton of really great people that work here. The CEO is the real deal.
cons: Don't work at the Bank (Charles Schwab Bank). The leadership team is driven by emotion. Systems are terribly antiquated with very little appetite to invest further.  Most processes are very manual, but as the Bank continues to grow staffing for those processes doesn't keep pace leaving existing staff to pick up the  slack by working longer and longer days.

headline: A great employer
pros: Very fast paced.  People are passionate about their work.  Good corporate atmosphere.
cons: A lot of re-orgs that there is no continuity.

headline: Great company that values its employees and clients
pros: Working in a branch is great. Clients are for the most part great. My team is awesome and my manager actually cares about me and my professional growth. The back office is great and gets things done efficiently. The pay is great and above industry standards. Great 401k match with immediate vesting, ESPP's, and good time off plan. The company's stock price has doubled in a year and schwab is starting to eliminate the competition
cons: Technology could be a little better. Our computers and some of our systems look a bit dated. The hiring process in my branch network is very slow so we were left quite short staffed during busy seasons (tax season)

headline: Portfolio Consultant
pros: Great people and a real passion for clients. Limited sales involved as clients are typically sent your way via financial consultants in local market
cons: Client contact is primarily over the phone and practice sizes are too large to provide the level of relationship that could be provided at an independent firm.

headline: Good company, room for improvement
pros: Comp is solid if you are a performer.  Company allows you to be somewhat independent.  Colleagues are decent.
cons: No upward advancement without a significant pay cut.  Branch management is full of opportunity for improvement (a.k.a. pretty bad). Regional level has, for the most part, been there forever and think they are demigods.  High performers have nowhere to go except out and the new managers are mostly jokes who don't know how to manage a proper sales team.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good Team to work with. Great atmosphere and collaboration. Work-Life balance
cons: Slower growth potential to managerial levels and above. Need to break glass ceiling

headline: Charles Schwab
pros: Good company to work. All the technologies used are up to date. Even tools used are the most recent version.
cons: no cons found yet as I worked as an offshore resource.

headline: Business Systems Analyst
pros: Fiscally conservative and very ethical
cons: Does not promote from within

headline: Schwab Review
pros: Innovative, customer focused financial company.
cons: Most IT jobs will move away from San Francisco

headline: Account Solutions
pros: The people you work with are great and the 401k match is fantastic. Management supports getting licensed.
cons:
Licenses are limited to department need, so if you eventually will need a license to transfer to another department they will not allow you to sit for it, even if you pay.  OSAS is a joke. The entire management team is out for themselves and won't assist in growth unless they see it as convenient. The managers are constantly trying to meet nonsensical numbers and force their stress on their employees. Everything is about numbers and not quality of work or even client service. If you need time off and you're in a supervisory role, GOOD LUCK. You'll have a less stressful outcome if you just prepare yourself to call out. If you're pregnant, they want you to get on FMLA so that it will cut into your (already short) maternity leave. 

The pay is below industry standard and it is well known. They don't do anything to make up for that fact. Management announced that Schwab was the #1 publicly traded company and that same month lowered the quarterly team allotment for outings. That's the only extra incentive, too. The morale is low and the department is a sinking ship. 

Did you do everything they asked last year? Did you exceed everyone else's numbers but didn't do enough brown nosing? Then you're not getting a promotion or your bonus. There are very few people I know here who are happy with their job/career, and who want to stick around long term. 

The company may be different in other states but I would never recommend the Orlando office. I'm currently researching other companies for better opportunities.

headline: high volume
pros: left alone and all is well
cons: not a career destination, they watch what you get paid

headline: A company that is focused on hiring young new graduates only
pros: The benefits package offered is somewhat fair. Definitely not one of the best.
cons: Poor management, salary is below average, does not hire older workers

headline: Estates and Operations
pros: Great co-workers and health insurance.
cons:
Managers are promoted based off of tenure and test assessments!

Having knowledge doesn't matter at all.

headline: Great company
pros: Friendly staff, great training, opportunity to make a great income, managers are above average.
cons: Phone work. 90% phone work. That is something that I was unable to perform. I knew going in that it was a phone job, but unfortunately i couldn't handle the lack of creativity. Long waiting period between advancement in positions, but I understand why.

headline: Operations
pros: High on the ethics listing...
cons: Not a lot of upward mobility

headline: Good opportunities
pros: You will work very hard and learn a lot.  The firm really does care about its clients and supports employees to deliver great service.
cons: Like most large companies, initiatives are rolled out sometimes before they are fully ready.

headline: Client Relationship Specialist
pros: Everything, great group of people and plenty of room for advancement
cons: Taking the 7, incredibly hard but possible.  Also, the roll is one of customer service and has all of the down sides of customer service.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Little autonomy, little dialing. Each branch has very different dynamic, get to know the traffic flow and manager.
cons: constant grind, each year the trail goes down and asset goals go up. Great position for advisor with less than 3 years experience.

headline: Good Corporate Culture
pros: Very committed to the average investor, truly desiring to help everyone achieve their future financial goals.  Caring environment, with good work/life balance
cons: Relationships are key, so if you don't have them, it is hard to advance.  Very old school.

headline: Senior Marketing Manager
pros:
Great work environment 
Leaders that care
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Great Products
pros: Great product offering makes it very easy to position solutions to meet clients' needs.  Charles Schwab is great at democratizing financial services to make it accessible to the masses.
cons: Base pay needs to be much better.  Very confusing structure, only a portion of base is fixed the rest is based on service pay which is variable.

headline: Financial Services Professional
pros: Highly structured, ethically sound corporate environment
cons: Bureaucratic, "churn-em & burn-em" mentality towards employees (ie high negative attrition), below industry average compensation, unfulfilling line of work

headline: positive
pros:
good people
work can be varied and interesting
good work culture - you are valued as an employee
cons:
current relocation strategy to Denver
bit slow adapting to new technology

headline: Techical career killer company
pros: Work life balance is good
cons:
1.  If you are a technical person and want to advance your career, the company is ten years behind technologically.  They still use a mainframe around which they do everything.
2.  The management does not value technical people.  If you are technical, you are treated as a second class citizen.  This is a money making financial business and always looks at the bottom line.
3.  Schwab has very questionable morals.  They encouraged their employees to vote for Trump.  They do not encrypt their customers information as they send it to India for example, and overall their marketing says one thing, and the management does another.  They gouge their customers any way they can.  They do not believe in building relationships.  
4.  There is conflict of interest in this company.   They offer financial advice that is borderline illegal because it is skewed towards their own financial products.  Of course they have an army of lawyers that makes sure all is covered in the small print.
5.  Upper management in technology are not technology people.  They are great politicians but most of them have never worked in technology.  As a result, technology is not understood and innovation comes from vendors only.

headline: Sr Manager - Training
pros: Most everything, chiefly the culture, ethics, opportunities and benefits (for example: 4-week fully paid sabbatical for every 5 consecutive years worked).
cons: Very little - provided you have the talents needed.  It is a fast-paced and rapidly changing organization (as all healthy growth companies are), so you must be comfortable with change.

headline: Web Development Manager
pros: Excellent corporate culture. Honest. Respectful. No subterfuge.
cons: Severe technical constraints from legal department.

headline: Client Relationship Specialist
pros: The company puts the clients first.
cons: There are no cons of working here.

headline: Not sure where all these 4 and 5 stars are coming from? Paid posters?
pros: Very nice people work there and if you are a client, you could not ask for a better place to have an account. They have everything for clients.
cons: Management micromanages you to death. They measure everything, how many pees you take a day, how many times you breathe, how many times you aren't pounding the phones yet still having to sound like you are relaxed and perky. Great job for a perky college grad trying to get going in this industry but a horrible place for experienced staff. They are the wal-mart of the industry and you are treated like it. Raises are teeny, bonuses never live up to how hard you work.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Nearly everyone you meet is very nice, willing to help and incredibly intelligent.  Management really advocates for employees and truly work through the eyes of the client, across all businesses, which is what stood out to me when I initially applied 5 years ago.
cons: With the move from San Fran to Denver, the morale is down for those in SF, not engaged and hard to influence when new projects are initiated.

headline: Great Company
pros:
Amazing culture
 Plenty of room for advancement for those willing to work for it
cons: None at this time.  Keep it up!

headline: FC Outlook
pros: Great people, clients and benefits
cons: Too much bureaucracy that becomes a wast of time but that is part of working for a large financial service firm

headline: review
pros: there are many resources available
cons: begin a remote location is limiting

headline: Team manager
pros: the people and time off benefits
cons: Not enough people to do the work

headline: Good People, Standard Pay
pros: Motivated and hard-working employees. Clean company that does the right thing for its customers. Easy to move to different departments/internally transfer. Very good employee recognition programs.
cons: Takes a while to move up, constant re-organization, salary increase is difficult. Layoffs imminent as company cuts costs.

headline: Excellent Company
pros: This is the best company I've worked for, the culture is amazing and I've never felt so valued before.
cons: Honestly I don't have any

headline: Sr administrator
pros: Opportunity to grow, not a call center it is an operations center opportunity to get licenses with finra good experience for starting financial services Career
cons: Micro manage, low salary, low bonus, not many departments in el paso compared to other centers from the same company, lower salaries compared to same job in other cities like Orlando and Phoenix

headline: Events Manager
pros: Great people, work-life balance
cons: Not able to work remotely

headline: Operations Manager
pros: Leading company in the industry, fantastic overall culture. It's clear that senior leadership cares about employees. An incredible number of senior personnel have been with the company for 20+ years, which is a testament to the fabulous culture.
cons: Not all sites and/or departments are created equal. Some get more perks/bonuses than others. The long tenure of leadership can cut both ways, making it difficult to spearhead new initiatives.

headline: Advisor Custody and Trading Specialist
pros: Great benefits. Great retirement plan structure as well as stock purchase plan.
cons: Low salary. Slow to advance for 90% of work force. Redundant skill. More challenges and SME criteria should equal better salary. Lack of growth and potential is under utilized.

headline: Salary
pros: Upward movement is attainable with dedication and motivation.  The pay is great for a new college student ready to start working
cons: call center enviroment and metrics are always being monitored.  Relocating is probably a must to advance in a position for more pay

headline: Senior administrator
pros: Opportunity to obtain licenses, company has many areas to grow. Shifts vary during the week but you don't have to work on the weekends. Great if you don't have a degree and want to quit the restaurant or retail industry.
cons: Many high school graduates with no formal education, 90 percent of hires are women, no cafeteria, mom and pop mentality when it comes to rewarding employees or Holiday's parties.

headline: Client Service Manager
pros: Career growth opportunities relatively quick
cons: Poor Management and high turnover with employees

headline: Worst company I worked for in Years
pros: good pay and benefits. good locality
cons: no work life balance. worst company I worked for in years.

headline: Relationship Specialist
pros: Good benefits, great start for entry level and to get your licenses
cons: Upper management can sometimes stifle your growth- you must know how to work in the politics to advance.

headline: Great company culture and well managed
pros: Company has a great culture- generous benefits, high integrity management, no jerks allowed to be hired.   Not your typical  greed-driven Wall Street environment for the financial industry.   They are innovative in their market space and try to do the right thing for investors.  They are a well run company with strong financials and good growth prospects.  They allow employees to spend volunteer time working at local nonprofits, and they have a company matching donation program.
cons: Pay is lower than average.  They are a big company so the typical challenges that go with that environment

headline: Operations Account Solutions Specialist
pros: Great company to work for with great benefits
cons: Can be too extreme on metrics.

headline: Ethical and Customer-Focused Financial Services Firm
pros: The executive leadership at Schwab is very focused on meeting the needs of millions of ordinary investors, delivering value and excellent service experiences.  This mission infuses the entire firm and makes most employees very proud to be "Schwabbies".
cons: As in any large organization, especially one operating in the very low interest-rate environment that we've had in the US since 2008, there is sometimes a mismatch between tasks and the resources, tools, and personnel assigned to carry out those tasks.  At Schwab this meant that bonuses and raises were pretty paltry, opportunities for advancement were somewhat limited, and the company consciously determined to eliminate or move thousands of jobs out of San Francisco, the high-cost location of its headquarters.

headline: Great Employer
pros: Great work environment with positive leadership and many career development opportunities.
cons: Can be difficult to make vertical moves, but lateral moves can expand your knowledge and afford multiple upward opportunities for highly skilled individuals.

headline: Charles Schwab IT
pros: Bonuses and stock options when awarded are very good.  Great team experience and environment.
cons: Constant rate of change, often resulting in projects and solutions being "close enough" so there can be a lack of closure.

headline: Great Company with Declining Investment in California/Home State
pros: Great people, collegial atmosphere, strong client focus.  It was a good place to work, until the unit I was in moved to a structure that enforced back channel communication
cons:
Limited advancement, Company is not invested in a California location.  They have consolidated SF footprint from 6 buildings to 1 in my tenure.  I give it 3-5 years before they exit California entirely.  All the signs are there.

I also have reason to believe that I was treated poorly due to disability I acquired during my tenure there.  Certainly, my management told me point blank that accommodation was not possible....I believe "well, your colleagues don't have these limitations, so why should we accommodate yours?" was what was said.   My accommodation cost them nothing but my goodwill in the end.

headline: Don't Do It
pros: The work you perform is very rewarding, it has sound and immediate impact to the company's overall objective and mission. People are friendly and willing to go out of their way to help you. Great software tools they are using for their trading. You are surrounded by people always pushing the status quo and going above of beyond, not settling for the simple answer and analyzing more than necessary.
cons:
Doesn't Recommend
Negative Outlook
No opinion of CEO
I worked there (More than a year)
Pros
The work you perform is very rewarding, it has sound and immediate impact to the company's overall objective and mission. People are friendly and willing to go out of their way to help you. Great software tools they are using for their trading. You are surrounded by people always pushing the status quo and going above of beyond, not settling for the simple answer and analyzing more than necessary.
Cons
Management isn't always forward thinking. Very bureaucratic. Can be extremely political, you do have to kiss butt to the right people to move up the ladder, which is extremely slow. In the headquarters, the culture and climate is good but people do act like their poop doesn't stink. This is also noticeable in the company holiday party and summer socials/ happy hours. Compensation lags a bit behind what other competitors pay for the same position in the Denver metro area.

headline: Relationship Specialist
pros: The people were friendly and always willing to help. There was room to grow and I learned something everyday. The company is great.
cons: I have nothing negative to say about the company. I really enjoyed working there. Just be aware of the investors/clients. Sometimes they were angry about things that wasn't in our control.

headline: Schwab
pros: Allows for a good work-life balance.  The company is full of good co-workers
cons: With the shift to move employees out of San Francisco, the morale is low, for SF workforce.

headline: Amazing company
pros: Great bene and they care
cons: I really have no cons

headline: Bank Rep
pros: Great company and culture if you are a broker, interacting with clients in the market is a learning and growth opportunity.
cons: nothing that sticks out in my mind. if you want to be a broker, do not hire in as a bank rep. the selection process to move is minimal

headline: Working for Charles Schwab
pros: Salary bonus telecommuting not much else
cons: Bad management. Managed by a nontechnical manager who project manages the team with priorities that constantly flip flop

headline: Very political.
pros: Free retirement advice and trading discounts  . New modern facility. If you want a safe place to park until retirement and you don't question how things are done, then this is the place for you. Typical working environment for financial service, banking or insurance.
cons: Rated best place to work by the employees that are just waiting it out to retire.  In management you are strong armed to give highest ratings on survey.

headline: Challenging - both good and bad
pros: Fast paced & technically challenging.
cons: Priorities often shifted on a whim

headline: So far it's great!
pros: You know, in the end, it completely boils down to compensation.  If I feel like not only am I being fairly compensated, but that I also have a future here, I'm a happy camper.  Schwab also values its people -- there is training and education budget every year.  A far cry from some of the tech companies I've worked for!  I anticipate being with Schwab for a long time to come!
cons:
I really only have two complaints:

1) There is no regular work from home policy.  You can work from home if you really need to, but you are otherwise expected to be in the office.  

2)  You have to accrue your time off.  So even though I can accrue up to 200 hours of vacation time, you start out with zero, which depending upon the time of the year that you start, can really be a bummer (i.e., right before the holidays)

I don't see any point in complaining about the high deductible healthcare plan, because pretty much all companies have gone to this.

headline: Financial Services Professional
pros: There is great leadership at Schwab. They care about your career and if you want to go somewhere, they will help you get there if you put in the effort and show dedication. They are really good at hiring as there's a lot of strong talent.
cons: Not many downsides... It's very busy on the phones. They may be understaffed. If you like competition this is the place to be. There is a lot of strong talent.

headline: Financial Services Professional
pros: There is great leadership at Schwab. They care about your career and if you want to go somewhere, they will help you get there if you put in the effort and show dedication. They are really good at hiring as there's a lot of strong talent.
cons: Not many downsides... It's very busy on the phones. They may be understaffed. If you like competition this is the place to be. There is a lot of strong talent.

headline: Revolving door policy at Charles Schwab in Denver location
pros: Good company to work at your first year.
cons: On your second year they will harass you on your performance to get you out of the door. If you want to transfer to another group you have to renegotiate your salary and your 2 year cycle begins again.

headline: Team Manager
pros: Decent benefits, many different departments allow for opportunity to try new positions when you get burned out in your current role
cons: They have become much more focused on metrics than in the past.  Employees complain they feel like a number and not a valued member of the firm.

headline: great if you don't have a big family and are willing to work
pros: Team based, great managers, room to improve and move up.  stock plan services. great heath insurance
cons: required overtime, might work holidays, required voluntary overtime

headline: Good
pros: Good company to work for
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: High Stress, Low Pay
pros: The word in the office is "Schwabfare" (instead of welfare).  Poor pay for the heavy responsibility you take on with every trade and every time you speak with a client.  The company is making an effort to change the low pay, but for right now, I would say get your license and move on. High deductible/ mediocre health insurance.  Sick time instead of PTO.   Every second of your day is scheduled and tracked.  Even though I'm a broker, I’m really just a customer service representative in a call center with high stress and low pay.  You can move on to other positions, at higher grade levels,  but they only allow a certain percentage increase in your salary which is less than the grade level you’re  promoted to.  I’ve been “successful” in my role, but I’m thinking I could make the same money as a receptionist with a lot less responsibility.
cons: Some of the nicest and brightest people I have ever worked with.  I have a great manager.   They helped me get my licenses and trained me.

headline: freelance art director
pros: Everyone was very pleasant from the first contact on. Great work-life balance, incredible benefit, talented team.
cons: Some assignments can be a bit dull, but expected.

headline: good culture
pros: good people who care about the work
cons: moving half of the jobs outside of SF

headline: Good Company
pros: Great benefits and nice work environment.
cons: I have nothing bad to say.

headline: Not a great work environment
pros: This one's tough. I try to be positive, and there weren't many things that I liked about this job.
cons: I hope you never have to go to the bathroom. You could get written up. I never called off - one day i got a call at 3 pm, 1 hour before I was supposed to leave. My wife flipped her car and I had to get to the accident scene. Told my manager what was going on and she let me go. The next day I got written up for leaving early. Mind boggling.

headline: Good company, great people
pros: Fantastic people. I have never worked with a group of people so friendly and dedicated to their roles.
cons: Horribly antiquated internal systems. Extremely difficult to perform job due to how poor the internal databases are.

headline: Use them to get your series 7, then immediately look for more money elsewhere.
pros:
One of the best series 7 programs in the industry. 
Friendly atmosphere.
Education and licensing programs available.
cons:
Below average pay.

You will never get a raise. You might get a promotion (usually a lateral one) but you will never be paid more for doing at good job or tenure.

Promotions (especially to another department, which is most common) seem mainly based on 'who you know'. Knowing someone that knows the hiring manager and can put in a good word matters above all else.

headline: VoIP Support Engineer
pros: Convenient, Practical, Business Etiquette & Persistent
cons: Professional Environment, Small Office, & Flexible

headline: Don't work in tech
pros: None that I can think of.
cons: Health benefits are awful, as it's a high deductible plan.  Don't plan on getting promoted unless you play the politics game...and have a manager who is part of that game.  In 10 years I've never seen anyone in my group promoted.  Telecommute used to be an option, but no more.

headline: Customer Service Rep
pros: The company benefits are amazing, good time off, and the company truly cares about their employees.
cons: Entry Level Position even with extensive Industry Experience is on the phones doing password resets.  Very Daunting and repetetive.  The Customer Service model is lacking

headline: Alright
pros: Relaxed environment,  very nice people
cons: Lack of transparency, very slow progression

headline: Advancement
pros: Great benefits and general culture
cons: Advancement promises that never come through. Hiring freeze when the company is very healthy..

headline: Be ready to relocate
pros: Sabbatical every 5 years. Some teams allow for telecommuting (1x / week or several times).  Pretty decent Medical/Dental etc benefits. Some teams have excellent VP's/management.
cons: Geographic strategy (moving jobs to Denver, Phoenix etc) sometimes with no offer to relocate. Soon probably to TX. Hard to change departments unless you have a solid way in, otherwise they claim no experience in given dept. Politics are heavy in some groups, favoritism is clear. Denver CSIM is like a high school group of popular kids, you are either in or out. Backstabbing.

headline: Director of Business Strategy
pros: Great culture of accountability and success
cons: Extreme focus on street expectations and results

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Absolute great environment to work in. Nothing to complain about.
cons: As stated above, nothing to complain about.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Absolute great environment to work in. Nothing to complain about.
cons: As stated above, nothing to complain about.

headline: Client associate
pros: Very team oriented, working together
cons: Lots of meetings for the same topic

headline: Database Developer
pros: People are great, wide array of skillsets and personalities.  For certain levels, the nonexempt status provides great work/life balance,  true HSA and decent benefits.
cons: Well known with all employees, documentation is either very outdated or simply does not exist.  New location is so cramped and LOUD, it is counter productive causing many people to jump into headphones.  Lots of offshoring and closed door management creates an "us vs. them" culture.

headline: Ui
pros: Good environment friendly ppl good work like balance
cons: I don't see to many issues

headline: Anonymous
pros: Great place to work. Great work and life balance. Really enjoy working at Charles Schwab.
cons: Not that something I am aware of. People are great and very friendly.

headline: Focused on Clients, Not Employees
pros: Schwab is conservative, but very focused on clients. The benefits are good, and there is a reasonable work-life balance, depending on your department and job role.
cons: My department had a complete lack of vision and direction, which made for an extremely unstable work environment. Reorganizations happen at least once (sometimes twice) a year, and most come with layoffs or a noticeable volume of employee turnover. Managers are focused on their next ladder move and their "likability," and tend to ignore important personnel and project issues. Trending business/industry models and theories are implemented, only to be disregarded within months when nothing immediately changes. There is little to no employee onboarding or additional training/development after you start, so new employees have to figure things out on their own or make up their own rules. The company places little value on technology, and is behind the curve in providing necessary software and data management tools. Promotions and advancement opportunities are extremely difficult to obtain, and moving to job roles in different departments is next to impossible.

headline: APECIALIST
pros: Charles Schwab is a very stable company that invests in a lot of trainings for its employees
cons: Most people get ahead not because they are better than others but when they are close to higher ups

headline: Account solutions administrator
pros: They are always hiring especially former servicemembers.
cons: They ask during the initial interview how much was your old salary and will tell you if they want to move forward after saying they won't pay that amount. An that they don't like promotions they would rather you work the position you were hired for the entire employment from what I was told by the recruiter

headline: All that glitters isn't gold
pros: Yearly bonus and raise if you follow the rules without much effort.
cons: Phoenix office is turning into more of an off the script call center than anything else. There seem to be less and less career minded people there, and more young kids looking for a springboard to a better job.

headline: Senior Compliance Manager
pros: Culture of putting the client first.
cons: tight budget and cost cutting. opportunities for career growth all outside California Bay Area.

headline: Good Place
pros: Great colleagues, and good benefits
cons: Management should care more about career advancement and scheduling

headline: Intern Experience
pros: They invest a tremendous amount in their interns, I felt that the professional development efforts were excellent and beneficial to all of us. Overall my experience was really positive.
cons: My manager was in a different state, and at that stage in my career I would have benefited from a more hands on mentor. Additionally, I experienced some unfortunate moments of sexist behavior. However, that behavior was from other interns, not full time employees.

headline: Always trying to improve.
pros: $18 hr to take 50-60 calls a day, qtrly raises if you meet your metrics, month long sabbatical with pay every 5 yrs of service, benefits, bonues, cash service awards for good performance, short commute, opportunity to get licensed, can relocate with offices in Dallas, Denver, Phoenix and Orlando, allowed 15 minute window at start of shift to allow for weather, traffic etc without being penalized, coworkers build relationships that extend beyond the job.
cons: Stuck at a desk with short breaks and 30 minute lunch, monotonous unless you get time off the phone to work on other tasks or complete required training,  can be hard moving to other departments if you're not licensed, shift bids means schedule can change any time business needs change so don't apply if you have to have a set schedule, attendance policy somewhat strict because it's a call center.

headline: change is constant but so is growth; at first
pros: The people are wonderful. I genuinely loved my colleagues and coming to work each day. The camaraderie was amazing. There are a lot of opportunities when you are new to the business. Great training and benefits. ESPP plan was a huge plus.
cons: After being with the firm a long time, it becomes really challenging to move up or across business units. If you are successful, senior leadership will want you to stay in your role and remain successful rather than encouraging you to try new things and grow new skills. There is a constant change of leaders at the top of organizations so that creates less consistency of messaging and direction. Bonus was inconsistent at best and salary did not seem commensurate with market rates over time.

headline: Technical Director
pros: Well run company with a clear mission and well defined goals. Communication is clear, frequent, and transparent. Benefits, salary, and work life balance all good.
cons: Somewhat conservative culture that goes along with financial services industry. Long time employees sometimes stuck in old ways of doing things.

headline: Amazing Company
pros: They truly care about your development as an employee and as a person. The support and tools they give you is incredible.
cons: Haven't had any yet. They truly support you in every area and have no problems if you want to leave one position for another.

headline: Sr. Restricted Stock Services Representative
pros: Great company to work for with excellent benefits and opportunity for advancement.
cons: Many of the jobs are being relocated outside of California

headline: CVRC
pros: Outstanding  Opportunities for growth
cons: Location is not the most disirable

headline: Specialist - Correspondence Representative
pros: Great people to work alongside. Good experience in to brokerage services, markets, etc.
cons: Compensation. The job itself is quite the grind.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Schwab is a very high-tech, state of the art company where you can learn and grow as an IT professional.  There are many groups to support you and there is a great family atmosphere.
cons: No cons I can think of.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great work life balance, Great subject matter
cons: Same cons as any big corporate company,

headline: Financial Consultant Academy
pros: Great culture and environment. Managers who truly care and listen to you and the clients.
cons: Daily role in client service and support doesn't require much skill and can be very disinteresting and makes going into work very undesirable. Easy to lose motivation because progression goes somewhat slow.

headline: Project Manager
pros: Friendly environment, co-works always willing to help you out and get you settle in the role.
cons: If you're in a revenue generating organization, I understand it's great. As the foundation of the company, the HR organization is the worst area to work for with consistent turn over, in the same department and/or the same role, reporting to the same managers.

headline: Great company to work for as long as you're not on the technology side
pros: Great benefits and salary, good place to slide by without being noticed and collect a paycheck
cons: Management is terrible, employees are used and abused. Promises are made and then broken
