headline: Sub par financial company
pros: The company overall is great to their customers and is considered conservative and stable.
cons: Structure of management and technologically they're behind the curve. Under paid in industry terms.

headline: Risk analyst
pros: great company to work for
cons: there are no cons here

headline: Current Employee
pros: Reasonable base salary and bonuses for non-exempt
cons: No telecommuting, Only 12 vacations days per year, no flexibility in branches.

headline: Mixed Bag
pros: The compensation is fair and the benefits are good
cons: Some management are incompetent and use politics to secure their positions

headline: help desk
pros: A lot of room for growth. Will pay for schooling. can move around easily.
cons: late bonus payouts. increasing work loads throughout year. no bonus for top performers.

headline: Senior Instructional Designer
pros: Great environment, including adjustable stand/sit desks; happy people
cons: They can't seem to hire me even though they love me and my work.

headline: Reporting Analyst
pros: They are all good. Actually everything was excellent
cons: Nothing. There is nothing to mention about cons

headline: Above average culture, below average professional satisfaction
pros: Ability to leave work at the office.
cons: Below industry-average compensation, inadequate resources for upward career progression, "shallow" engagement from management.

headline: Terrible place to work
pros: Loved my team.
cons: Manager of the division was unethical and created a very hostile work environment.

headline: Not a great place to work
pros: Front-line employees care about clients, but management cares about profit margin and lining their own pockets.  There are pockets of people who are smart and committed.
cons: Cronyism and politics at the executive level coupled with finger-pointing and blaming.  Ultra conservative CEO and Board preventing growth.

headline: IT Director
pros: Smart and talented people. Great culture back in the day, and the majority of people there are still great. There are still opportunities for employees in non-San Francisco locations.
cons: Unfortunately, priorities have changed and cost containment has become more important than employees. The politics have also gotten worse in some areas. The migration of jobs out of San Francisco has resulted in very low morale for the people remaining in SF.

headline: Sr. Manager
pros: Focused on seeing through clients eyes and encouraging employee and leadership development.
cons: Politics as usual as in any corporate environment due to individual personalities that belie the corporate mantra.

headline: Solid Financial Services firm
pros:
It's a large, established company with many opportunities
Average health care coverage
Sabbatical every 5 years
cons: Effecting change can be slow and political

headline: Relationship Specialist
pros: Professional, ethical, fun opportunity for growth
cons: There are no cons that I'm aware of

headline: Solid Foundation
pros: Working at Charles Schwab helped develop consistance, conservation and fostered a team enviroment while learning to work individually.
cons: The pay scale was a bit low after working 8 years with this company.  However, stock options were gifted throughout the years and that was a pleasant surprise.

headline: Great Company. Decent Pay.
pros: Great perks and cool place to work.
cons: You would be working for a very large corporation. Pay not great.

headline: Charles Schwab Knoxville
pros: Family office feel. Flexible hours. Working face-to-face with most of my clients.
cons: Not enough capacity to do all that is expected.

headline: Associate Financial Consultant
pros:
Good products for clients
Good Benefits
cons: Management was an issue in the branch I was in, which limited upward mobility

headline: Branches are "whack a mole" daily.
pros: Benefits are reasonable and the people (most) truly want to help clients.
cons: Newer management has been recruited from the wire houses and they have brought that mentality to schwab.  Metrics that are not meaningful to the client experience or to profitability are pounded and occupy the vast majority of Financial Consultants time as well as branch managers.  It has become nuts in the last 2 years.  Prior to that, the client experience was king.

headline: Software Developer
pros: Sane hours, good work life balance, great benefits.
cons: Poor management choices resulted in a lot of stress and frustration for my team.  Management was either oblivious to the havoc they were creating or preferred to ignore it in order to protect their reputations.  Also, due to the size of the company, there is an element of indifference.  Developers are shuffled around at will sometime on a daily basis.

headline: Great Company with Potential
pros: Company offers one to do the best they can do for clients. Their mission and values are passionate and it shows by the way workers show up and work hard. Potential for work flexibility
cons: Career paths are lacking. Can be very political. At times there seems to be egos that get in the way of moving forward. Slow to progress.

headline: Retirement Investment Services-Intern
pros: Great people, great culture, and they really stress maintaining a solid work-life balance.
cons: Didn't have many cons, loved my internship

headline: good place to start in finance
pros: good benefits package for employees
cons: lunch hour is only 30 minutes. no time to go anywhere

headline: Good, stable large company
pros: Great work environment, nice people, opportunities to grow and move within the firm. Training opportunities available if you seek them out.
cons: Lower salary for comparable title at other companies in Austin. Flexible work environment is due to manager, not a firm-wide policy. The worst medical insurance and embarrassingly archaic parental leave benefits.

headline: Too much politics, you are only a soldier
pros: Cozy, safe, good for a job before retirement
cons: Politics, some people get promoted even if they are not competent.

headline: Great experience
pros: Salary, benefits, career development, Ethical, growth opportunities
cons: I don't have any cons to share.

headline: Great experience
pros: Salary, benefits, career development, Ethical, growth opportunities

headline: AFC

headline: Good Company, Tight on Budget

headline: Great company

headline: Great culture

headline: Treading Water

cons: Inexperienced leaders.  Poor business integration.  Egos often get in the way of business decisions causing the best talent to use the firm as a stepping stone.

headline: Workforce Analyst

headline: Intern experience

Welcoming culture
Real work for intern
cons: No cons to list, really good company

headline: It was not all bad

cons:
salary was not competitive with the industry - did not encourage out of the box ideas or methods
inflexible not supportive of remote or mobile employees

headline: Callers Schwab Review
pros: great coworkers, excellent benefits, convenient location

headline: Broker Trainee
pros: Positive turnover. They allow you to set career goals and if you are performing in your current role then they have no problem helping you get to where you want to go.
cons: At the end of the day its a business and your goals will be halted at any time if they deem necessary for business decision.

headline: Sr Staff
pros: Culture, Flexible, ethical as investor, Innovative
cons: Location strategy,  Political, Salary

headline: Sr. Specialist
pros: nothing come to mind right now

headline: Schwab Product Manager
pros: People. You always seem to remain friends after Schwab vs, just workmates.
cons: Loss of innovation of yore - just about branch sales and tepid typical marketing.

headline: Register Representative
pros: Excellent culture and company values. Performance reward bonuses.
cons: Difficult to progress depending on your center location.

headline: Advisor Consultant
pros: Sabbatical, maternity and paternity leave, healthcare, time to volunteer, 401K, employee stock purchase plan.
cons: Compensation. Compensation. Compensation. Compensation. Compensation.

headline: Excellent team
pros:
Collarborative team.
Mentor from the management team.
Met with executive vice presidents who are really nice.
cons: None. My over all experience at Charles Schwab was wonderful.

headline: Great benefits, good learning opportunity.
pros: Great learning opportunities, growth potential is usually very good and can happen quickly, lots of emphasis on culture and diversity.
cons: Changing targets too frequently which can change who is high performing and who is under performing on a less than quarterly basis at times.

headline: Senior Regional VP
pros: Excellent compensation, well-managed company, tons of resources to help you succeed, good senior management.  Be placed I ever worked -- so far!
cons: Tends to be a young person's company, the culture is aggressive with high expectations, movement within company can be political

headline: Inside the Schwab
pros: Decent pay, No weekends, Occasional OT if you want it and if it's available. Managers are very friendly and they want to see you succeed.
cons: Full blown call center and multitasking. Big push from corporate to make that bottom dollar. They want to squeeze every bit of life out of you. Be prepared to be totally exhausted mentally, when you leave for the day. Always under staffed.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Bonus, stock, and merit increases are very good for highly successful empliyees. Company culture is laid back, most folks are very nice.
cons: Understandable, but investment in technology has been lackluster.

headline: Oscar simply Cant-do
pros: Great co-workers whom I miss seeing on a daily basis. They were like family and really worked in a team environment where everyone helped each other out.
cons: Where to start...Do you want to work for a company that took dedicated, well educated, and well performing FCs, and basically threw them out like yesterday's garbage? If you don't fit their ideal of a robotic hamster that's willing to run on the wheel like an army full of  little sales pushers, then you are of no value to them. Very check the box mentality. Managers are severely lacking in intelligence and experience. I still hear from many of my former co-workers who are my friends, and they cry about how awful it is. The regime. Managers have hidden numbers that no one else can see, so even if you're performing, it means nothing. They have "special" numbers that they make up to push you out. No one is safe. You are of absolutely no value. I've met so many amazing people at this company, many who left because they were shoved out, without reason. Great talent with great moral fiber, who appreciated the relationships they had with their clients. Such a shame. Truly the company's greatest loss.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Great Company with greath benefits,
cons: It's a business development job and not a financial advisor.

headline: Broker Trainee
pros:
-No financial background required 
-Variety of schedule options
-Paid time to study for licensing 

Schwab is a great place to begin a career in finance, IF a career in finance is truly what you want.
cons:
-CALL CENTER
-Below average salary 

If your interest in finance stems from the desire to become the next "Wolf of Wall Street" I must inform you that this is neither the time or place to do so. Aside from it's extremely conservative approach, Schwab starts everyone out in a glorified call center, in which you are expected to take inbound calls from start to finish each day. Unlike many others, I anticipated my disdain for this initial role before my first day, but it wasn't until I learned that the call center environment would continue through future roles that I decided to reevaluate my decision.

headline: Charles Schwab
pros: Great Environment and Residual Benefits leading to work/Life Balance. Culture is extraordinary and focus on employee satisfaction drives client satisfaction.
cons: Compensation is a draw back, as similar positions in other companies pay more, but also have higher demands of time in the office and working outside of work hours.

headline: Schwab
pros: The benefits are decent and most colleagues are friendly and helpful. When taking exams for licences, you generally have adequate time to study and be properly prepared.
cons: Lack of transparency from top to bottom. There is a division between some managers and workers based on the fact that management is often so far removed from the day to day issues for each team, which hampers communication.

headline: I like Chuck
pros: More genuine then most financial companies, truly care about clients. Great people, great benefits, they care about you.
cons: Call center life, stuck in cubicle

headline: You can do better elsewhere
pros: The culture is very strong in doing what is right for the customer.
cons: Taking care of the customer is on the backs of the employees.  Salaries are not competitive, benefits are pathetic and expect to work long hours.  Cost cutting is a constant and investments in the business lacking.  Hiring freezes are the norm.  The firm is always moving to the next cheapest area or moving out to whatever state gives them a tax break.  Not having financial services experience is considered a hiring plus.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Charles Schwab was a great place to work at...they treat their employees well and really care about their clients. Loved the Sabbatical that u received after working there 5 years!
cons: Pay could be higher to compete with industry more. Asset quarterly goals started getting so high that couldn't possibly meet when expected $16 million in new assets quarterly....even after working there successfully for many years.

headline: ACCOUNTS PAYABLE
pros:
Great company to work for, great benefits, great teams.  Very flexible when it came to work hours.
They had many activities to engage all the employees and always felt like our opinion mattered.
cons: They laid off many departments and didn't offer new positions.

headline: ACCOUNTS PAYABLE
pros:
Great company to work for, great benefits, great teams.  Very flexible when it came to work hours.
They had many activities to engage all the employees and always felt like our opinion mattered.
cons: They laid off many departments and didn't offer new positions.

headline: Pretty happy
pros:
Work life balance
Great pay
People are smart
Financial advice is famtastic
They work hard to set you up for success
You can transfer yourself to better job within co
Nice new building
cons:
Healthcare is horrible
Execs are Pollyanna dreamers who "appear" out of touch
Front line managers lack basic, modern mgmt approaches and skills but seem like decent people

headline: Branch Manager
pros: Schwab still truly believes in giving a fair deal to the smaller investor. It's good for the soul to work at a company that doesn't exploit it's clients. Generally you can succeed as Schwab. Quality and quantity of work get rewarded financially.
cons: Schwab has not really developed a good career track for employees. It basically means that if you want to get ahead beyond a certain point you should leave, and go get an MBA or some other experience and then try to come back. This may be the result of the company just not being big enough, or maybe it's too spread out over various centers.

headline: Okay to work at
pros: Everyone who works there is very nice and works together. Build your people skills and get trained on exactly to do the job.
cons: You are stuck to phone for your whole shift and it never feels like you get a break. The company is starting to turn into a sales company and it not about just giving good serivce

headline: Good Culture
pros: Strong Culture, very supportive group with fair benefits and opportunities. Best brand on the street!
cons: Sometimes difficult to get projects started in a timely fashion.

headline: Nicest place I've ever worked
pros:
People are really nice.  Everyone is really helpful.  I came from a place that was much more cutthroat and  it was almost weird at first how nice everyone was to me.  
If you're into trading, there are lots of perks available for employees.  Low costs, which are nice for clients.
cons: The actual trading software is pretty outdated.  The Phoenix Peak building is a little dungeon-like.  It could use a refresh.

headline: Great overall
pros: Good talent pool, plenty of interesting work opportunities.
cons: The usual that come along with a large corporation.

headline: Senior Product Manager
pros: Great company culture, work life balance, and opportunity to grow and develop.
cons: Not the best compensation and benefits.

headline: Great work/life balance
pros: Great company to work for.  People are willing to help you succeed.
cons: Too many layers of management.

headline: Project Services was Dismal
pros: Great people, great benefits and beautiful campus
cons: Although the management team stated that they were looking for entrepreneurial types, they were really more interested in the status quo. The team lacks innovation and is formed by clock punchers.  So many people come in and leave the department, it feels like a train station.  The Denver location was less engaged than a group that was facing layoffs.  That says a lot!

headline: Managing Director, Schwab Technology Services
pros: Integrity, Collaboration, culture, professionalism, fairness
cons: Consensus decision making can be slower, Moving most staff out of San Francisco

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: The people are great to work with, very kind and helpful. Good insurance and 401k benefits.
cons: They are not great when it comes to customer service.  The stats require a certain amount of calls per hour so you feel like you have to rush people off the phone or your statistics will suffer.  Also, you have to be in a call center environment for 18 months before you can apply for a different, more suitable position.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: As a Financial Consultant, you were incentivized to transition "buy and hold" stock and bond clients into fee-based clients.
cons: Management seemed to be more concerned about creating a path for their own career goals, than fighting for the rights of their associates in the branch when the firm constantly changed comp.

headline: Great place to work
pros: They have a great work/life balance policy.
cons: They are a bit being the curve on technology.

headline: Client services
pros: Great growth opportunities - great place to get your feet wet.
cons: Not great work life balance.

headline: It went downhill fast
pros:
Good culture
4X10 shifts
OT
Sabbaticals
Work you enjoy doing
cons: Within a year of a new manager joining the team, who knew nothing about the department, I began getting bad reviews, suddenly the work I had been doing was now inferior and it was clear she was intent on getting rid of me.  This was after nearly fifteen years of dedicated work there.  I would have gladly continued working there but for her.  It was obvious to me that she joined the team to get rid of senior reps.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Great business structure made for handling large scale operation.  A lot to learn about from the people and state of the art technology.  Access to many new software and a great place to learn about many skills that can be employed in many other busineses.
cons: Arrogance. Cult style groups.  Lacks diversity in executive level.  Too much bureaucracy.

headline: Massive Disparities in Departments
pros:
- The name "Charles Schwab" is the best part, people are impressed just by that - even if they don't know what you do there. 
- The facilities you physically work in are nice, in Lone Tree the campus is new so everything's in great shape - though bear in mind you will likely be in a 5'x 5' cubicle. 
- The "Kool-Aid" is great, when you first join you feel like you're working for the best company ever. 
- Fellow employees are, for the most part nice, it's hard to really get to know anyone because they push you to be productive like 95% of the time (there are even stats to measure it for you) so having genuine conversations is challenging. 
- If you're into investing they give good employee benefits specifically for that, if you're not...well, there's nice legal services available.
cons:
- It should be clarified that these are two separate companies, so be sure you know if you're working for Charles Schwab (brokerage) or Charles Schwab Bank (banking)
- The pay is a) below the industry average and b) not proportional to the cost of living increases 
- You will like be working in a glorified call center. 
- Heavily restricted cafeteria hours, even though MANY employees work non-traditional hours. 
- Moving up (or really at all, even laterally) is difficult, particularly if you start in Charles Schwab Bank - lets say you want to be licensed, you have to study on your own time (compared to the month an unlicensed broker is given to study off the phone) and then IF you pass the first time you get a $2,000.00 salary increase, even though an unlicensed broker likely already makes $6,000.00 more than you off the bat.
- This will become one of the most repetitive jobs you'll ever have, luckily you don't have to read from a script - but you do have many of the same conversations in one given day.

headline: Product Manager
pros: Generally wonderful people that work there, which makes for a pleasant day-to-day work environment.  Earning a sabbatical after five years of employment is a nice perk.
cons: Politics within management.  Very difficult to advance career without playing political games. Typically pays lower wages than industry averages.

headline: Positive experience
pros: Amazing company, with a fantastic culture and a genuine environment that encourages personal and professional growth. The company works hard to help employees achieve a productive work/life balance, and doesn't set unrealistic goals that few employees are capable of achieving. Lots of benefits for the employees, their families, and personal retirement.
cons: Low starting salary for the amount of work an employee will be doing once they are licensed brokers.

headline: Financial Service Professional (FSP)
pros:
- 401k match up to 5% 
- Employer Contributions to a HSA 
- Paid Time off 
- Opportunity for a portion of continued education to be paid (if qualified)  
- Opportunity to obtain 7 & 66 or 63 licenses 
- If you like to work OT there is plenty of it as call volumes are nearly always very high
cons:
- High call volumes create very little development & coaching, you will have to do this on your own 
- Strict schedule which does not allow for development 
- Can be very difficult to schedule time off 
- Heavy majority of team meetings will be removed 
- Expect to be micromanagement from the top down 
- Financial Consultant Academy lacks structure (expect 90% of your time to be on the phone)

headline: Great environment and people!
pros: Great pay and benefits. Work life balanced is very good. Great management that truly care about employees. Invest in continuing education.
cons: Constant change in search of continual improvement - if you don't like change this isn't the job for you. Need to be more flexible with remote working options.

headline: Pleasant Company
pros: The benefits are nice (paid time off, holidays, stock purchase plans). There are plenty of opportunities for advancement no matter what department you are in. Plenty of different shifts to be put on at call centers. Compensation seems appropriate.
cons: If your position is to work on the phones, every single minute of your day is strictly scheduled for you. Your lunch is only 30 minutes long (but they do give you two 15 minute breaks). Managers can be hit or miss.

headline: Financial Consultant position
pros: There's a culture of integrity and honestly looking out for the best interests of clients. A broad base of wealth management strategies to present to potential clients.
cons: The work load without any assistance is a burn out. Every month you start over on goals for net new sales and net new assets to the firm. you're on a fast paced tread mill until you quite or retire. I thought this was going to be a "destination" position...there's a lot of turn over at the Financial Consultant position. medical benefits are very average...maybe that's just part of the new benefits landscape.

headline: Talent Acquisition Specialist
pros: The culture is absolutely fabulous!
cons: I cannot think of any cons.

headline: retail client services Team manager
pros: Location Values and Fairness training programs
cons: discount broker operations all in house

headline: Operations Specialist
pros: Decent place to start  a career but no advancement opportunities.
cons:
Micromanagement
You are just a number and the next one will take your place.

headline: Senior Team Leader
pros: The best thing about Schwab is the people. I also believe in the firm's mission and values.
cons: The only con I can think of is once you join Schwab, it is really hard to entertain the idea of leaving and going elsewhere.

headline: Nice place to work
pros: 4 week sabbatical every 5 years
cons: It is difficult to initiate change.

headline: Sr Staff
pros: charles schwab is great work place
cons: as the company is moving its IT/Software to other places, less growth opportunities.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Great pay and a company of high ethics. Chuck and Walt Bettinger are some of the best CEO's in the Financial world.
cons: Micromanagement is at its highest level and job security is not what it used to be. Hope to get a good manager as many are puppets and are only looking out for themselves. Company quickly changes goals and targets and selling sometimes gets in the way of actually developing relationships.

headline: Not All Change is Good
pros: There is a good work / life balance.  The work environment is generally low pressure.  Most employees are easy going.
cons: All of the firm's investment product need improvement.  The review process requires self to be put ahead of everyone else for bonus allocation.

headline: profitable departments tend to have the best perks
pros: laid back yet professional culture works for most. many similar companies pay better but relaxed environment can offset that frustration for some.
cons: typically for career advancement licensing is required. many unspoken rules when seeking new positions. not always the most qualified selected. managers tend only be looking out for themselves

headline: Sr. Account Administrator
pros: Plenty of work high speed and plenty of perks. There's a lot to learn and great for any first timer in the financial industry.
cons: Base pay is kind of weak compatatively. It can be difficult to learn the large volume of information.

headline: Senior Operations Specialist
pros: Great Benefits, competive salary, the company/management cares about their employees.  Best company I ever worked for!
cons: I cannot think of anything negative to say.

headline: Horrible processes, no work life balance
pros: Semi-decent health plan, nice building in Lone Tree.
cons:
-No process or direction. The Lone Tree campus in Colorado was supposed to bring 1000's of jobs. What it brought in is 1000s of Infosys contractors. IT is literally run amok with contractors. They have their own circle, and keep to it. No sharing of knowledge, no process. They speak to their offshore team in their own language, and the results are clearly visible in quality of apps in Schwab portfolio. My full timers are leaving because of this culture.

-Constant badge in and badge out. Core hours, no flexibility. Horrible policies to get anything done, zero access on work laptops. everything has to be approved at VP level. 

-Not enough PDO, and getting what you have approved in another story. 

-Outdated systems. There are deadlines that are always missed, which results in some uncomfortable conversations but nothing actionable comes out of it. No work life balance.

headline: Government Job
pros: Work/Life balance, by 5pm everybody is out the door.
cons: Very hierarchical, people are there to punch their time cards, systems are very outdated, I've heard this used to be a great place to work, but every month we hear something about relocation outside of SF which is concerning.

headline: Asset Transfer Specialist
pros: Great corporate atmosphere and Orlando location. Also, company does host employee appreciation events and allows employees to participate during the work day.
cons: There is alot of office politics and favoritism which often involves management. Work environment sometimes promoted negative engagement rather than a positive one.

headline: Here is an update on my employee experience
pros:
One of the very few pros is the opportunity to learn about the securities industry. This is a very difficult industry to get into and you cannot obtain a series 7 license without sponsorship from a broker dealer like Charles Schwab. 

The company will sponsor you to go through the series 7 program and pay for the books and exam provided you are meeting your productivity goals set in place.
cons:
Many employees complain about the pay being lower than what other companies pay for the same type of work. Even if you obtain your series 7 license, you cannot expect a raise in pay. To my understanding, you do get a raise if you also obtain your 9/10 license. However, working as a principle or supervisor role with your 9/10 license is very stressful because they have changed the productivity standard from 3 minutes per case, down to 2 minutes per case. This include reviewing complex account openings such as Trusts and Orgs, which are considered complex account openings. The 9/10 supervisor reps are normally stressed out. The reps who open accounts are also unhappy because of low wages compared to the work performed and the cost of living. 

The company is even too cheap to give overtime and when offered its for one day or a span of a couple of weeks. Then they cancel the overtime offering. This is a detractor because there are some who need to make extra money to save for a vacation, holidays, or all of the above. Charles Schwab should indeed offer overtime opportunities because they require you to submit any additional outside work to them for approval. So Schwab does not offer the overtime and then you have to get approval from them to take on a second job??? They deny you for the second job and then what? How are you going to pay your rent or mortgage or other expenses? So in other words, if you work for this firm, they will own you.

headline: Technology
pros: Company is committed to clients and customers.
cons: Shrinking knowledge base due to a geographic strategy that has moved employees out of the headquarters location.  Business partners may be located in different regions.

headline: Good firm but changing
pros: People are good to work with (for the most part), infrastructure is good, technology is good
cons: Sometimes a lacking of transparency, technology, though good, can sometimes be lacking in good control and centralization.

headline: Great start but need exit plan
pros:
Licenses and study time
Network and Investment education
Start foundation building in the financial world
Talk to many different clients
cons:
Bonus structure and pay 
A lot of work...tons of calls, follow up and paperwork

headline: Good company
pros: solid company, a lot of different career choices
cons: it is a big public corporation

headline: Good place to work!
pros: Great benefits, pay and opportunities to grow personally and professionally and learn the business.
cons: Slow decision making process, working remote is limited. Performance rating system is outdated and arbitrary and does not reward high achievers. Working on the technology side, need frequent diversity and inclusion activities to engage the team and promote teamwork.

headline: Air of Superiority
pros: Awesome pay and benefits.  Great Lone Tree campus.
cons: There is no on boarding or in depth welcome to the firm. It was made clear early to watch my back and keep every email to cover my actions; trust is nonexistent.   Going in with a enthusiasm and ideas was immediately rejected.  I experienced leaders with a passive aggressive nature and an air of superiority that was sickening.  They treat direct reports and those under them with arrogance and disrespect.   Only caring about their direct bosses, no one pays attention or bothers to see what is really going on.  A majority of the staff is contractors, and they are  treated like outsiders.   Teamwork within the leadership team was nonexistent.   I never once heard a tenured employee say something positive about another department or person.  Sad.   Data is getting transferred from the SF site with little to no structure, and any attempt to fill in gaps is immediately rejected.   This has been the worst job experience I have ever experienced; the pay is not worth it.

headline: Windhaven
pros: I worked at Windhaven. The culture is more engaging than Schwab overall. Very smart people, especially in research. Relaxed work environment. Genuinely nice people, including senior management. It still keeps a small company atmosphere and mentality. Can-do attitude.
cons: Compensation does not measure up to the investment management industry as a whole. Some key talent left recently. Small AUM declines could mean sharp cuts in bonus. There is no recognition of the large profit margins Windhaven has. Very sales oriented. They tend to keep high profile underperformers around for a long time.

headline: Do not work in CVRC.
pros: The chance to get into a different department, if that is worth 18 months dealing with the current group in place. I had few positive experiences here.
cons: Poor management that cannot make decisions, set expectations and expect staff to read their minds. Bad culture, employee engagement is the lowest at Schwab and turnover is extremely high even with tenured staff that have joined the team. Team lacks confident central leadership and general respect from the company as a whole.

headline: Unrealistic demands from developers. Pressure to deliver.
pros:
- Occasional evening events where consultants and full-time employees were treated equally.
- Standing desks and cushioned mats. Excellent for developers who prefer standing.
- Good communication between developers and QA.
cons:
- Cannot carry laptops outside the facility.
- Multiple developer and code sharing websites blocked (no social media).
- Slow process to expedite use to third-party libraries and architectural changes.
- Lack of team strength, lot of pressure to deliver especially for contractors.
- Terrible cafe food. Don't eat there please.
- Poor phone coverage in the buildings. Cannot attend phone calls from cube.
- Takes 1-2 weeks to get full access, onboarding process is extremely slow.
- Indirectly forced to do overtime because of nearing deadlines.
- Secret faces from upper management show up in online Lync meetings.
- They do not sponsor H1B visa or hire alien immigrants for full-time positions.
- Extremely rapid shuffling within the mobile development teams.

headline: Overall, it's a good company to work for.
pros: Benefits are good and employees are friendly. Management is trusted and trying to make the company better place to work.
cons: Don't pay a lot and switching to health saving account is one big change they made  and many employees including myself don't like it a lot.

headline: Life at HQ
pros:
Good work/life balance
Colleagues are nice people
Employees and company as a whole actually want to help the clients rather than squeeze out every dollar
Decent pay
Low expectations - great for people who just want to coast, work minimally and cash your paycheck
cons: Incredibly difficult to make any substantial change - everything is stuck in the status quo from the early 2000's. There is a large unwillingness to take risks.

headline: Excellent Place to Work
pros: Great people, great benefits, very committed to high quality and an excellent client experience.
cons: A lot of jobs are moving to Denver and Texas.

headline: Former Schwabbie
pros: Excellent culture, Chuck set a great tone and the company has a very bright future.  Teamwork, collaboration and client focus are at the core.
cons: low interest environment makes investing in project spending difficult - culture shifting

headline: Great company
pros: Great benefits,  opportunities to move around,  collaborative environment.
cons: Small teams that make advancement challenging.

headline: senior administrator
pros: -amazing benefits, good company ethics, generous
cons: -tedious work messy training,too much work, no windows in el paso branch

headline: Great Company
pros: Great people and company culture.  Extensive training programs to develop skills and competencies.  Can move up rather quickly if you work hard.
cons: The pay is not great at Schwab.  Don't particularly like to promote from within.

headline: Okay place
pros: Good educational benefits, decent salary - chance to work variety of schedules. Structured environment, salary decent, environment good
cons: No room for advancement, herd like mentality follow instructions exactly, no guidance outside of e-book of regulations

headline: Horrible managers
pros: Great products with the investor in mind at all levels.
cons: The worst managers I have ever experienced in my career.  Our department had a 30% turnover rate over 2 years and when HR did exit interviews they would ask ... What are you going to tell me that I have not already heard?

headline: Schwab
pros: nice employee cafeteria and sabattical
cons: low pay corporate culture feel

headline: Diminishing opportunities in SF
pros:
Client-centric
Democratizing investing
Work-life balance
Customer service
Value for clients
cons:
Very constrained level of investments
Tops-down decision-making and solution design
Very limited advancement opportunities in San Francisco

headline: Overall great place to work
pros: The company has many great aspects including a sabbatical program, great co-workers, advancement opportunities and the opportunity to relocate to either locations if you are interested in different roles. It's easy to move to different departments and roles to gain experience with many areas of financial services.
cons: Company philosophies change often and this leads to projects that are never completed. Reorganizations take place every year leading to confusion on who does what. There is a lot of company jargon that takes new employees a while to learn.. So much jargon that Schwabbies can find a glossary on the Schweb...

headline: Technical Recruiter
pros: Great forward-facing reputation, fiscally responsible company, 5 year sabbatical, growth potential
cons: Very limited opportunity for remote officing

headline: Employees and Client now in the back seat
pros: Good initial experience in the industry and the company had solid ethical principles that it followed until the past two years.
cons:
Pay is extremely low. Benefits have progressively gotten worse. Cronyism is rampant in Investor Services.

Schwab Intelligent Portfolios is the best and most public example of the culture in decline. Schwab changed it's recommended allocations so that more client money would be in cash for the sole benefit of the share holders and company executives. Then Schwab forgot to budget the incentive cost for FCs to sell free advice resulting in massive budget cuts, hiring freezes and extremely understaffed conditions. This made a huge impact on clients and employees. Sr Leadership has disappeared during all of this and in many cases started to install scapegoats to buffer them from the fallout. Morale is at a ten year low by a wide margin. All of these budget cuts were again to support earnings and shareholder equity (few employees are shareholders any longer) of which Sr Leaders are the primary beneficiaries. We were told the cuts were to pay a full bonus (not much any way) but that didn't even happen last year. All of this is one example of profit at the expense of clients and low paid employees.

headline: Great experience after 9 months
pros:
Strong ethics -- doing what's right. 
Good work/life balance.  
Interesting technologies 
Progressive senior IT leadership -- not afraid of change.
cons:
@Vacation time is separate from Sick Time -- unlike most companies who have "PTO". If you're never sick, you have limited time off each year. 
@high deductible health insurance.

headline: Finance Manager
pros: I had opportunity to work with many different groups at Charles Schwab.  The directors that I worked with were nice people to work with.
cons: There was not enough growth opportunity and eventually day to day became routine.

headline: Risk Analysis
pros: Great benefits. Culture mostly good in larger groups. Smaller teams could have issues.
cons: No communication at critical junctures.

headline: Things are O.K
pros: Flexible schedule and an okay salary (to hit the word minimum)
cons: Lack of development opportunities, the opportunities that are there only prohibit your growth. Mostly 'resume builders' which do nothing in the long term.

headline: We're gonna be getting rid of these people here...
pros: Relocating the workforce out of state sounds like a good idea (especially for California).
cons: Too much hype and not enough real work gets done. Ultimately leads to a inefficient and frustrating work environment with unqualified managers.

headline: Awesome Company
pros: Culture, value, beliefs, client-centric, employee-centric, career development paths start immediately
cons: Having to start out in a call center

headline: Client Service Manager
pros: Great company, divert cultures, core values from the top to bottom, great people, and most importantly great benefits; sabbatical.
cons: Not much to say, it is all about the managers who can make the team feel the greatness of the company and the team

headline: Relationship Specialist
pros: your paycheck is always on time
cons: 1- you have to do your onboarding ppwk on your own time prior to start date (read: 3 hours for free as no one helps or talks about benefits with you) 2- you are just a number, no one really cares about you (the department as a 44% turnover rate)  3- a high deductible health insurance plan 4- the training is not great

headline: Relationship Specialist
pros: your paycheck is always on time
cons: 1- you have to do your onboarding ppwk on your own time prior to start date (read: 3 hours for free as no one helps or talks about benefits with you) 2- you are just a number, no one really cares about you (the department as a 44% turnover rate)  3- a high deductible health insurance plan 4- the training is not great

headline: Great company, tremendous opportunity
pros:
Great benefits
Genuine concern for the welfare of their clients, employees and shareholders
Tremendous opportunities for promotion and advancement
Good trading platform for clients
cons:
Ask a lot from their employees for low pay.  Compensation schedule is not competitive.
Advisor technology is woefully behind the industry.

headline: Product Manager / Owner
pros: Benefits, Company Culture, Ethics, Sr. Leadership and CEO, and diversity of opportunities.
cons: Pockets of inferior management - mostly in middle management positions. Misguided in what comprises there "Magic Sauce" leads to undervaluation of key employees. In some ways the company has strayed from it's core mission. But in a changing environment it is still the cream of the crop to work for within the Financial Services Industry.

headline: Relationship Manager
pros: Great people, culture and core values at the regional office level.
cons: I really have nothing bad to say.

headline: Model transformation analyst
pros: Good diversity. Very Professional. No nonsense attitude.
cons: contract job. Future opportunites uncertain

headline: Registered Representative at Schwab
pros: Highly intelligent and friendly workforce, benefits, dependent care, sabbatical program, time-off, 401(k) match, stock options for key contributors, paid training/licenses/certifications, trade commission discount, new campus, and plenty of career opportunities.
cons: I can't really think of any, but to meet the 20 word minimum:  no profit-sharing, no non-health savings/high deductible type medical benefits, and no student loan repayment/annual contribution.

headline: Associate Broker Services
pros: The benefits are great, the pay is decent, and there are opportunities for professional growth.
cons: No flexibility and the company will put off training  delaying your licensure. ZERO flexibility. You're tied to phones for 10 to 12 hours a shift. You also cannot choose your shift. The majority of your first 6 months are password reset calls and routing calls elsewhere.  Financial receptionist work.

headline: Good company... Less than great pay
pros: Culture, stability, room for growth. Truly a great company to work for, amazing benefits
cons: Salary, management, schedules. Competitors pay at least 5-10% more for a comparable job.

headline: Great company
pros: They pay well, and expect you to work hard for it.
cons: Be prepared to work hard, nonstop.  Past achievements are not recognized.  "What have you done for me lately" mentality.

headline: Client Relationship Specialist
pros: Great place to start out in the business. Large and established company. Lots of staff, so things get done quickly.
cons: Need to provide more time for employees career growth. Allow them to shadow, set aside 1-2 hours a month to do so.

headline: Great training/mgmt, poor pay and technology
pros:
- The training is unmatched and the management is very focused on your skill development
- Reg rep trainees get paid for a month just to study for the Series 7/63
- You are given a wide breadth to help clients and only need to approve a small amount of things with your managers
- Management has gotten much more flexible with approving vacation
cons:
- Lousy tech: the internal trading platform is basically command line like MS-DOS. The website/mobile app/active trader platform go down constantly, even during market hours, creating a storm of angry client calls
- Much of your time is wasted resetting passwords and the like, rather than actually trading or teaching how to trade
- The compensation is lackluster and they do not allow you to negotiate, even with a promotion
- Toxic clients, and sometimes so client-friendly it's employee-unfriendly (not firing abusive, unprofitable clients for unknown reasons)
- Every second of your day is scheduled and tracked, to the point where going to the bathroom/getting up from your desk outside of your appointed break time hurts your stats
- Even though you're a stockbroker, it's still a call center. Every day is like Groundhog Day and you make no progress towards anything which is demoralizing

headline: Opportunities moved out of Phoenix
pros: Solid company, financially secure, consistent bonuses, longevity of many employees.
cons: Move out of San Francisco took years to manage. Morale took a hit around the company.  Committed to moving jobs to Denver and Austin, limited growth opportunities for employees in Phoenix.  Budgets were tight, limited ability for technical teams to stay on top of new versions, tech.

headline: Investment Specialist
pros: Great atmosphere and team environment that promotes learning and your personal ability to excel. Not subject to the typical "ups & downs" related to commissions only pay. Schwa is a company that advocates for YOUR success and branch managers are willing to do what's necessary to assist you.
cons: Most clients of Schwab are self-directed investors, and therefore even though you may give advice, they are less likely to empower you with trade decisions. Like the stability with salaried + fee pay, it is also a con because you might have a great month in trading and new accounts that would warrant high commissions. Yet, you're stuck with salary. Some competition exists within each office, but that's typical with greed.

headline: VP Financial Consultant
pros: Great culture, full product spectrum, book of clients.
cons: There are no cons for this company

headline: Good Place to Work With little short comings
pros: Very good work culture. Its a people's friendly company. Lot of opportunities to grow.
cons: You will hardly find any mentors to grow further in your field. Lack of smart developers.

headline: Schwab
pros: Client focused.  Does the right thing.  Good people.  Good work/life balance.
cons: Limited growth opportunities in SF.  Mediocre health plan.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Good pay, good benefits, good working team
cons: cult following of senior management, when left company they aggressively came after me for trying to taking client which were not solicited but found me through a advisor search via the SEC website search, company continued to cut compensation for 3 straight year, pay out plan is constantly changing for the worse only ones benefiting were upper management.

headline: Great Company, slow growth
pros: Schwab was an inovator as the first to move online and provide low trade prices.   Good people and community.  Sabbatical of a month every five years
cons: Flexibility is non existent, little telecommuting even for non client contact staff.

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Great company culture!  Charles Schwab also has a good training program for incoming employees.
cons: Nothing I can think of right now.

headline: Great work environment
pros: Great environment and open door policy from management is great.
cons: Salary is below average compared to work output.

headline: A Great Chance To Learn The Markets
pros: Opportunity and Education. They will pay to get you licensed and trained. After enough time on the phones, you will be given access to a variety of career opportunities.
cons: Working in a call center environment presents its own challenges. Staying motivated is a true challenge after enough time in the role.

headline: Review Title
pros: Charles Schwab is a great place to work
cons: Each location has different assets but same expectations

headline: SR System Annalist/Software Support
pros: The took good care of their people
cons: I don't have any complains about the company.

headline: Call Center
pros:
Great work environment. Almost everyone I met in my department and other departments were kind, helpful, outgoing and encouraging.  

Schwab Austin provides opportunities to network, volunteer and join different professional groups.

Great retirement benefits.
cons:
In a call center position, opportunities to move up, have the ability to network and participate in company events are very narrow.  

The call center schedule is very strict, and may be subject to change to fit business needs, although there is plenty of time given for employees to plan around any changes.

If hired under COE (Condition of Employment) to pass the Series 7 and 66 exams, BE PREPARED to devote an incredible amount of your time and resources to pass these exams -especially if you have no previous finance experience.  The resources Schwab gives employees to pass these exams are very poor: no instructor, just read a colossal amount of  material during an 8 hour shift and take practice exams... if this is not your learning style, good luck in passing!

headline: VP Sr. Financial Consultant
pros: Excellent & superior platform to serve clients, plenty of current clients & prospects to help.  If you u enjoy getting know & helping clients can be extremely rewarding personally & financially.  Could take large market share of wealth management business if & only if they can figure sustainable relationship model. Financial success of company will depend on this.
cons: Model breaks as you become successful.  No plan for FC to maintain meaningful relationship with realistic  number of advised clients.  Clients sense this in large advice practices & retention decreases along with referrals.

headline: Great company
pros: Great culture and good colleagues
cons: Monthly sales goals are sometime tough

headline: Senior Video Collaboration Engineer
pros: Great company to work for. Great benefits and work environment.  You'll work with the best and brightest people in the industry.
cons: Be prepared to be challenged and work long hours.

headline: Excellent Company!
pros:
Teamwork
Sabbaticals
Great work environment!
Kind and respectful people
Fun
Cares greatly for the clients
Values and integrity
cons: None that I can think about

headline: Great culture
pros: Great professional culture. Minimal politics. Projects move pretty fast considering it's a large company. Good learning environment and development is encouraged. Really good benefits package and work/life balance.
cons: Execs are well compensated but company is not very competitive on salary/bonus for mid-level jobs. Not a lot of opportunity to move into different roles in the company.

headline: getting started
pros: open culture , supportive manager , good communication
cons: nothing yet just getting started

headline: Senior Analyst /APC
pros: Great culture in the beginning. Good benefits.
cons: Not "older" employee friendly. Replaces all senior employees with 20 yr olds. Mass exodus as pay shrunk .

headline: Associate Financial Services Professional
pros: Loved how on Fridays, you can dress in casual attire. Also during football season, every Friday's you can wear your favorite sports jersey to work.
cons: High turnover rate. If you don't pass your Series 7 and 63 for the role I was in, you are out in 6 months. Studied hard for the exam, unfortunately I did not pass. Wish I had more time. Some managers will try to help you get another job in other departments. I tried really hard to stay with the company, but I guess they value getting someone else over me in that role.

headline: Run like hell
pros: As with most corporate jobs, you get paid. On a bi-weekly basis.
cons: If you're working in San Francisco, or under the age of 35, RUN! This place is dysfunctional, poorly managed, your colleagues are getting laid off or quitting constantly, all funded projects are on hold. Don't accept a position there without reading this review. This place is a disaster. Doing ANYTHING else would be a better use of your time.

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: A good opportunity to learn about the financial industry, and unlimited overtime if you are about making some extra cash while gaining more experience as a financial professional.
cons: Management is flakey. You could be forced to work a schedule that does not match your personal life very well. No cost of living raise.

headline: Operations Associate
pros: Schwab has great work/life balance
cons: Must stay in first role for 18 months.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great atmosphere. Everyone is willing to help and be social, makes coming here enjoyable.
cons: It is very scheduled and you don't have a lot of autonomy

headline: Standard Corporate Tech Environment
pros: Job security and some cutting edge tech.
cons: Too much work, too little time.

headline: OptionsXpress legacy
pros: Benefits are good.  Some growth in Chicago,  but only certain departments
cons: Slow moving, moving a lot of work to Denver & Phoenix

headline: If Chuck only knew....
pros: It was a good firm until the "new" layer of management was created and the focus from up top has changed.  I believe in time the new focus will show its inefficiencies and the previous management's focus will be brought back.  It could be great again.
cons: The culture has changed!  The FCs are conflicted vs what the firm wants to "sell" to the public (wealth management) and what the role is really based upon (volume).  From this seasoned FC's humble opinion, you can't have it both ways.  We are held to tasks and box checking standards that do not coincide with true wealth management.  It seems the firm would welcome all 20 somethings to only focus on the next sale rather than maintaining the client relationship and to value the retention.  The compensation is geared toward the next sale and next dollar in.  That breeds a poor client relationship.  The culture has severely changed in the last few years.  FC morale is LOW and we don't feel like valued members of the firm.  The mentality from management is you are easily replaceable and the clients are not yours but belong to Schwab.  Do NOT wrap your arms around them as you only rent the compensation and the them until they leave the advised solution, spend their retirement money or perhaps move on to another advisor because you are not focused on them after they get into advice.  The compensation model is broken and it's not a concern.  If you want to work here prepare for the treadmill of "what have you done for me today" not even "lately".  These are not sour grapes I promise you that.  Want to love this place and my clients again.

headline: A growing company
pros: Growing company with plenty of room for growth.  Great cast of employees and managers
cons: mediocre health care plans, subsidiary of a large company that has many layers that make getting things done difficult.

headline: A growing company
pros: Growing company with plenty of room for growth.  Great cast of employees and managers
cons: mediocre health care plans, subsidiary of a large company that has many layers that make getting things done difficult.

headline: Registered Represenattie
pros: good number of vacation days but hard to actually have the days approved  very little else positive to say about Schwab
cons: forced overtime; outrageous "political" favoritism; forced to work on advertised holidays; below average pay; focus on call center environment, very litle attention to market specfics

headline: Great company; some pockets of pain
pros: Schwab's vision (helping the middle class to grow wealthy through investing); all employees get financial education and discounts; all employees get 8 hours each year to volunteer; leadership are good stewards of their clients' money.
cons: Nearly all positions that remain in San Francisco will be gone in a few years, though job growth is good in Arizona, Colorado, and Texas. Many tech jobs are in Bangalore.

headline: Great Company
pros: Room for growth, great atmosphere
cons: Should give Better compensation once become licensed

headline: Good company to work for, solid integrity
pros: Opportunities to get industry licenses, sabbatical, positive environment
cons: Low pay, glorified call center, higher turn over within management

headline: Contract position, first impressions
pros: Easy going culture, very nice people, emphasis on community
cons: Big organization going through lots of transition with jobs moving to Austin and Denver

headline: Absurd and terrible experience
pros: The Austin office is supposed to be decent.
cons: Employees were told that more than 1,000 jobs would be moving out of San Francisco within a few years (and then told, every few months, that details would be forthcoming), yet, despite the lack of information (not to mention job stability), we were expected/pressured to give glowing internal reviews and provide a "five-year career plan." Never been so happy to leave a place.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Great vacation plans, benefits are better than average
cons: Depending on position (management particularly), hours can be long which interferes with the concept of work/life balance,

headline: The House That Chuck Built
pros: Tries hard on employee engagement
cons: Corporatocracy; can be somewhat impersonal

headline: Good client focus
pros: Good place to work, good work-life balance, decent opportunities for promotion, and likely to be pretty stable for a finance job.
cons: Things can be a bit slow and bureaucratic.

headline: Senior Operations Specialist
pros: San Francisco had great management, and helpful colleagues.
cons: Most of the company had been moved away from San Francisco.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Great culture and people, good pay and benefits. Very mature and stable company with a lot of future potential.  Strong employer in region.
cons: Very large organization, thus (as with any large company) can become fairly silo'd and tough to navigate at times.

headline: Good company
pros: Great benefits, a lot of opportunity to move up, volunteering encouraged
cons: Stodgy, too conservative at times. Some managers in over their heads.

headline: Great
pros: It is great working for this company. It will allow you to take your career path anywhere.
cons: You have an 18 month limit on customer service before going elsewhere.

headline: Good Company to Work For
pros: Great culture.  Good benefits.  Average pay.  The company sets a good social tone.  They care about their employees.
cons: The hiring and training process needs improvement.  Not to many bad things about this company.

headline: Advisor Services
pros: Great people.  Great benefits.
cons: Inconsistent messaging from management.  Program failures resulted in job cuts.  Lack of accountability from management.

headline: Manager
pros: Great culture with intelligent teams. Job growth is mainly in Lone Tree. They offer great benefits and perks. Flexible work hours depending on your manager.
cons: Work/Life balance could be better with increased work from home opportunities for high performers. Pay and merit increases for high performers are a joke.

headline: Good place but................
pros:
On the whole a good place to work. Working for Schwab is great experience and can lead to other opportunities in the Financial Industry. 
Good employees and everyone wants to get the work at hand done
cons: Management upheavals. The entire management team for my unit was replaced within 6 months. Replacement manager plays favorites and promotes on that basis.

headline: Use to be a fun place to work.
pros: Flexible work environment. Company loyalty  towards customers is good. Many great employees use to be there but slowly most of the talents have left.
cons: As other development centers has opened around the country, no focus on San Francisco  employee engagement. Senior management doesn't care about it either.

headline: Manager
pros: Lot's of job growth on the Lone Tree Campus
cons: Pay/benefits seem to be average at best compared to the industry

headline: MD
pros: The company's culture is great and executive leadership does care about the employees.
cons: Some VPs don't care about equitable pay for their employees, and career growth is limited.

headline: It use to be a fun place to work
pros: Good people, learn the markets to trade/invest for yourself, basic salary to just get by
cons: Over the years, the company has lost their soul from Chuck's original vision "take care of employees, who will take care of our customers", that no longer exists

headline: Not a place for growth opportunities in San Francisco
pros: As far as Financial Services providers are concerned, Schwab has a well-diversified investment product line and business model, they place a high value on customer service, and you receive excellent value as a customer. It's a purpose-driven company which somewhat helps keep you grounded through what feels like constant change and downsizing in San Francisco.
cons:
I used to think I could do my best work at Schwab, then the downsizing in San Francisco began. There used to be 6,000 employees in San Francisco. When the current round of moves away from SF are completed, there will only be about 1,100. This is very unsettling for those staff members in San Francisco. The company feels like it's being managed from outside California (in many areas), even though the headquarters is still technically in SF. There are concerns about whether the number of positions in SF will continue to shrink over time.

It's a tough culture to be innovative and cutting-edge. Many talented staff members have left. It's the end of an era for Schwab in SF -- especially for those of us who knew it during it high points.

headline: Can be a great place depending on how you network
pros: Schwab is a great company although the work can be demanding as with any career. People are amazing, sabbatical for every 5 years, amazing flexibility to grow within the company.
cons: The pay which of course we can all argue we're underpaid/overworked but I'm not sure what that actual ratio is compared to other financial firms.

headline: Software Developer
pros: Really nice company that pays competitive wages. Charles Schwab (CS) has invested a lot of money into their Lone Tree campus that really has a nice set up.  They have many perks, health benefits, matching 401K, Employee Stock Purchase Plan etc. CS is also convenient to the light rail and they offer a discounted pass for those who take advantage of it.
cons: I found that there was little (if not none) mentoring for students right out of college, you will spend the first 2 months literally just sitting at your desk waiting to get proper permissions (passwords and software access) to perform your job. Nothing at CS moves fast. CS relies heavily on contract employees both onshore an offshore and this presents a challenge. The contract employees (mostly of Indian decent) have their own clique, they stay together and are rather secretive but in the chance they do share information it's rather hard to understand exactly what their saying. I also found that many of the contract employees don't understand investing thus they just go through the motions without real insight into the business to which they are writing code for, which presents a big problem. This is just my frustration and there have been many developers come in an do a great job without issues but then I've also seen top developers leave within a year because of the issues listed above.

headline: Client Service Professional
pros: Generally great group people, lots of benefits, decent amount of flexibility in hours, staggered training to really gain concepts.
cons: The job itself - an inbound call center for Schwab Bank. You spend a big chuck of the day being yelled at by clients. It can be draining and demoralizing.

headline: Good place for steady paycheck
pros: Salary return on actual number of hours worked here could be highest in the industry, good work-life balance, nice people, convenient for commuters, good resume fodder
cons: Very bureaucratic, geostrategy in SF makes work atmosphere depressing, lots of dead wood, mediocrity is the norm rather than the exception

headline: Sr. Project Manager
pros:
The only ethical financial services company
Nice people
cons: Have to be really nice to get work done.  Takes time to gain consensus.  Will mostly work with distributed teams across Denver, Austin, SF and other sites.  Lower than average pay and few promotions to Director and above.

headline: financial consultant
pros: great resources to help you work with clients. good knowledgeable employees. decent amount of managed products to help with client solutions. able to spend time with clients to make sure you're doing the best job for them. top rate benefits package. overall a great place to work
cons: starting to get more like other companies in requiring you to focus on certain products. also want you to play a numbers game on goal planning and retirement planning. fc's often use bogus plans for sake of meeting number each month. often pushed to follow the agenda of a regional manager who might be looking to make a name for themselves. comp can be difficult to follow

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: I was a FTE for more than 5 years. I loved my time there. I only left to getting remarried and relocating. Schwab offers great benefits including a sabbatical after 5 years. They believe in and promotes work / life balance, great community feel for a large corporation. I really miss working there.
cons: Hiring process is quit lengthy.

headline: Sr, Investment Spclst
pros: Great legacy, great products and services, superb infrastructure, many career opportunities.
cons: During recent years, too much favoritism, unfair internal hiring policies.

headline: Quality, ethical firm to work for
pros: You will never doubt that the client comes first, which makes working here very rewarding. I have had the good fortune of working for engaged managers who take on my best interests and communicate openly.
cons: If you are just starting out, you will spend at least one year grinding out calls in the call center under rigid time-management parameters. Vacation will be difficult to get approved, but after diligent work you can move "up and out" of that world and things become immensely better.

headline: Great Benefits, Poor Work-Life Balance
pros: Schwab will teach you valuable insights to the Financial Industry, and will give you all the tools you need to push your career in the financial sector where you want it to go.
cons: I have found that the work-life balance is very poor. The job is very stressful, and it feels like you are chained to your desk all day long. You are limited to a 30 minute lunch, which gives you enough time to scarf down your food to get back to work. I would work somewhere else with less pay to get away from the poor work-life balance.

headline: Retirement Plan Specialist
pros: sabbatical, good company, good benefits
cons: had one really bad manager, department is looked down on, pay was below par

headline: VP - Financial Consultant Level 2
pros: When I originally joined almost 11 years ago, Schwab, as run by it's namesake, Chuck, was a great place to work and for me to do some of my best work in an industry I've been in for going on 24 years.  It was client focused and relationship based.
cons: Since Chuck has stepped away micro management has taken over it's more about the numbers than the clients or the FCs.  Very little local assistance and focus is on monetizing clients not doing your best work for them.

headline: Financial Consultant and CFP(R)
pros: Most likely you will find good co-workers in the branch with the exception of the manager who likely has zero experience as a Financial Consultant or in consultative sales generally, has little actual management experience of experienced sales professionals, and is too young to understand how to effectively interpret complicated nuanced communications--something that can only be learned by having significant consultative sales experience.
cons: See above re Manager lack of experience.  Micro management is now on steroids as is check the box criteria that have zero beneficial results for the client but since the firm invested money in some technology it must be used extensively even if it is a waste of time and energy.  They no longer care more about revenue production than all else.  They care more about conforming to the latest dictate from above.  For multiple years, 2014 and 2015, I was the #1 producer in my branch, the only CFP(r) despite compensation claw backs and reduced benefits but since I did not play the politics and kiss the ring of the under qualified manager I was terminated without just cause.

headline: Operations
pros: Great culture and good benefits. Sabbatical every 5 years.
cons: Difficult to advance within the operations department.

headline: Client Relationship Specialist
pros: The people in general are the best part, you can actually make good friends
cons: Pay and culture - the pay is not scaled according to the work expected

headline: Operations Specialist
pros:
Great Benefits
Wonderful corporate culture- a lot of respect for employees
Good training opportunities
cons: Current market climate dictates promotions

headline: Vice President
pros: Good people good benefits nice new campus good 401k matching diversity important
cons: Culture has totally changed   No longer the CO that Chuck built. Micro management by EVP and her staff.

headline: A very decent company
pros: Values employees, great benefits, great collegues
cons: Some managers do micro manage

headline: Registered Representative
pros: flexible schedule available, very professional environment
cons: bonus structure, lots of time on the phone

headline: Schwabbie
pros: Great honest company which values its employees
cons: Pay structure needs work, they definitely have a renewed focus on advisors and private client experience

headline: Lack of Identity and Culture
pros: Customer service driven company with positive results year after year as demonstrated by their financials.
cons:
Unfortunately the company began its cultural demise when new leadership stepped in for Chuck when he retired. Now the company has lost its culture, employees are being asked to move to several parts of the country as they diminish their footprint in the Bay Area. Not many people are taking their offer.
What they have ended up with is a workforce who is demoralized and is there only to get a paycheck without energy to spend anymore time in the office than necessary.

headline: Great culture
pros: You can own your tmrw  .
cons: Traffic is bothersome sometimes. But that's anywhere i guess .

headline: Former Role
pros: Large Company, strong presence, good resources, good pricing, client loyalty, great website, strong investment choices, strong central support, good reputation.
cons: Large Company, limited growth in the branch network, reduced benefits over the years, low 401k match, limited financial products outside investments, poor mortgage pricing through quicken, poor management, continuous changes in leadership and direction, micro management, favorites outweighs effort and performance.

headline: Company has lost it's way
pros: Fairly good health care and vacation benefits. Compensation is variable but can be substantial if one works extremely hard. Coworkers can be helpful at times.
cons: The company has lost focus on doing the right things for clients. Sales pressure is very intense and the focus changes frequently to the product of the moment.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Great advice platform and tools
cons: Push slaes goals over what is appropriate for clients. Bank on employee turnover.

headline: broker
pros: client focused structure, they care about progressing you as an employee.
cons: repetitive work for many entry positions

headline: Client Service Manager
pros: Strong ethical culture - flexibility - good culture
cons: Lacks some internal processes and policies

headline: Retired Schwaby - 18+years
pros: Sr Rep for 12 years, Benefits good, vacation/sick leave/1month sabbatical every 5 years.  Free licensing -state, 7 and 9/10. Get Your license!
cons: Management has changed since Chuck no longer leads.  It is all about the numbers! No allowance on numbers for those who handle complex issues.

headline: Not the best place to work by a long night shot.
pros: Position was interesting and educational.
cons: Poor management, antiquated systems, lacks organization, doesn't value employee insight, not family friendly.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Great management and financial tools
cons: Too many products to sell with constant change regarding what's to be sold first

headline: Charles Slob
pros: if you happen to already be rich, then they care about you.
cons: they have no regard for clients.  only hard selling products.  they encourage trade activity even if it is not in line with client objectives so as to drive revenues.  you are outright told, 'I dont need you you need me."  Really a lackluster company that thinks they are the best thing since sliced bread.  Your much better off with a firm that will actually care about you and your clients.

headline: Human Resources
pros: Overall Schwab is a good company.
cons:
Prior to the current CEO, there was a great feeling of being a part of something special.  That has changed.

During an 8 year period, the business unit had 5 different HR generalists that operated differently than the previous generalist, no consistency in the way the administered policies.

headline: Document Control
pros: Great Company to work for very loyal to their employees.
cons: Very fast pace to much overtime

headline: Relationship Specialist
pros:
Career Development
Management actually cares
Great Culture
Great Team Environment
Colleagues are exceptional
cons: Pay can be more competitive

headline: Payroll Associate
pros: Great benefits and company discounts
cons: Director bias with employee choices

headline: Associate Financial Consultant
pros: Work with nice people for the most part
cons: Management is a wreck and there is very little room for advancement.  Firm has taken a wrong turn in terms of priorities.

headline: Great place to get experience working with all kinds of clients
pros: Schwab provides a clean, friendly, professional work environment.
cons: Like many other financial institutions these days, effort an emphasis is being targeted at boosting shareholder return, often at the expense of employee quality of life.

headline: old fashioned, slow and political
pros: Nice people on the surface...easy working life where most people seem to work 9-4!
cons: Quite political - lots of back-stabbing.

headline: Operations Support Specialists
pros: Schwab always treats their employees fairly and equally. They have a great benefits package and offer a wide variety of continuing educational classes. I felt very comfortable providing my opinions and suggestions.
cons: During my last year of employment, there was a general feeling of unrest within my office. There were several changes made that employees were unhappy with, including moving certain departments out of state. It made most employees feel insecure about their jobs.

headline: Used to be a great place
pros: Good people. Was once an amazing place to work.
cons: Extreme penny pinching destroyed the corporate culture.

headline: Registered Representative II/ eServices
pros: A great place to build a career. Managers are really engaged in the success of their employees. I have been given a raise every year I have been here, and the vacation time and sick time really help.
cons: The seems to be a lack of a proper work/life balance. They often times do not hire enough staff which often creates a heavy volume of customer inquiries. The phone reps take back to back calls all day and the chat reps take two chats at a time all day without much off a breather. We are asked to work overtime and holidays, and the pay is great. I just wish they would hire enough staff to prevent burn out.

headline: Little advancement opportunities
pros:
Standard benefits healthcare, 401k matching.   
No limit on sick time accrual.
Sabbatical after 5th year.
cons:
No promotion opportunities.
Salary is on the low end of the curve.
Not much discount for brokerage services.

headline: Accounts Solutions Administrator
pros: Great company to work for
cons: I have nothing wrong to say about this company

headline: Great Company
pros: One of the best companies I've ever worked for. At times felt like we were the Google of financial services.
cons: Moves at an extremely fast past; sometimes hard to process/digest it all. As soon as you do, your mgr expects you to move on to the next big thing.

headline: Review
pros: Big company with employee benefits.
cons: Reorgs happen every couple of years.  Hard to progress career.

headline: Review
pros: Great company, very innovative, Great benefits, Good people to work with all around, Good working environment.
cons: Some of the downsides to working at Charles Schwab are the pay could be a little higher and can be a little disorganized.
