headline: Good place to work and find a career
pros: strategic plans form management  Great benefits.  Excellent ability to move laterally through company and find a career. open door policies with upper management.
cons: at times the work can be incredibly monotonous.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Offer a small Base Salary
cons: Have to focus on select products.

headline: I worked at Charles Schwab for 8 years
pros: Very laid back environment, good work/life balance, great benefits. They care about their customers and their employees.
cons: Pay could be more in comparison to other similar positions.

headline: Great opportunities if you can weather the storm
pros: This is a company that will support your ambitions and development if you can play the game and get along with others.
cons: Relatively limited pay scale. Advancement can be limited if you follow the standard corporate metrics.

headline: Bank Representative.
pros:
At least on the bank side, there are so many things you can offer to keep a customer happy, that it's not too difficult to get satisfied and pleasant people to talk to. And the company feels like they genuinely care about their employees. 
It's easy to switch departments so long as you try your best wherever you are.
cons:
It's a phone based environment. This means that so long as there is high call volume you can expect almost no ability to interact with your coworkers. 
And in the bank side, there is almost no room to grow. If you don't eventually want to go into being a stock broker, expect a low ceiling.

headline: Client Service Specialist
pros: Pretty decent pay and benefits
cons: Lack of authority to resolve issues.  Segmented departments displacing responsibility makes it difficult to get things done.  Crushing bureaucracy, has gotten much worse over time.  only opportunities are in sales at the branch level to move up unless you want to move to el paso. branch environment is annoying.  the worst of both worlds of retail banking and super high net worth clientele.

headline: Great company
pros: Great company.  Great people.  Great mission.
cons: I have nothing negative to say.

headline: Manager
pros: Great company to work. They care about their customers and their employees. Upper management is transparent and readily communicates with employee base.
cons: No downside. I enjoy working Great company to work. They care about their customers and their employees. Upper management is transparent and readily communicates with employee base.

headline: El Paso leadership
pros: Great benefits, very employee oriented company.   A lot of upward mobility.
cons: I worked in the El Paso center, the site leader tends to micro-manage all aspects of center, even the front line reps.  High turn over rate in management positions because of this attitude.  A number of managers/directors were looking for or took other jobs in the very short time this center has been open.

headline: Jr Network Engineer
pros: Great place to work in.
cons: Very long hours during the week

headline: Great company that invests in your personal development!
pros: 401k is 100% vested, great culture, growth opportunities, quarterly bonuses, 30-day sabbatical every 5 years, relocation opportunity, management is responsive and caring (at least I. The Indianapolis location)
cons: Low pay when comparing same position with other companies. Hard to get the time off you want, Overall, not too much to complain about.

headline: Great company that invests in your personal development!
pros: 401k is 100% vested, great culture, growth opportunities, quarterly bonuses, 30-day sabbatical every 5 years, relocation opportunity, management is responsive and caring (at least I. The Indianapolis location)
cons: Low pay when comparing same position with other companies. Hard to get the time off you want, Overall, not too much to complain about.

headline: AFC
pros:
good pay for the job
lots of flexibility
cons: you're in a schwab branch, selling schwab products.

headline: It Depends
pros: Really solid benefits, large and stable company, many helpful and friendly people across the organization, great charitable intent and associated programs, many people build their career here by moving up within their group or changing teams or groups to achieve promotions over time
cons: More generous with titles than pay, your work-life balance and overall experience really depends on what group you work in, many jobs are being moved out of SF to CO and TX which can be a hassle if you want to live and work in the Bay Area

headline: learning and development
pros: Smart people and willing to help out
cons: no flexibility for contractors, must work on site, lots of downsizing

headline: Ups and downs
pros: Great benefits & decent pay
cons: A lot of politics between upper management and employees looking to get promoted. Seems like they were more willing to hire externally instead of within the company when new openings came about

headline: Great company but little room for movement outside of call center unless you are willing to move into sales
pros: Great benefits and overtime opportunities.  Even though the base salary is below industry standards, you can still make a decent salary by doing overtime.
cons: There's very little respect for a licensed broker in a call center and definitely not a place you would want to be long term.

headline: Financial Services Professional
pros: All the employees love Schwab, feels like a family.
cons: Promotions are really just side steps, vacation can be difficult to get

headline: Insurance
pros: Poor management at best. Way to much collusion between senior management and client best interests.
cons: The department was run by a former Director who was solely self absorbed on himself. He had his best friends in the department that he would go on vacation with outside of work. Then give them gray reviews in the process. No way to apply out to seek better opportunties for yourself do to lack of support for the Director or V.P. They where only interested in keeping there status elevated

headline: Fiance
pros: Freedom to work independently from management
cons: I was very happy to be working here

headline: Great place to work at
pros: People are great. Benefits are above average. Easy to move around departments. Decent salaries.
cons: Salary increase are currently capped at 3% annually. So in order to get a higher salary increase you would have to apply for a new position within your team or another department. Changes are visible but at times it can take a while to get them implemented

headline: Good Job
pros: Stable Job, good coworkers, fun
cons: No merit raises , insurance is expensive

headline: Analytics Role
pros: Good benefits, great salary for the amount they expect you to work, flexible work hours. Start with 3 weeks of vacation and 2 floating holidays in some roles.
cons: The company is fairly fragmented and they are fairly behind the time when it comes to staying current with modern technology. Alot of the benefits they offer don't start until after you have been an employee for a while.

headline: Senior Staff. Mainframe Capacity and Performance specialist.
pros: Great pay and always busy.
cons: Most of the managers micro-manage

headline: Short
pros: They care about their employees
cons: Tough to make change happen

headline: Sad decline of a once extraordinary company
pros: Supportive, cordial culture; talented and dedicated co-workers; fast-paced and interesting work.
cons: In the space of a few years, the company has gone from taking extraordinary measures to avoid laying off employees during the worst of financial downturns to cutting long-term employees purely for purposes of hiring in cheaper locations--and this in a time when the company is highly profitable.  I think you can still have a good experience with Schwab if you are hired into a currently desirable geographic location, but be aware that despite touchy-feely rhetoric from management about building a lifelong career with the company, they will cut you in a heartbeat if they decide you, or your home city, are now too expensive, or your position can be better filled by a foreign contractor.  In this they are now sadly like most other large corporations.  They used to be better than this.

headline: Get your licenses!
pros: free brokerage/checking accounts, many options for lateral career moves, free licensing, new employees can instantly become senior reps by getting licenses.
cons: Tenure means little except for vacation/sick time accrual. Passing 9/10=(g56) senior rep; passing 7/63=(g55) senior rep. No exceptions. Employees without a 9/10 are (g55) for life with lower bonuses and lower salary.

headline: Excellent training, many opportunities for growth, cares about doing the right thing for clients.
pros: They invest in your development and truly care.  You get to talk about the markets and help clients all day.
cons: Very structured schedule, need to be disciplined. Need to want to talk to clients all day, that is the job.

headline: Great way to break into financial career
pros:
- Company culture was diverse
- Employee's enjoyed having fun on and off the job
- Ability to advance quickly in career
cons:
- Weak pay scale 
- Easy to get caught up in corporate politics
- Managerial team who doesn't know how to manage employees or a schedule.

headline: Managed by grownups
pros: Schwab's mission is to be most trusted financial advisor. It achieves this by focusing on making clients happy, combined with a relentless effort to keep employees engaged. Senior leadership is evaluated on employee engagement scores, which has a huge impact on the firm's couture. True idiots tend not to be promoted.
cons: Super-long tenure leads to few openings and very slow career advancement. Expect to wait many years between promotions.

headline: Great place to work
pros: People are smart and talented. I love coming to work every day.
cons: Big company, so many people need to be involved to make decisions: projects move slowly.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: People work in the company are generally very low key and nice. work itself are not too stressful. kind of still keeping old fashion way of doing business.
cons: Upper level are lack of the leadership and direction. Incentive plan changes year by year. They are moving out of the major supporting employee out of San Francisco.

headline: Relationship Specialist
pros: Most of the people you work with are happy to assist you and help you with the day to day tasks, if they have the time.
cons: The benefits aren't the best and you are very limited on your Healthcare options. The pay is not worth at all the amount of work, stress, or responsibility you receive in compensation.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Receive a book of clients and can expand upon them.
cons: Keep expanding the branch network

headline: Participant Services Department
pros: Great company, management is overall supportive, fun, open communication. Great team of coworkers where you feel supported, motivated and encouraged.  Retirement benefits are excellent.  The department itself... not so much.
cons: High level of micromanagement.  There is very little flexibility in employee's schedules. This position is in a very busy and strict call center environment. Employees must adhere to scheduled breaks, lunches, etc.  Vacation approvals are nearly impossible, making it hard for employees in this department to schedule, plan for vacation time, including simple medical appointments. Difficult to get promoted, high level of nepotism.

headline: Awesome Company
pros: Benefits, Environment, Pay, training, Bonuses
cons: Securities industry can be very stressful.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Has been a blue chip San Francisco employer.
cons: Executive management takes the rest of the company granted.  While the top levels the company generous compensate themselves, they are extremely cheap with benefits an salary to the rest of the company.  Company rapidly moving as many San Francisco jobs to Colorado and Arizona or overseas.  Culture is rife with intellectual arrogance and cynicism.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Ethics, values,  very client focused
cons: brand recognition not as high in the east as the west

headline: Long Established
pros: Large company with a variety of opportunities
cons: Less employee focused than advertised. Becoming more like any other corporations verses what they use to be

headline: Great place to Work
pros: Great growth potential and good opportunities and resources to learn and acquire new licenses. People are friendly and good to work with
cons: Have to be willing to relocate and depending on the location, the growth opportunities are not the same. The pay could be a little higher

headline: Sr. Manager
pros: Very little to say here.  For Brokers, you can use Schwab to get trained and licensed and then move on to a competitor as they will pay much better than Schwab.  Benefits are competitive, but nothing special.
cons:
1. Cult like atmosphere
2. Power centers in SF and Denver - no career elsewhere
3. Very political management
4. Left wing politics

headline: Sr. Manager
pros: Wonderful team. New product development and fast paced challenging opportunities
cons: Opportunities to move within the company are limited

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Learn about the business from the ground up
cons: Can't think of anything negative to say. Been here for almost 20 years.

headline: Project Manager
pros: Great On-boarding. Responsive Management. Collaborative teams. Competitive Salary.
cons: Down time between projects. Shifting project priorities.

headline: You have to move up
pros:
The hours are generally tolerable and the benefits are decent. 
Great 401k matching.
30-day paid sabbatical opportunity every 5 years.
cons:
Big company = Big bureaucracy. It's hard to initiate changes are make yourself heard when you're at the bottom of the pyramid.
They claim to be a great place for VETERANS to work -- and they are consistently receiving recognition for it -- but I would be making more money on active duty (even when I factor in bonuses).

headline: Lacking Leadership at the Top
pros: Great benefits and low cost wealth management services
cons: Micro managers concerned for their jobs.  Sell to clients or be threatened. Forced to sell mortgages and annuities now.

headline: Culture and Work Place
pros: Great culture,great workplace environment, common goals and established career plan
cons: Not many. Great place to get experience

headline: CS&S Support
pros: Amazing support staff and constantly able to learn new things to become more knowledgeable in the role
cons: Slow progression.  Great starting job, want something more at stage of life I am in.

headline: Disillusioned
pros: Good salary and benefits, 401K matching.
cons:
Corporate culture went from great to terrible with the ascension of Walt Bettinger and his cronies. It's all about the bottom line. Upper management, from the top down to VP level and some Directors manage up without respect for senior and regular staff.

When I joined, the culture was based upon an equal footing of technology, employee engagement, and the bottom line. Now it's only about revenue.

headline: Once was a great place to work....
pros: Many great people who want to get good work done. Pace, scale and impact of work was fast, big and broad. Dynamic and challenging environment.
cons: Pulling out of San Francisco and California even though this is where they started. Corporate culture has really changed - workers used to be prized and rewarded for their contributions and now they are a commodity to be manipulated for the lowest costs.

headline: Constant Crisis
pros: Cares about the customer.  Can make a decent wage with good benefits.
cons: The company has been pretty much in a holding pattern for several years due to very weak (mostly women) management who rather than innovate and lead, now simply create perpetual crisis in order to substantiate their positions.  In my last meeting with my VP supervisor, i asked what she thought about the then current initiative  Her response was "I don't know because my boss hasn't told me what my opinion is.".  And that pretty much sums up the quality of Sr. Management

headline: Solid company
pros: Good work/life balance. Great training and caring managers. Paid time off of the phones to study for your exams.
cons: Networking is very key to your success at the company and promotions. It's tough being on the phones for 10 hours. Not very easy to take vacation

headline: Intranet Design, Development, and Support
pros: Great place to work for opportunity.
cons: If you are adverse to change, probably not the company for you.

headline: Its ok
pros: Got all the budget to keep things running. Based on the team you may work on latest and greatest.
cons: Less experienced managers handling some of the teams. Very traditional approach although they speak all agile. Less transparency. No visibility beyond your manager.

headline: Trading Services
pros: Good work/life balance. Paycheck to Paycheck life. Company does "really try" to do good for their clients. Great way to START your career. Get to work with lots of talented ppl. If you like providing good service to people with smile, this company is for you!
cons: Moving into wrong direction. Talent is leaving schwab to find a place, where their expertise is respected and utilized. Micro-managed Call center. Sales role disguised in Service centric role. Low pay for work that you do! No added incentives unless you are in Sales role.

headline: Experienced advisors looking to build long-term career should stay away
pros: Good place for young, inexperienced advisors to get licensed and trained.  Schwab encourages their advisors to acquire CFP certification and will pay for it.  Used to have good culture, but no longer the case after Chuck retired.
cons: Pressure cooker environment at branch offices.  Advisors are expected to bring in $5 million net new asset and enroll a couple million of these assets in fee-based platform every quarter, among numerous performance metrics they are expected to deliver.  Management literally treats advisors like little children and everyone is supposed to check-off a long-list of required activities.  Performance is assessed every quarter, and advisors are constantly fearful of losing their jobs if they somehow had a bad year.  The lofty goals ensures that advisors have little time to take care of existing clients, but they are expected to make up the difference if/when existing clients leave.  All the while the advisors are being paid peanuts compared to industry standards, while management continues to cut costs by cutting into advisor and branch manager compensation every single year.  Advisors are also under tremendous pressure to push proprietary investment products such as Windhaven, SMP, etc. that had been performing poorly.  Of the 1,200 or so advisors within the branch network, between 15-20% of the advisors have less than 1 year in tenure.  It is a revolving door and advisors who can't take the high-pressure and high target long-term will leave.  Those who stay are very unhappy but afraid to leave, because Schwab sues pretty much everyone that goes to a competitor.  Even though Schwab seldom wins these lawsuits, they are determined to drag their former advisors through the mud so that these people have little chance of success at the new firm.

headline: Client Service Specialist
pros: Great culture.  Collaborative environment.  Good work life balance.
cons: Limited opportunities for career advancement.

headline: Client Service Specialist - Broker Trainee
pros:
Great way to learn about the markets, team atmosphere, competitive starting pay and great benefits. 

They set you up to pass the series 7 and 63, take the training seriously and you will pass!
cons: Taking 30-50 inbound calls a day can wear you out quickly,  but if you hang in there you can work into more interesting roles.

headline: Ux Architect
pros: Smart co-workers, friendly environment and interesting projects.
cons: Too much politics gets in the way of good product design.

headline: Good place to work depending on management team
pros: Flexibility; Management focuses on engagement; Web based learning opportunities
cons: Systems are outdated; Pay is not up to par with the industry and is not in alignment with responsibilities

headline: Charles Schwab - A Text Book Visionary
pros: Chuck's day to day involvement and clear vision was admirable. Management encouraged risk taking, thinking creatively and collaborating across enterprises.
cons: Dave Pottruck's  careless management decisions cost hundreds of people's jobs.

headline: Charles Schwab - A Text Book Visionary
pros: Chuck's day to day involvement and clear vision was admirable. Management encouraged risk taking, thinking creatively and collaborating across enterprises.
cons: Dave Pottruck's  careless management decisions cost hundreds of people's jobs.

headline: Good
pros: Big company, resources, good money if you sell
cons: Overly conservative, worries too much about optics than what's right for clients

headline: Project Manager
pros:
Great Culture- Everyone is working toward the same goal and is eager to help with any effort. 
Great Benefits- Not only do you get health and compensation benefits, you have access to a vast financial network. As an employee you get free financial consultation in ever step of your finances and a free account!
Great Amenities- Our brand new Denver campus is unbelievable. Three, 5-floor building, ergonomic desks, 3 break rooms per floor, and a café with great food to choose from!
cons: None  that I can think of

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Great opportunity, competitive pay, clients come first, long term potential, great management and room for growth. Easily the best place I have ever worked.
cons: Limited operational assistance and no sales support staff other than operations. Complicated daily employment because advisors spend a lot of time on operational issues.

headline: Good benefits, good people, corporate shenanigans
pros: The company has excellent benefits in terms of health care and retirement plan options. The company offers a rare opportunity for work-life balance with part-time employees being eligible to participate in certain tiers of benefits. The employees in my area were smart, creative, and collegial. Work hours in my area were reasonable, 9-5, without the expectation of taking work home.
cons: Corporate out-of-touchness with employee concerns or disincentivizing legitimate complaints, despite a company-wide 360 review process and employee engagement survey. Employees' job descriptions expanded while pay did not expand proportionally. Payroll and HR were not receptive to legitimate employee concerns about payroll accuracy, pay for performance, or changing terms of employment. Managers did not face the same requirements to be reviewed as their reports, leading to the feeling that reports could not convey constructive feedback about their managers.

headline: Administrative
pros: Fabulous company as a whole. Experienced great culture and learning opportunities among peers. Loved the opportunity to get involved in community outreach.
cons: Location I worked at has shifted gears over the past few years away from team approach and more centered on individuals doing what it takes to get them to the next level.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Atmosphere, 401k match, sales experience
cons: Pay isn't competitive with other financial firms in the area.  95% of Financial Consultants are treated as average while top 5% get 100% of the recognition.

headline: RIA Intern
pros: A lot of opportunities to learn. professional development
cons: Not enough technical projects or assignments

headline: Financial Consultant Academy Participant
pros: Company is dedicated to improve its employees through training and education
cons: Nothing to note as of yet. I think the company truly values putting the clients first

headline: Client Service Associate
pros: Some nice people to work with; good 401k; good internal support from remote call lines; seeminingly good company culture
cons: Micro management; can't be 2 minutes late to work; scheduled breaks and lunches; criticized for  taking bathroom breaks; no mobility; disgrutal financial advisors; no teamwork; no mobility for must stay in a position for 2 years mandatory which don't tell you in the interview.  I was overqualified for the job and wanted to advance.  They post jobs openings outside of  interal company postings.

headline: Sr Registered Representative
pros: Overall culture, treated professionally, variety of job types
cons: Bonus amounts could be greater

headline: Financial consultant
pros: Great brand recognition and clients walk in the door - limited prospecting.  Clients respect the Schwab name
cons: Huge bureaucracy, politics and clawbacks on comp plan.  Branch managers don't manage. Infighting among FC's can be terrible too.

headline: Great former company, headed in wrong direction
pros: Some of the most dedicated professionals and caring people I've ever worked with. True focus on doing what's best for the customer.
cons: Leadership is clearly not committed to staying in San Francisco or promoting from within. Diversity is decreasing. This is now a mid-west company with a mid-west culture and a mid-west looking workforce. A shame given the company's rich history of being a west coast success with diversity and talent across the organization.

headline: Good job but busy
pros: Very busy job, lots of opportunities and learning chances.  Good opportunity to learn.
cons: Can be very fast paced and at times feel disjointed but that is because of the pace of the job.

headline: Strong ethics, clients come first, solid financial services company.
pros: Clients come first, Schwab's core competencies revolve around doing what's right for each client.  Solid suite of investment capabilities for both the novice and sophisticated clients.  Schwab serves the self directed and those that need assets managed.  They do it well. Planning, advice, costs, range of investments are all superior to competition
cons: Practice sizes are too large.  Marketing message is inefficient and vague at best.  If high net worth clients knew about our full range of services, the "full service" firms would lose many clients to Schwab. Our existing client base that are engaged with the branches know what we offer.  But many of these clients want to be left alone.   We need clients that want a trusted, lower cost relationship with higher end wealth management strategies.  Schwab's lack of direction on our capabilities to high net worth clientele makes an FC's job very frustrating and inefficient

headline: Contract Forms Developer
pros: It's a very fun laid back environment. Everyone in the Austin branch was very friendly and it's a nice place to be!
cons: Lots of meetings and not a lot of organization for work. Wish I had been given more notice that my contract was ending.

headline: Fiancial Consultant, CFP
pros: Ethical Sales Practices and great product platform
cons: Lower relative pay for sales

headline: cvrc
pros: Good company go work for.
cons: There are no cons here.

headline: If you get an offer...ask them to double or triple the pay, you will do the work of 2-3 people
pros:
The job itself is very good and rewarding. 
You will work with good people that want to do the right thing.
Pay is ok compared to other jobs in this area.
cons:
Workload - you WILL be doing the work of at least 2-3 people compared to other firms, so your semi -decent pay is actually below average. If you make 100k-150k and do the work of three people Schwab makes out  vs. three people at 75k each. In order to manage it you end up doing what's easier for you vs. what's best for the clients. Attrition is very high for one of the better paying jobs in this location.
  
Ethics - They preach great ethics, the employees and lower managers practice great ethics and are very ethical. Upper management/founder, the San Francisco elite - no ethics or concern for anyone but themselves.

Work environment - 100 people packed in a 50 x100 room in 6X6 cubes with one bathroom. 

Call center/factory - MBA's, CFA's, CFP's: you're just an assembly line factory worker at this place.

headline: Cashiering Dept
pros: Steady job, no micro managing
cons: you are constantly reminded of being a temp, from your badge, to the employee activities that they freely send you emails about but then blatantly say "full time employees only" guess they don't know how to filter recipients

headline: Great Company
pros: Great people and a great company to work for as a contractor or full time.
cons: Bring your own coffee. Get there early to get good parking or you'll be on the roof.

headline: Very micromanaging culture. Not a happy place. Want smiles, look elsewhere.
pros: Paid time off after 5 years. Schwab stands out as the leader in the discount brokerage helm.
cons: Backwards technology. Very cheap cheap cheap culture. They are the Kmart of financial services and pinch pennies like know other. If you want a pen, bring your own.

headline: sdespositov.1
pros: benefits, well-known co., positive working environment
cons: understaffed at times; heavier workload

headline: A company with real integrity
pros: Great company that truly puts clients first.  Well managed
cons: Very little employment upside  for average  worker because of slow growth, virtually none in S.F. because half the jobs are being moved elsewhere.

headline: Good Company Overall
pros: Company supports a good work-life balance.  There is an intense training program when you start this position so it is a good fit for an entry-level position for young graduates wanting to get their foot in the door.
cons: Some of the cons of working there is the bellow industry average starting pay, and little chance of promotion if you are not licensed within your first year of employment.

headline: A great company - not great training department leadership
pros: The client always comes first at Charles Schwab, regardless of where you sit in the firm. I enjoyed knowing that I was working for an ethical, reliable firm with ethical, reliable people in all levels of the organization.
cons: Working in a call center location had the feel of a call center overall. As a financial services company, and one who stayed out of the news during the issues in 2008-2010, Schwab is slow to make internal changes. In the training department, we dealt with old technology and old ideas. Schwab didn't seem to truly "get" training as a whole. Things were great for a while, then went downhill with new leadership over that group.

headline: Associate Financial Consultant
pros:
Great culture, truly do business through clients eyes
Great opportunity to learn, sharpen your financial acumen
Get experience here and move elsewhere to make more money/be happier
cons:
Large group of people who have been there 10+ yrs who just coast and won't adapt to new systems, products, etc
Upper management stiff and not open to new ideas
Very, very conservative in all areas
Pay is mediocre

headline: All Talk, No Action
pros: Time to study for Series 7(restrictions apply, see cons).  Coworkers are fun.  Looks good on resume.  Interesting client(some).
cons: Management makes many promises and rarely delivers.  I was told I would get my tuition reimbursed with the only requirement being the course work must be related to my position.  Total lie. I was denied for MBA course work in Finance.  Schwab does not take their training seriously anymore, they put us back on the phones TWICE during our series 7 training without setting a prior expectation that we may be called back to the phones.  On-going training is always canceled if we have high call volume.  However, you are held responsible when you make a mistake due to the lack of training that was previous canceled, leaving you holding the bag.  That brings me to finger pointing.  Managers are extremely efficient at finger pointing and outsourcing the blame to their brokers who have not received the adequate training due to their poor planning.  You will be REQUIRED and performance will be judged on the leads you submit, you will not receive a commission for the conversions nor will you be told about this in the job ad or onboarding process.  This leaves you taking all of the regulatory risk with none of the upside.

headline: Good place to learn
pros: Great place to learn, lots of opportunity, smart people, ethical, meritocracy, company does what is best for clients, leader in financial services
cons: Executives out of touch, under staffed in many areas, practice sizes to large for advisors and consultants, management more interested in furthering their careers than developing their employees

headline: No Work Life Balance
pros: Working in the Middleware team, I got the chance to work with the best architects and engineers in the industry.  The company use many different technology, so I got the chance to learn a lot in a short amount of time.
cons: There was absolutely no work life balance.  After working at Schwab for 2 years I was exhausted.  The salary was no where near the amount of work I had to put in.

headline: Almost Right
pros: My co-workers were good people and worked well as a team. The hours of 8 am - 4:30 pm were great as well. Upper management tried making it a nice environment by providing lunches, snacks, etc.
cons: Environment is overly corporate and micromanagement is unfortunately encouraged. It's a mindset of "just roll with the punches" and ignore the underlying issues instead of resolving them.

headline: Workplace Review
pros: Many opportunities for professional growth
cons: Work volumes make it hard to cross train

headline: UnderPaid
pros: Get your Licences and move on to earn more money
cons: Call center that's micromanaged that you're under paid for.

headline: Sr. Team Manager
pros: Employees are as much as an asset as Schwab's clients.
cons: Only hire experienced people to do staff/unexperienced jobs

headline: Vice President
pros: Great culture and opportunity to work with colleagues that I respect and who bring passion to their jobs.
cons: Getting more political each year which is changing the culture and trust between employees.

headline: Company decided to eliminate departments moving the job functions to another state with cheaper labor.
pros: Pay was good and time off as well.  Good people doing the best they can.  Some managers are good, if you're lucky.
cons: Too many lay offs, company seems to use lay offs as a way to manage costs.  The departments that are being let go and moved to another state, had nothing wrong with them.  Just another example of a big business letting people go for no good reason and hurting families in the process.

headline: Management Review
pros: Benefits are pretty good when you consider the wellness offers. Work life balance are good as well.
cons: Management  does not care about employees.  Management is deaf to problems/issues in workplace.

headline: Good Conservative Company
pros: Very sharp co workers, decent management, very conservative (never have to wonder if what your told is right or ethical.
cons: Its a large corporation so there is little change, resolute opinions about changing topics, small opportunities for advancement.

headline: NA
pros: Good ethics, good people, fair work life balance
cons: relocating out of San Francisco

headline: Marketing Analytics intern
pros:
-Great team members
-Helpful mentorship activities and opportunities
-Great office location in SF
-Great exposure to leadership
-Decent responsibilities and projects
cons:
-Team didn't always know how to use me and thus sometimes I was under utilized 
-Slow approval process and many meetings and presentations before things were implemented

headline: Good work life balance
pros: Great work life balance (get in by 9am)
cons: Slow progression/development (promotions only happen when the person above you leaves)

headline: Registered Representative
pros: Great opportunities to learn and choose career path.
cons: Incentive plans and performance evaluations are not client-focused.  They say to see it through the client eyes, yet incentives are to push products onto clients whether appropriate or not.

headline: Zero true growth
pros: It is Easy to get hired to entry level positions, company is committed to volunteerism good place to work if you don't mind staying in one role for a long time
cons: Senior leadership is NOT committed to growth of employees.. The company talks a good game but does not deliver. Only commitment is to shareholders and clients

headline: Work Experience
pros: Great company to work for. Lot of talented people work here.
cons: I do not have anything to say as cons. It is a great place to work.

headline: Great place to learn, and to build a career in financial services
pros: You own your future.  Many in management reached their positions after working in many different departments.  You wont get rich here, but there are also opportunities to advance to higher paying sales role if desired.  Great benefits.
cons: You will have a lot to learn, and need to be comfortable not always knowing the answer up front.  Your time usage and productivity are always tracked very closely.  Working in a contact center (using phone, email and sometimes secure message and chat), you will be at your desk/computer for almost all of your time.  Even branch positions are usually at a desk.  You will need a solid plan to keep your health a priority with movement and exercise.   All of these issues can be dealt with.  Just come in with your eyes open and build a plan for success.

headline: Typical Call Center
pros:
Culture
Lots of overtime available
Management is generally very supportive
5% 401k match
Work / Life balance (
cons:
WAY understaffed
Health care is okay
Minimal Raises / Bonuses (75% of employees get the standard 4-6k)
Call center is hard to get out of
Taking 60 phone calls per day is draining
Opinions are scarcley heard

headline: Great experience.
pros: The Schwab culture is really something special. Everyone encourages you to ask questions and learn more, and there is so much opportunity within the company. It is definitely an amazing opportunity for anyone looking to understand the ins and outs of the financial word.
cons: For people looking to work in something that leans more heavily on the creative side, Schwab might not be the place for you.

headline: a great place to work
pros: amazing culture, people.  real commitment to purpose.  all about clients
cons: operate in a regulated industry

headline: IT Director
pros: The people.  Talented, high quality employees dedicated to doing good work.
cons:
The intense risk aversion due to the regulatory environment stifles innovation.
Morale is currently very low.  Many employees no longer feel valued.  The company is losing so much knowledge and experience with its real estate strategy.

headline: VP-FC consultant
pros: Good place to learn...get your series 7 and move on
cons: They're not acting as a fiduciary under the RIA...all advice originates with PCs...FCs are just glorified McDonald's order taker

headline: 1 year in El Paso, TX
pros: The facilitators training everyone in the new El Paso, TX site are pretty friendly and everyone tells you about the Schwab culture that is loved.  It is a very collaborative and communicative environment and everyone is always glad to help out and follow up.
cons: There are some managers that seem like they are driven on metrics and don't want to adopt the culture of challenging the status quo that is asked of them but there is continuous training for managers to adopt it that challenger culture.

headline: Senior Editor
pros: Great people. Culture of appreciation. Opportunity to develop your career. Good benefits.
cons: Lots of silos. Need to be more strategic.

headline: senior staff
pros: good staff, expertise is only there for a few more months
cons: meetings meetings meetings and then nothing gets done. too much procedure, not enough action, projects takes months now to do

headline: Former employee
pros: Company is really try to offer good services to customers.
cons: Cut all IT jobs in San Francisco Bay Area. Moved to Phoenix, Texas and Colorado

headline: branch manager
pros: vision and values consistent with own
cons: none i can think of

headline: Associate Financial Consultant
pros: Worked with excellent professionals, enjoyed challenges set by management to meet quarterly goals, attractive product line therefore easy to sell appropriate products to clients.
cons: Depending on each branch's dynamics, some AFC's required to cover some administrative duties - unfairly measuring everyone equally.

headline: Advisor
pros: Company cares about the client. Do your job and they leave you alone. Decent benefits. 401k. One month sabbatical every five years.
cons: To many to name. Upper management could care less about employees. Just a cog in the machine. Most middle management (and there is a ton) are clueless.

headline: Software Application Engineer
pros:
1. There is a lot of growth for the last few years in the Austin office for the technology side. This growth will continue for the next few years. 
2. Good work/life balance - I have been in the I.T. field as a software test and software engineer for the last 9 to 10 years and this was the first place where I actually only worked only about 40 o 45 hours a week
3. Optional WFH on a once a week basis, you just need to speak to your manager
4. paid month long sabbatical after every 5th year.
cons:
1. The biggest  con - only one choice for Health Insurance and its terrible HSA plan for Texas employees. 
2. Not exactly cutting edge technology,but I guess most large financial companies push stability over cutting edge. 
3. Too much red tape and office politics

headline: Good people and corporate culture.
pros: Good work environment, interactions with other departments generally positive. Get a chance to meet many different kinds of clients.
cons: Mainly sales as a path towards career growth. Client service staff unable to put in overtime unless pre-approved.

headline: Financial Consultant - Vice President
pros: I worked for Charles Schwab in many different roles for over 18 years, the last decade within the Financial Consultant - Vice President role.  Good starting position to gain experience within the financial industry.  Internal lead source to assist with building a book of business.  Ability to switch job roles and have upward mobility within a large company that has national exposure.  Decent benefits, but getting reduced year over year.
cons: Disconnect between management and the brick and mortar staff.  Constant changing of the compensation model and pay cuts every 2 years.  Unequal treatment of Financial Consultants based on subjective analysis.  Increasing conflict of interest regarding compensation of what is being recommended to clients.  Inability to have a long-term career path due to constant changes to compensation, job role and turnover of national leadership.  Poor training on complicated subject matters such as financial planning and annuities.  Inconsistent values and goals between Institutional and retail business lines, sometimes leading to poor customer service and inability to help a client navigate all their options with transparency.  Inability to work for a Registered Investment Advisor that is part of Schwab Advisor Network directly from the Financial Consultant - Vice President role.  Threats of lawsuits pertaining to previous clients contacting you on their own and choosing to continue a working relationship.  Constant pressure to maintain a high level of sales over a career and threat of being fired if a consultant is below the medium of their peers after 6 months.  Inability to customize a personal style of consulting due to pressure to sell equally between all different investment solutions.  Pressure to steer clients into a fee based solution through the low level of compensation of servicing self-directed clients and high annual sales targets for advice solutions.  Requirement to manage between 300-500 client groups and maintain a high level of contact ratio per year, even if client can't be reached.  Poor health benefits and being forced into high deductible plans.

headline: Associate
pros: Schwab has great pay, great leadership, and strives to be the best for the client. I have never worked for a better company. I hope to be with this company for a long time.
cons: I feel that there is no downside with working with Schwab. Schwab has great pay, great leadership, and strives to be the best for the client.

headline: Financial service representative
pros: work and life consideration, when you leave work no strings attached
cons: Underpaid and it seems raises are going to be a small increase also

headline: Operations Cashiering
pros: Great company and corporate culture. Lot's of opportunities as it has lot's of departments to choose from. Health benefits, smoking cessation help, incentives to stay healthy via bonuses to HSA, 401k match, financial advise for employees.
cons: Management can vary from department to department. Some managers are very inflexible, can make life stressful.

headline: Great Company with solid values
pros: Smart management with ethics at the forefront of business decisions
cons: Can be hard to move up

headline: Customer Service
pros: Flexible work schedule.  Family-work balance.  Volunteer services.
cons: Poor management, coworkers don't value their jobs.

headline: Changing, not necessarily for the better
pros: One-month sabbatical for every five years of service. Depending on the department, flexibility or occasional work from home. Solid financial record, even amidst the ups and downs of the last few years.
cons: The culture seems to be shifting, with more to do with less people. The "location strategy" of moving jobs out of San Francisco is making it very hard to get things done as coworkers come and go, even for those not in SF.

headline: Great place to start
pros: Flexible hours and great corporate culture
cons: Sometimes the job gets repetitive

headline: Does not understand UI Engineering
pros: Not many. Their lack of UI knowledge does not create much opportunity for constructive criticism.  Schwab's focus is on a dated hierarchical culture before working as a team to create better technology.
cons:
They have adapted TypeScript and Angular as front end technology. On the surface, the code looks brilliant, well organized, and highly functional. As you peel back the layers, you see many anti-patterns, and a very unprofessional attitude among leads enforce these anti-patterns. Schwab has this hierarchy leadership culture that does not easily permit new knowledge and ideas, especially from contractors. It's a very dated mindset, where as open source technology facilitates communal contributions.

TypeScript is used as an excuse not to learn Angular properly. Inheritance is strongly favored over composition, with deep layers of super classes. This creates, ironically, very tight coupling to dead code and unused functionality, so refactoring and clean up is a major task that takes weeks. 

A lot of money is wasted working in poor architecture.

Angular controllers are +10k lines.

Overuse of Angular logic in html ( ng-if, ng-show, ng-init ), which are well documented anti-patterns. They have no clue how to create and use directives properly to fix these issues. 

Routes are used like services to re-use controllers, where services should be used. Hence the +10k lines in controllers. Where as routes should be used for deep linking, and not necessarily for state management. They have to use variable swaps to keep data "organized". Very fragile code. They clearly do not understand modularization and separation of concerns.

Use of TypeScript causes memory leaks and fragile functionality, where if they learn angular, this would not be an issue as much.

Worst of all, leadership blames "inexperienced" people of poorly written code and bugs, yet they approve every line committed via code reviews. They take no responsibility of work submitted. By this workflow, they should be accountable for everything. In other companies and industries, leadership takes full responsibility in a similar workflow. The lead architect and team leads facilitate this culture of non-collaboration, as if they will lose their job for fear of incompetence if they listen to other people objectively.

When presenting Angular Standards to leadership, you will hear excuses like "all that javascript", "we need to do that in TypeScript", The senior developers facilitate this attitude. If they would adopt angular standards more, and not typescript or outdated web standards, they could reduce their code base by 70% to have a more performant and secure architecture.

As a result, the bugs in their apps are infinite.

headline: Senior Storage Administrator
pros: Sabbatical every 5 years.  5 Months severance if laid off , even if only employed 1 year
cons: It seems that more importance is given to auditors. So many regulations and security prevent you from actually doing your job.   No real recognition or benefits anymore. Work from home is seriously restricted.  Managers do not stand up against senior management and then engineer themselves, Managers seem to want to be technical and make decisions without input from the engineers they manage.  No communication.  Less benefits than a customer.  $1.50 discounts on trade and not allowed to access trading tools that a customer has access to for active traders.  Combines short and long term disability so you get nothing unless you contribute.   $2600 family deductible for insurance.  Not $1 is paid until you pay $2600 even if only 1 person sin your family needs medical coverage.

headline: Not what it seems
pros: there are good people there and good software
cons: not honest about the career development growth

headline: Not what it seems
pros: there are good people there and good software
cons: not honest about the career development growth

headline: If you're in with the in crowd, it's a nice place to work.
pros: Nice facilities, people are generally friendly
cons: Advancement opportunities are slim, and generally reserved for friends of management. Procedures are not very specific and mistakes are usually laid at the door of the lowest ranking employee.

headline: Schwab is an ok company to work for
pros: Nice people, hard working and engaged employees, good benefits
cons: lots of meetings, slow output, limited opportunities for creativity and new ideas, too conservative

headline: No flexibility
pros: Highly motivated and driven employees
cons: Absolutely no flexibility with work hours. Not good for working mothers.

headline: Charles Schwab Review
pros: Good opportunity for growth, great salary
cons: The company is reducing the number of employees in San Francisco so Bay Area opportunities are limited.

headline: National Option Manager
pros: Great latitude to to promote company
cons: Did not discover any cons

headline: Great Company, Great People
pros:
Mature in Agile Process, collaborative atmosphere
Everyone I work with is both kind and brilliant
Leadership takes employee engagement very seriously
Refreshingly innovative
cons: Recruiting process is a little ambiguous. It takes prospective employees a while to get through the system due to lengthy background verification.

headline: OK job if you are part of the in crowd.
pros: Mostly great people to work with and benefits are pretty good. Vacation and sick pay start accruing right away an after 5 years you earn a 1 month paid sabbatical. There is also a stock purchase plan with a 10% discount.
cons: Management has unrealistic expectations about workload and some groups are expected to work many hours of OT while other groups pretty much have a standard 8 hour day. This creates moral problems. Also, management appears to favor the social butterflies over those who just want to come in every day and produce work in an attempt to get out at a decent hour.

headline: overall very positive
pros: good people and good environment
cons: possibly lacking opportunity at given location

headline: Project Manager
pros: This is a great company, with great benefits.
cons: There is limited room for growth within the company

headline: Branch Customer Services
pros: Great environment, managers want you to succeed.
cons: 401k and benefits, complex corporate structure. Before it was employees first, now it's clients first.

headline: Was a great company/culture, not anymore
pros:
Some of the legacy leaders are still great to work with/for
Ok time off policy, employee stock purchase program, volunteer days, new location in Lone Tree is nice.
cons: This used to be a great company to work for. The leadership was top notch and encouraged a positive, collaborative, accountable work environment but that has all changed. New executive leadership in Investor Services have very different views on how employees should be treated and their initiatives are driving great performers out the door in droves. By the time Walt realizes that their "new ideas" are shifting the once great culture that Chuck worked so hard to establish into a fear based system of politics and back-stabbing, it will be too late. My advice to job applicants is to look elsewhere. There are plenty of companies in this industry who will pay fairly and offer a more positive work environment that will allow you to flourish and succeed without fearing for your job or when the next hammer will drop.

headline: Great place to work
pros: great place for career growth and professional development opportunities, very collaborative work environment
cons: raises based mostly on business results, not personal performance, and bonus based on corporate earnings, not personal performance

headline: Summer Intern
pros: Very friendly people. Lots of collaboration with upper management.
cons: nothing I can think of

headline: Associate financial professional
pros: 401k, salary, time off, bonuses
cons: Work/life balance, work is life

headline: Once was a great company...not so much anymore
pros: Company has a strong focus on putting the client first. Broad spectrum of financial services and products available.The people who work there are generally nice.
cons:
Used to be an innovative leader in the Financial Services industry, now not so much.
Culture and values have eroded over the years. 
Work environment in SF is depressed and disfunctional.

headline: So much potential... Unrealized
pros:
Great brand.  Unbelievable commitment to doing the right thing among client facing staff.  Generally very polite, nice people.  

Particularly in headquarters, if you get satisfaction from doing what you're told and being busy regardless of the business impact, Schwab might be the place for you.  Especially if senior people find you personally relatable.
cons:
Patronage model among upper management, starting at the top.  The higher up you go, the less important competence is as a job requirement.   Loyalty to your patron (not necessarily to Schwab) is critical.  And it's important for your patron to easily identify with you culturally.  Hint: the more you find the San Francisco Bay Area to be a cultural fit for you, the less likely you will be culturally relatable for top management.  

Creativity or even brilliance isn't a source of distinction and a basis for advancement.  It's more like an irrelevant curiosity - like being left-handed.

headline: Complete and Total Disarray
pros: Very nice, new buildings and office space in Lone Tree, CO.
cons:
-IT is a total disaster and the transition of employees and/or jobs from San Francisco to Denver is being handled extremely poorly.
-Lots of animosity between San Francisco group and Denver group with toxic environment between management.
-Struggling to properly define jobs, roles and responsibilities...high number of newer employees have no idea what their responsbilities are.
-Onboarding process is the worst I've ever experienced.
-Unclear reporting lines between managers and differing opinions on subordinate roles and responsibilities.

headline: Participant Services
pros: Opportunities for advancement, good work life balance
cons: nothing I can think of

headline: Charles Schwab
pros: Smart people.  Month-long sabbaticals every 5 years.
cons: Poor insurance coverage options, loyalty unrewarded

headline: Great Company
pros: Great company, very structured so there is no confusion on what is expected. They care about their employees and employee retention. Lots of opportunity to explore within the company.
cons: Since they are so structured there isn't much room for negotiation or flexibility. Not much wiggle room on salaries or bonuses and very repetitive work structure.

headline: Long time there
pros: The company management was great.  The charity portion of the company is awesome.  The work was great.
cons: The management changed within the call center changed and that brought on a whole new dynamic that was toxic and un-productive to you unless you were on the inside of the decision making process.

headline: Vp Technology
pros: Strong client focus, great compensation
cons: Limited work from home options

headline: Operations Specialist
pros: Good benefits. Sabbatical every 5 years is great. 401(k) match. Work/Life balance. Wellness support.
cons: Pay is part of total benefits package, therefore salary increases have not bee great in the past 6 years or so. Decision process and execution is very slow. Very little happens quickly.

headline: Broker
pros: Good culture, intelligent and solid team members.
cons: If you start on the phones you will die there.  This is a good position to learn about the industry and get your feet wet if you are right out of college.  Remember the goal is to make it to a front-office position

headline: Great Company, Bad Decision to Leave Bay Area
pros:
Excellent people dedicated to their work
Generous compensation, equity, benefits
Superb work-life balance
Managers care about their staff
cons:
Bad choice to vacate San Francisco, I fear the backlash for this company
A bit scatter-brained and too reactive
Lacks adherence to their own processes

headline: Portfolio Consultant
pros: Many career options at this company.
cons: Not any cons come to mind.

headline: Broker
pros: Seemingly endless possibilities for those interested in sales
cons: Very limited possibilities for those not interested in sales

headline: Risk Analyst
pros: Very structured job with upbeat people. Very easy to transfer between positions to find something you like. Great job security at a company with a rising stock.
cons: Middle management had zero capabilities to foresee work capacity and to hire accordingly so mandatory OT  was put in place due to the management unable to hire replacements in a timely manner

headline: Management is less experienced than staff
pros: Great live-work balance, but it comes at price... Low salaries.
cons: Promotions are politically based and often the less qualified applicants get the job. Staff knows A LOT more than management.

headline: manager
pros: Client oriented-- not there to push inappropriate investments on people to generate commissions.
cons: Upper management constantly pushing improvements and projects back 2 or 3 quarters, in often shortsighted attempts to make current quarterly earnings look better.

headline: Not what it was..
pros: Great people, great corporate job if you're looking to be home in time for dinner but that comes with the downside of no advancement opportunities.
cons: Conservative approach to business, not very innovative (although senior management thinks they are) and not willing to try new things.  Recent products have proven to be self serving.  Very structured and corporate.  It feels as though the brand lost it way from Chucks original vision.

headline: Sr Staff
pros:
- Excellent working Environment
- Very flexible working hours
- WFH options
- Great Managers, they work with you through any issues you have
- If you want to change the team, they will work with you for same.
cons:
- Comparatively less salary with respect to industry stds
- Medical - Only HSA available. Not very reasonable.

headline: Toxic
pros: Good benefits, good location in SF, can be interesting work.
cons: Fear driven toxic culture.  Lots of incompetence.

headline: Schwab A-Okay
pros: Excellent culture, nice campus, and good benefits
cons: Changing times for wire brokerages in the face of industry and technology shift

headline: Lack of internal promotion and lower than average pay
pros: One of the benefits of Schwab is work life balance and 4 week paid sabbatical every 5 years. Company culture is a positive environment and one of the strongest assets in attracting talent.
cons: Company morale in SF is at an all time low since it has publicly disclosed a downsize presence in SF. Pay is average, however it cannot compete with other financial services firm and neighboring technology companies like Salesforce. There is no career growth and lack of internal promotion which causes employees to look for other opportunities. I do not recommend applying for a job in San Francisco, however Denver and Austin have more growth potential.

headline: Great Enviorment
pros: Great people, great culture, stress free place to work.
cons: lower end of average pay compared to the industry.

headline: Benefits are a Joke
pros: I never plan on losing my job. They have low standards
cons: Benefits are bad. The 401k match is terrible. Benefits are expensive

headline: Great company - Taking calls is bearable
pros: 401k is good. Compensation is middle of road. Management is decent.
cons: If you are on the general customer service line - very very slammed. Terrible system used to track employees on the phone

headline: Registered Representative
pros: Great training and internal promotion opportunities.
cons: I wished that more statistical analysis went into their evaluation of employees performance.

headline: Registered Representative
pros: Great training and internal promotion opportunities.
cons: I wished that more statistical analysis went into their evaluation of employees performance.

headline: Institutional Trader
pros:
Intelligent, hardworking co-workers
Freedom to pursue projects
Fair industry pay
Full Medical benefits
Opportunity for advancement
cons:
Very bureaucratic
Tons of efficiencies and to done
Large work loads
(recently) high turnover and resignation rate among employees
Little ability to renegotiate raises and salaries.

headline: Customer Service at Schwab
pros: Schwab gives very intense trainings.  Will give you training so that you can pass your Series 7 and 63 licensing. Environment is very positive and competitive.
cons: Shifts. Most schedules are 10 hours shifts.  No direct way of getting a promotion unless trying to change positions. Works on team concept but you have no time to interact with co-workers unless thru instant message or outside of work.

headline: Client service manager
pros: Stable company, been around for a long time
cons: Closed-minded leadership, no flexibility on hours or location

headline: Great place for motivated employees to build a career.
pros: If you are motivated and willing to go above and beyond, you can build your career into whatever you want it to be.  There are vast opportunities in a variety of different fields within Schwab, and everyone there is willing to help you build your career.
cons: Schwab is a conservative firm, so pay and promotions may take a little longer to fall in place if you don't really pursue that next step.

headline: Looking elsewhere
pros: Great benefits and incentives. Paid holidays, and some departments get weekends off.
cons: Extremely low pay. So low that some people actually have a part time job on the side. Some people get started at 24k... with college degrees! Not a livable wage.

headline: Excellent Culture
pros: Schwab is a company that bends over backwards to empower their employees to delight clients and to allow their employees the opportunity to grow personally and professionally.  I've never seen an environment so dedicated to doing right by the customer before doing well financially, however I think that singular focus on the customer is what allows them to do well on the Street,
cons: Well they spend a fortune on training, base salaries could be more competitive.  Other than that its a great place to work.

headline: Great employer
pros: Great culture, fantastic training and vast promotion potential
cons: No cons that I would consider unique. Standard corporate slow motion

headline: Sr. Associate Retirement, Small Business & Trust and Estate Planning
pros: Strong solid financial company. Annual, quarterly bonus opportunities
cons: Low overall base salary compared to the industry. Management plays favorite. Culture change is needed

headline: Good place to work
pros: Great employees, great clients for the most part.  Good salary and benefits.
cons: Company became very political in the past few years.  Good people were demoted or asked to leave. Company has become much more bureaucratic than it used to be. Death by meeting.

headline: Manager
pros: Dynamic work environment.  They welcome creativity and your contribution.  Ethical foundation with clients best interest in mind.  Reward you for hard work and individual contributions.
cons: Health coverage is very expensive.

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Flexible work environment and strong internal communication.
cons: Salaries could be more competitive with similar job descriptions at other firms.

headline: Take your talent elsewhere!!!
pros: Pay and benefits in exchange for work performed. Some colleagues who have a very good attitude. Its actually my team members that have gotten me through this oppressive enviornment. Good teams but bad managers.
cons:
As a few folks have stated the schedules ARE inflexible. I asked my manager for a more flexible schedule and was told no because only the favorites who have been with the company for years can choose the schedule they want. 

When I applied for the job, the job description advertised the bonus as between 2k and 5k per year. However, after I was hired, the offer letter said 2k to 4k per year (so they changed the top number after I was reeled in). In actuality its 500 per quarter less taxes, which comes out to 2k per year minus taxes. 

The productivity system they measure you by is not accurate and employees skew the numbers after learning how to manipulate the system. This causes the ones who are processing correctly to have to work even harder to make the numbers. The managers are aware of this but they ignore it. 

As some others have stated in their reviews, your success with this company and whether or not you like your job depends on if your manager likes you. If your manager does not like you, they are given the leeway to make your work life a living hell. 

During any one on one's with your manager the manager treats you like you are a patient and he or she is a Psychologist. Allow me to explain. The manager has a note pad and writes down any ambiguous statements that you make that can be taken negatively and then uses these statements against you. Furthermore, if you have any type of nervous physical habits they write that down on their pad and then "provide feedback" on this and classify it as negative behavior. Still further, management has a system where they even give you fake feedback to put you on the defense and then when you deny the behavior they say you are not accepting feedback. So its a lose lose situation for the employee. In a nutshell, management is given the leeway by the company to mistreat employees as I have described and the employees have no recourse. They have a human resources prop put in place but thats about it. So my advice is, if you do decide to work here, be phony to survive. Pretend to like your manager even if you don't. If one of your colleagues is not treating you right or is acting inappropriately - just ignore it. Otherwise, if you report it, it is used against you and they make you out to be the odd person out. Also, make sure you document every interaction from your one on ones with your manager and any incidents that take place. That way if you are thrown under the bus, you can at least try and cover your butt.

Management and upper-management all know each other very well and have worked together for years. This compromises any integrity, especially regarding employee treatment.

headline: Broker
pros: Good people experience Great people
cons: More training and time spent with employees

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Leader in the industry and most transparent to clients
cons: Compensation plan isn't understandable and reports are often wrong

headline: Overall Review
pros:
healthy work environment
client's needs come first

lack of career advancement in some areas
low pay

headline: Used to be great!
pros: It is a job, not a career
cons: Compensation is not the best

headline: flexible corporate career
pros: Flexible, reasonable steady career working for a proven company.
cons: Culture varies from one business line to the next. You need to work for the right people.

headline: Top notch Company
pros: Work Life balance. Competitive comp.
cons: Health benefits significantly downgraded with only high deductible HSA plan available

headline: Call center? Yes
pros: Colleagues all have the same outlook as me
cons: Where to start? You are micromanaged to the hilt.  Numbers numbers numbers are measured.  How long was your call (average handle time), how long was your wrap up of your calls, how many calls did you take, how closely did you adhere to your schedule,  how much time did you spend during the day not taking calls.  Don't even think about taking a call if it's going to go into your break or lunch as this will count against your adherencee.  Oh and if you want to really have good customer service and need to call a client back per their request you better make it a quick call because this will count against you as you are supposed to adhere to your schedule and an outbound call is the same as not being on the phones when you're supposed to  be.  You are on the phones all day long with one 30 minure team meeting a week.  We get training time scheduled every week but we never get to take it because we always get alerted out meaning there are too many calls waiting to be answered.  The job is grueling and tedious.  Call after call after call after call.  You can never take a breather otherwise your manager will bring it up in your team meeting going over PERF ( performance numbers).  My advice is if you don't want to be in a micromanaged environment where every thing you do is measured by some metric (metrics that your $500 quarterly bonus depends on) look somewhere else like the Gap or Taco Bell. And you're expected to put in leads for new assets that you uncover, leads that you have to hand off to the advice or sales teams that make over 6 figures simply by taking your leads and converting them.  Oh and leads are required.  The more you have the better living you make for the sales team.  You don't get paid squat on them even if you do all the leg work to uncover them.  Think twice about interviewing for a CSR role, it's not worth the agony

headline: Depends on what you are looking for
pros:
1. Great Work/Life balance
2. Good pay for workload
cons:
1. Like most young companies - big, but has a lot of growing up to do.
2. Very paternal management culture style.
3. Very little advancement opportunities - (good and bad of employees with long tenure). Bad being that senior positions are generally filled by employee attrition rather than talent.
4. Almost non-existent field training opportunities - management practically discourages.
5. Generally working remote is not an option.
6. Company is not as innovative as they market - a customer may get a cool new investment tool, but an employee is probably going to be running on an xp machine.

headline: I'm Pretty Happy
pros: Wide range of jobs. Tons of areas for growth and advancement. The sky is the limit.
cons: There is always going to be something to complain about. Schwab is a great company but you have to be ok with corporate America.

headline: Terrible company
pros: co workers are great to work with
cons: Managers are cutthroat. You don't get paid nearly for all the work that you do. You have to ask to use the bathroom. 30 min lunch for 11 hour days

headline: Senior Manager
pros: People are passionate about their work.  The company is genuine about helping clients succeed in their financial life.  Benefits are generally ok.  Pretty standard for a financial company.  Don't compare it to a tech start-up, you'll be disappointed.  The sabbatical is definitely a plus that you don't typically see elsewhere.  401k match is good.
cons: Innovation is slow, especially around tech.  As much as the company would like to be innovative, changing priorities and management makes it difficult to move the needle.  If you don't like working in a geo-located matrix style team, then this is not the place for you.  Advancement is limited.  They encourage you to look lateral instead.

headline: Profits Before People
pros: Has one of the best infrastructures in the business. The primary focus is on Security and the customer. Individual staff members are outstanding and very talented.
cons: One of the most uncomfortably restrictive environments that I have worked in. HR does not support staff, only management. Pay is low, benefits are mediocre at best. Reorganizations run rampant and are very disruptive. Too many contract and off-shore positions mean valuable and talented employees are overlooked and often have to leave in the middle of projects. Too many rules, regulations and policies in regards to staff are restrictive and devalue talented employees. People do not matter to this organization on any level.

headline: Good but not great
pros: This is a solid conservative company with great benefits.  Like any other large corporation your division and manager can make or break the experience. I found that most people in the company were willing to help you on projects even if they had never met you before. I was impressed with how well different divisions worked together considering how large the company is. I think it was as good as it could be given all of the unavoidable cons.
cons: Like any corporation they are very process oriented and centralized. It can take a long time to get things done because of the bureaucracy to be dealt with. It can be difficult to break out of your current job role to try new things. Being a financial services company they are focused on security and they are highly regulated. This adds to the bureaucratic sluggishness.

headline: Not a bad place to work, just needs to stop changing so frequently
pros: Great people, career growth, challenging opportunities
cons: Instability in various organizations. Hard to move forward amongst multiple re-orgs throughout the year.

headline: Positive Place to Work
pros: A real sense of community among the employees. Interesting and diverse group of people who believe in doing an excellent job.
cons: Sometimes management isn't nearly as transparent as they believe they are when sharing the aim and direction of the company.

headline: Great First Job in Financial Services
pros:
decent benefits,
great people,
great place to start in the industry,
atmosphere can be fun,
flexible with work and life balance.
cons:
not focused on trading at all,
lower pay than street average,
rigid bureaucracy,
upward mobility difficult,
disconnected management.

headline: Manager
pros: Engaged employees, opportunity for growth
cons: Outdated technology, long hours

headline: Summer Intern - great experience
pros: Great culture, very driven and helpful peers.
cons: Large corporation, lots of reshuffling

headline: operations
pros: great company to work for. Really feels like your apart of something bigger.
cons: some idea's don't filter down to the people that will actually be handing the issues. could have  better communication.

headline: Managed out
pros: The the people at the peer level and not management level were great lots of talent,.
cons: Over 50 so got managed out.

headline: Good Company
pros: Good company with good ethics, positive work environment.
cons: Long hours on the phone.

headline: A lot to learn and absorb in a short period of time
pros: Nice culture with genuine values to do the right thing and embrace integrity on all levels
cons: Too many complex resources to learn in a limited time.  Managers need to engage on a much more active level instead of from behind a wall

headline: probably best company in lousy, corrupt industry
pros: Awesome co-workers! Decent benefits (used to be better) and pay..Very good work/life balance.
cons: The industry itself is corrupt on a systemic level so even though Schwab is a good, honest company and most of its employees are too, the system it operates in is NOT. That's a big problem for me. I'm making plans to leave the business altogether. Other negatives is you feel like a little cog in a wheel, a cog like any other..no individuality, no real freedom to advise clients how you see fit. Everyone looks the same, dresses the same, acts the same. BORING! High level of micromanaging and surveillance too.

headline: Retirement Plan Specialist
pros: The majority of Schwab Employees go above and beyond to create an exceptional client experience. I always could count on my coworkers to assist me when I was in need of assistance. We were like a family.
cons: My manager was not able to assist me with specific client accounts or how to navigate the system. I would reach out for a Senior Represenative since they had more knowledge than management.  Trainings constantly got canceled due to not enough coverage to handle calls. Mandatory over time, with commonly same day notice.

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Great people to work with.  Very supportive and  dedicated.
cons: Management plays favoritism and discrimination is very obvious.

headline: worst job in my life
pros: used to have good benefits
cons: Felt like a wage slave with no incentive to move forward. Easy to get lost in the crowd. No one notices you as an individual. Youth oriented environment. They tolerate seniority. This company has screwed over many talented people.

headline: Great company
pros: Okay Pay, great benefits, great atmosphere

headline: Director

headline: Old and New work differences
