headline: Great for entry level
pros: Good benefits (vacation time, sick time, good health benefits). Good salary. Very good image for clients and future employers. Great traning
cons: Very little input into workflow even if you can improve it. New employees usually gets assigned to late shifts. Opportunity to move to other departments, but it is mostly horizontal

headline: Too nice, too slow
pros:
Great work-life balance.
People are supportive and non-competitive.
Great for those looking for non-challenging long-term career.
Nice perks.
cons:
Passive-aggressive behaviors; no one says "no";
IT infrastructure is a mess and Mac support is lacking. What is this, 2004?
Marketing is not integrated and way behind the curve in terms of modern, social web.
Inadequate support for user-centered design practices.
Takes forever to get anything done because of so many layers and departments.

headline: Get In, Get Experience, Get Out
pros: Company with big pockets that doesn't think twice about investing in latest and greatest.  If you want to work with best tools and not be hindered this is a good place.
cons: Middle and upper middle management disconnected from employees.  Definite boys (and girls for that matter) club in effect.  You can't have a career there without some serious butt kissing and if you should happen to question the wrong person about something you are stuck forever.  Will not hesitate to drive your family life to the point of divorce with overtime.

headline: Call center work, interesting but also a grind.
pros: Lots of training provided to help you acquire, learn and advance your skills and knowledge.  Decent benefits, most of the people on your team are caring, hard working individuals.
cons: You have to like being on the phone all day long.  50 - 100 calls per shift is average.  Either you master their information retrieval software program or the frustration level can climb through the roof.  Schwab needs to convert their trading software to a Windows platform; in its current form it's not intuitive and increases the possibility for brokers to make mistakes.

headline: Process rules unless it gets in the way
pros:
They are concerned about their employees financial well being. They provide you all types of opportunities and access to staff for planning your financial well being. They have full time employees dedicated to doing nothing but help other employees with their investments. After all, that is the business that they are in. The division in which I worked was flexible with your work schedule as long as you were getting the job done. Work from home was available as was working from another branch office if you needed to be in another city. 

In addition to the vacation and other benefits, every 5 years of employment you earn an 4 week sabbatical. There are some people that have worked there for 20+ years.

I worked in the software development division and can't speak much for the areas that are specifically financial in nature.
cons:
They are federally regulated so everything is tightly controlled. Do not expect to be able to check your Facebook page or personal email while in the office.

They have people that have worked there for 20+ years and a large number in the 10+ range. While this provides great continuity for the company, it also makes it difficult for new employees to "become one of the family". A new employee with great ideas is going to be hard pressed to get those ideas visible to anyone that will listen. There is very much an "old boys/girls" network at the top.

The longevity issue has also made the organization very top heavy. New or entry level employees will find it difficult to advance through the career ladder when you have other people above you that have been there for 10-20 years.

headline: Registered Representative
pros: They pay for your license and friendly company.  The managers and other co workers are willing to help new employees that have troubles.
cons: Very high call volumes on the phone.  No down time at all.  Lower base pay and down economy keeps bonuses low.

headline: Good Benefits, pay a little low
pros: Good benefits (vacation time, sick time, good health benefits), a lot of opportunities in other departments, time off for volunteering, good work life balance
cons: Pay is a little low.  Employee moral was a little low (but it was during the big downturn in the market).  Although there is definitely opportunity to move to other departments, most of the moves are lateral.  There isn't a lot of room for upward advancement.

headline: Schwab is Employee and Client Focused
pros: Charles Schwab tries to balance employee needs and desires with client needs and desires in order to have the perfect mix of happy sales people and happy clients using valuable services. For example, employees have tremendous health insurance benefits, great 401k plan that is 100% vested from day one, sabbaticals of 4 weeks after 5 years service, time off for volunteer work, etc.  In addition, Schwab tries to provide a balance for all clients from free services to fee based services as well as one on one time with clients, and customizable solutions.
cons: Sometimes there is too much focus on one area of opportunity or growth and other areas are neglected and/or seized upon by the competition.

headline: Good People and Good Benefits But Pay and Environment Really Varies by Department
pros:
- On the whole, you work with a lot of good people who know what they are doing
- Great benefits and a company that goes out of their way to try and help their employee's fulfill  their financial and personal health goals.
- Overall company's objectives and goals are something I can get behind and feel good about.
- Company provides many in-house training opportunities.
cons:
- Lots of people who stay for a very long time, which can stagnate progress (resistance to change).
- Legally conservative company with lots of red tape that does a decent job to protect the brand but also slows progress and change
- Pay is average to below average compared to others in industry in area. HR is not very creative at coming up with ways to recognize employees for their contributions.
- To move up, you have to change departments. Difficult to grow within.

headline: Active Trader Overlay
pros: Great way to learn the markets and analyze trading strategies.
cons: Low Pay, this is a company that will teach you all that you want to learn, but dont expect to eat lobster while you learn.

headline: Good place to get lisicened and learn trading
pros: Flexible shifts, get your series 7
cons: Call center, not a lot of opportunities for personal interactions with clients

headline: Challenge and opportunities for those who like to work hard
pros: People are the really knowledgeable and support each other
cons: The bar for performance seems to be continuously raised

headline: It is a good place to work.
pros: High quality people to work with and work for.  Corporate culture is great because people buy in and work towards making everyone financially fit.  Highly engaged employees that care about what they do.  Good leaders for the most part.  Good development programs.
cons: Performance rankings were clearly a forced bell curve.  In some BUs middle management is suspect.  It is bad when you speak with senior leaders more than you speak with your director or VP.  Unable to advance professionally in certain business units unless you move, even if the job could be done remotely.  Some middle management suffering from individual genius disease.  Some group think issues in middle management.

headline: Charles Schwab is a great place to work.
pros: Charles Schwab has a great culture.
cons: The bulk of the opportunities are usually in a just a few metro areas.

headline: Quality company
pros: Competitive salaries in my field. Coworkers are nice people who care about their work and our clients. Cream rises to the top in a way that seems fair from my perspective (as someone who is in a fairly limited role in terms of mobility, by choice). Sabbatical every 5 years is the best benefit ever. You get out of the company as much as or as little as you give.
cons: I understand call center jobs can be frustrating but I'm on the technology side. Things can move slowly due to the size of the company, regulatory requirements, and so forth. The acquisitions process is nightmarish, so if you need things that the rest of the herd doesn't in order to do your job, get ready for red tape.

headline: Generally positive
pros: Great culture, opportunity for career advancement, fast paced environment, numerous learning opportunities.
cons: Some employees are disengaged, and are there only to earn a paycheck.  Compensation not great for front line employees, which can be a demotivator.

headline: Good job, poor career
pros:
Robust client base
Good technology
Excellent name recognition
Leader in its space
cons:
a deep disconnect between management's vision and a reality "on the ground"
lack of consistent direction within company
business model/vision changes constantly making it difficult to manage client's expectations
strong pressure to conform 
may hurt future career in the industry

headline: Great people to work with.  But lack upward mobility opportunities.
pros: The people at Schwab are great to work with.  The company has a desire to train, develop, and help employees to do their best.  The benefits are decent within this industry.  Work / life balance is good.  The additional compensation with annual bonuses and a sabbatical every 5 years is a great perk.
cons: One can hit the growth ceiling pretty quickly.  Though there's opportunities for lateral moves, upward mobility is lacking...and not due to one's lack of drive or performance.  Also, reorgs are frequent (every couple of years), which slows down productivity.

headline: Not the best, but not the worst
pros: Interesting projects, decent pay, work from home opportunities, access to employee financial wellness programs
cons:
The corporate culture needs to be improved.  I've witnessed too much backstabbing, talking behind others' backs, undermining and bullying in this workplace.  

Also, your opportunities are limited if you're in a support function outside of San Francisco.  Other companies I've worked for have encouraged talent in all locations, but Schwab tends to want to keep all the higher level positions in its headquarters even though great talent exists elsewhere.

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Great compensation, great benefits, excellent values and respect for the employee.
cons: Challenging work/life balance at Director level and above.

headline: Good Company, but can improve.
pros:
-I work with very smart people that I actually like, in fact, in 2.5 years I have not met 1 person at Schwab whom I disliked. Not something I've ever been able to say.
-I think that management really cares about the employees. There is an Employee Appreciation Week. I've never heard of this anywhere else.
-Board members and upper management actually goes into the branches and call centers to see what's going on. I've actually met the Executive Vice President over my department.
-If you are willing to work hard and network and reach out to people that can help you, you can advance to higher positions. If you don't, then you will probably stay in the same position for years.
cons:
-Pay could be much better.
-Branch reps and FC's are not held to the same standards that brokers in the call centers are, yet are almost always paid more. It seems like I am often apologizing for an FC that doesn't return a phone call or processes a client's paperwork slowly. Most of the time brokers in the call centers place the FC's trades because we work on a recorded line. Therefore some FC's don't seem to know a lot about trading.

headline: Good company depending on department and position
pros:
good benefits and salary
interesting projects
cons:
excessive reorgs stall productivity
branch sales goals work against schwab adviser services (direct competition)

headline: A good company that could be great
pros: Great compensation, good benefits, opportunities to learn new technologies
cons:
Promotions are nearly non-existent and too much politics internally
More transparency to employees needed

headline: A place that supports career growth
pros:
In multiple job functions a sabbatical after 5 ears of employment.
Multiple locations and are open to internal transfers.
cons:
Not the highest py in the industry.
Culture is different in the multiple location across the country.

headline: Excellent company to intern for and gain real world business experience
pros: Flexible in job description - was able to "shadow" many different department
cons: Abundance of rules and regulations - comes with the territory though

headline: My experience was fine but it is definitely a little more stuffy compared to your normal commercial bank
pros: It is a well known and respected name in the Financial Industry.  They have the technology for you to work from home if an emergency comes up although they prefer you to be in the office. Standard starting time for employees is between 8:30 and 9:00.
cons: The downside is that the pay is generally lower compared to the market. In order to make the money that you are use to making, shot for a higher titled position than normal. From what I've been told by coworkers, get your desired salary when you first start because promotions are minimal.

headline: The enthusiasm in working for Stech is long gone
pros: The company still offers above average salaries, decent benefits package, and paid sabbatical leave every 5 years.  Very good and skilled IT people and some of the best co-workers to be found anywhere.
cons: Terrible management.  Company is run by bean counters now and there no vision for new technology.  Penny pinching has gone to the extreme and has downsized.  Schwab is also letting its older workers go, and their years of knowledge, and bringing in younger workers out of tech school as a way to cut salaries.

headline: A good place to make a pay check
pros: Local teams and branches work very well together
cons: Very political and favored towards corporate employees - not so much in the branches

headline: Little or no strategic planning. Everything is a fire drill!
pros: Company has a good reputation with smart leaders
cons: Little or no strategic planning. Everything is a fire drill!

headline: It was a long run, but direction has changed and politics and bullying have won...I'm gone
pros:
great products and services
wonderful clients
fantastic peers
cons:
Lost its direction
Management is top heavy and deaf to what we are saying
If you disagree with the direction; keep your mouth shut. Get rid of longer term employees because your manager said so. 
Popular? This is the firm for you...if you have an opinion, go somewhere else.

headline: Fair practices.  Great place to learn and grow.
pros: Paid time to study for licenses.  You learn a ton about the business.
cons: Call center environment.  Most of the financial recognition goes to the top five percent of performers.

headline: No advancement, poor pay, inbound calls forever
pros:
- will get time to study for 7 and 63 license as paid time.
- Schwab does a decent amount of training
cons:
- nothing but inbound calls. Any promotion, which will be purely horizontal, will be taking inbound phone calls in another cubicle town.
- want to be a manager? So does the other literally 350 people aiming for 12 spots.
- training is very superficial. It is on how to do things the "schwab way" and not how to actually help advanced traders.
- Managers have little ability to lead team.
- entire value to company will be determined on if you can get clients to click on certain parts of the website, regardless how you do it.
- pay is average and increases are CAPPED at 2 percent.

Get you 7 and 63 here and post your resume on Monster to make 10k somewhere else.

headline: No advancement, poor pay, inbound calls forever
pros:
- will get time to study for 7 and 63 license as paid time.
- Schwab does a decent amount of training
cons:
- nothing but inbound calls. Any promotion, which will be purely horizontal, will be taking inbound phone calls in another cubicle town.
- want to be a manager? So does the other literally 350 people aiming for 12 spots.
- training is very superficial. It is on how to do things the "schwab way" and not how to actually help advanced traders.
- Managers have little ability to lead team.
- entire value to company will be determined on if you can get clients to click on certain parts of the website, regardless how you do it.
- pay is average and increases are CAPPED at 2 percent.

Get you 7 and 63 here and post your resume on Monster to make 10k somewhere else.

headline: My experience at Schwab has been fine.
pros: Fundamentally, and relative to it's peers, Schwab is an ethical company with sound corporate values and a sincere commitment to its customers and shareholders.
cons: It is a tough place to get promoted, even when doing good work, or to develop or progress in a career.

headline: Very structured work place with a corporate feel.
pros: Great technology and back office support.  Great products and value to clients.  Brokers are empowered to make decisions to satisfy clients.
cons: Doesn't seem to value independent / creative thinking.  Because Schwab is such a big company, in order to make things scalable, they need/try to control a little too much.

headline: Schwab has been a great place to grow -- I'm no longer sure it's the right place to stay.
pros:
- Stability
- Benefits
- The People
- Commitment to Development
- Commitment to Clients
- Commitment to Improve Employee Engagement
- The Location in SF / Facilities
cons:
- Collaboration to a fault / too much effort to get buy-in from everyone to be nice and keep partners happy
- Lack of Career Development Opportunities
- Limited Bonus Potential for Less than Top Performers
- Culture has been lacking a soul for some time
- Adoption of cutting edge technology feels very slow
- Lackluster stock performance
- Questionable ability for middle managers to effectively manage their people, especially average performers

headline: Had a great time working with some very professional and nice people.
pros: I have been a technical contractor at Schwab in San Francisco several times over the years and have always (well, almost always) had a great time working with the staff and managers there.  think they must screen for "nice" in the hiring process.
cons: As a contractor I had no complaints.  The employees sometimes grumble about the annual 2% pay raises.  You need to leave Schwab to get a raise they say.

headline: Overall positive but advancement is frustrating
pros: They care about their employees
cons: They disguise horizontal movement as advancement.

headline: Great opportunity to Learn and Grow
pros: Great culture and really feel like people care.  Things change often, so if you're unhappy with the current situation, sit tight because change is coming.  Training and career development is a top priority.  Very ethical and conservative when it comes to making business decisions. Opportunities to volunteer and give back to the community.  Stenghts based environment.
cons: If you're not in the corporate office opportunities and compensation seem to be slow coming.  Schwab compensates outside applicants with less experience more than high performing tenured employees promoted internally.  There is a lot of talk about diversity and inclusion but it appears to be just that.  I don't see very many diverse employees in upper management or sales roles.  Some managers don't know how to manage employees and are not held accountable.

headline: Great Place to Build the Foundation of a Successful Career
pros: I have been working at Schwab for a year now and I could not think of a better place to start in the financial world. They pay you to get your Series 7/63 licenses. Literally put you in a classroom and have you study for 5 weeks to get your licenses and they pay you for it. Advancement opportunities are everywhere. I don't know what these other people are talking about but since I started working there I have had the change to ghost with many other departments, which has opened up numerous doors for me. My manager has a one-on-one meeting with me at least once a month where we go over career pathing and things that I need to do my job better. The atmosphere is laid back, dress code is relaxed, and the salary is consistent = no stress to get commissions because we are not paid on commission. Everyday, I get into the office and look at the market and current events and have conversations with clients about whats driving the market and have conversations about investment strategy. Oh yeah, I also can place trades in my own account as long as I am not on the phone with a client. I'm looking to be able to advance into a Financial Consultant role in 3 years.
cons: I can only think of two cons. 1) It is a call center so you do take inbound phone calls. However, I have never taken more than 90 calls in a day and when I became a Broker I take about 50 calls. 2) The salary is mediocre. With that said, where else are you going to get paid to learn about the industry in a laid back environment? I have looked elsewhere and am happy that I am at Schwab.

headline: Rewarding
pros: Great benefits, sabbatical time off after every five years.
cons: Salary is not competitive compared to other brokerage firms

headline: It is employment
pros: Great benefits, solid company with good reputation. Young work team for the most part. Pleasent environment with good equipment and tools.
cons: No room for advancement, high turnover.  Have not seen advancement within team for almost three years.  A lot of promises, no results.  Pay is above poverty level.  HR person actually told a group "If you need to make more money you need to look elsewhere".  Churn and burn.

headline: The pay is fair and the experience is great.
pros: Fair Pay, Good Management and friendly work environment. Even the call center employees seem content. Overall a good place to work.
cons: No Investment Bank to advance to if one wants to go that route. On the sales side the pay seems to be capped.

headline: Call center burnout
pros:
Great place to learn the industry & get your Series 7/63 licenses
Pretty strong emphasis on training & equipping staff to handle wide variety of issues
For aggressive traders, learning Street Smart software was a great perk
cons:
Felt very micro-managed
Very quickly got burned out taking 80-110+ phone calls a day
Choosing to go the Active Investor route led to harder phone calls, less business leads uncovered, and ultimately stunted my progress

headline: Excellent overall.
pros: Fun, exciting, never boring, fast paced.
cons: A bit stressful, but in a good way.

headline: So Much Opportunity
pros: Very laid back office atmosphere, relaxed dress code, flexible hours, intelligent management, career advancement opportunities, etc. The company also pays for pursuing industry designations and is great about making sure there are enough sponsored events to keep up with CE credit requirements for those designations. They are very good about keeping you informed of your progress and I've experienced a very "open door" type atmosphere.
cons: Compared to the same position at other companies, the salary isn't the greatest but there are other things that make up for it in the benefits package. I did come from a much smaller company so the bureaucracy aspect took some getting use to. Even the slightest changes require a long time to implement and that can be frustrating; however, overall there isn't much negative I have to say about Schwab. I've been here for about a year and it's been fantastic.

headline: Great people, great hours, great place to work
pros: I loved working at Charles Schwab. I had a great team to work with and they were all creative and fun. There was also hardly any long hours or late nights and the pay was great.
cons:
You only really get to do Charles Schwab things versus a traditional agency where you might get to work on many clients. Some of the work can be a little boring. 

You can definitely tell you work at a large corporation. Nothing is decided quickly or easily as it always has to go up the chain of command with all the appropriate protocols followed.

headline: Great place to start out
pros: Great training and opportunities for career development. Most managers are very receptive to what you need in order to better do your job and genuinely want to see you succeed. There is a lot of transparency when it comes to performance - you will always know where you stand and what you could improve upon. Team environment allows you to utilize peers when you need help. The company is very focused on doing what is right for the client, and you don't feel pressured to get the client into unsuitable products. All in all a great place, especially to start out.
cons: The pay is not the greatest in the industry. With the center being open 24/7/365 you may have to work some holidays or off hours.

headline: Good
pros: Collegial work environment, standard benefits with a few extras (30 day paid sabbatical after 5 years), reasonably fair and capable management, opportunities for paid education and paid time off for charity work.
cons: Distributed organization so types of jobs are limited in the field (headquarters in San Francisco with regional call centers/operations centers in Denver, Phoenix, Indianapolis, Orlando).

headline: Full of Schwab Lifers with NO real work experience
pros:
Great place to coast
Decent salary for contract work
cons:
Inexperienced managers
Political
Disorganized
No resources available to perform reasonably

headline: Great way to get started
pros: Great culture with opportunities for additional education
cons: Not a lot of advancement opportunities

headline: Pay is 15-20 years behind pace.
pros: Liked the values of charity and the firm's ethics. Company is grabbing a large share of Financial Services business.
cons: Pay, pay, pay! Did I say pay? I can make more working 30 hours a week at a local steakhouse serving tables than using my multiple years experience answering a ton of calls chained to a desk with a bad backache everyday. Benefits are really expensive. No Christmas bonus ever. Not even a card. How cheap is that? Raises, even killing yourself, were stuck at a miserable 2% which got eaten up by higher costs for medical.

headline: Company will do anything for its employees except pay them.
pros: Good opportunity to learn the brokerage industry and do right by customers.  The firm will go to great lengths to preserve its brand in the face of retail customers.
cons: The firm is cheap, and pays its employees poorly overall.  Its also a large, rigid firm that is consistently a "last mover" when new opportunities arise.

headline: Best company to work for in the financial industry
pros: The pay is good, the ethics and values how they want to work wiith clients are how I envision, and great tools in helping client!
cons: Not enough training, and the work can be a little more on the service side than I would to do for clients

headline: Limited opportunities for IT workers, virtually no internal IT training
pros: Great employee benefits, respect for live-work balance, good salaries.  I still think Schwab has some of the best financial services available to the public.  Essentially, I learned how to successfully invest and manage my own money during my employment with the firm.
cons: The company is very slow to respond when it comes to updating technology within the enterprise.  Internal training programs for employees focus on business and banking skills and not on technology skills, so there is limited incentive for IT workers to stay.   Also, when key technology players leave the firm, there is no real plan in place to replace them.  This  means that the remaining staff end up inheriting more workload and stress, resulting in a domino effect as remaining employees become overwhelmed with the increased work load and  end up jumping ship as well.

headline: Settling with a mediocre salary, than this is the place for you!
pros: Awesome enviornment and work-life balance. Offer work from home for mid to senior level employees and alternative schedules.
cons: Terrible "total rewards" pay structure, which limits employees to no more than a 2% raise annually. Schwab does not pay to retain talent, but creates a culture of "turn and burn" with their employees. Also, if you are promoted, which I have been 3 times and within 3 pay ranges, you will be paid 1% over the minimum salary range. No negiotiations or compromise by leadership on salaries. Again if you are looking to increase your salary by climbing the corporate ladder, please look else where.

headline: Great company
pros: Charles Schwab is a great company to work for. There are many avenues for growth and internal promotion. Senior leadership lives out the vision and values. They are fair.
cons: As Charles Schwab service centers are open 24/7/365, you are required to work some holidays throughout the year. There are many teams that work late evenings and/or weekends as well.

headline: Great colleagues but lack of promotion opportunities
pros:
Great colleagues
Collaborative culture
Challenging projects
Financially conservative
cons:
lack of promotion opportunities
bonunses have been reduced
small annual increases

headline: A good company to provide newer investors to varied investments and advice platforms.
pros: Great opportunities for business development with existing clients.
cons: Difficult at times to concentrate on business development activities, servicing many clients with little administrative support.

headline: Tumultous, I would discourage anyone from working on the Bank side.
author_position: Schwab Bank Customer Service Representative (Call Center)
pros: Having Schwab on the resume is beneficial and the benefits are generous with lots of vacation and sick time available.
cons: Generally, working for Charles Schwab might be good for most people. If you work on the bank side, it is a miserable place to work. The technology is in the dark ages, so are the services Schwab Bank offfers it's clients. The debit cards often don't work because of Schwab's conservative approach to risk management. Clients are always calling in because their debit cards don't work. Also, internal employees at Schwab always call bank for the wrong reasons. They act like Bank is the help desk if they don't know the answer to something related to their job. They never use internal resources such as the help desk for their department or the internal search engine. There is a "when in doubt, call bank" mentality. Also, the pay on the bank side is subpar for the work that is required of us and the more than 20 different systems we had to use.

headline: The cleanest place in a dirty industry
pros:
Company is committed to the client and to doing the right thing
You are not forced to sell any products to the clients, unless you are a branch financial consultant. Even then, anything you are "selling" is only if it is in the best interests of the client.
cons: Unless you want to work in the branch, you are severely limited in locations you can live and work in

headline: If you're not ready to settle for less, keep your resume handy.
pros:
- Good work life balance (you can almost get away with doing nothing)
- Good benefits
- Usually friendly people
cons:
- Compensation/Incentives package highly prohibitive (if you are towards the bottom of the pay range, you'll never catch your peers towards the upper end of the spectrum, regardless of how hard you work.  The program favors the company.)
- Promotions into management nearly impossible unless you are one of the chosen few.  Career paths have been defined and leadership development programs exist, but don't lead to growth opportunities.
- Middle management filled with yes men, don't expect your boss to set up to bat for you.
- Absence of mentoring and guidance to help individuals develop their skills and prepare for the next step of their career.  Classes offered by Schwab's training department, but again don't lead to positive outcomes for employees.
- Management prescribes to the philosophy that engaged and happy employees will work for lower pay because of high job satisfaction.  They forget a large number of employees are supporting families on less than $50K a year, which is pretty tough - I guess money isn't everything but it is pretty important when you practically live paycheck to paycheck.
- Not a growth company, resulting in limited growth opportunities and directions to move your career.
- Hiring managers are often unresponsive to internal applicant's request for informational interviews. 
- Knowledge, skill, and abilities, get you nowhere; to be successful you need to communicate with force, confidence, and the assumption you are right (it is more important to be right than to do the right thing).
- Schwab is a classic bureaucracy, very conservative and risk averse.
- Recognition and appreciation are trivial and on the verge of insulting, unless you are in second grade.

headline: Educational
pros: great place to get licenses and learn about the industry.
cons: Compensation needs to improve to keep talent.

headline: Solid company with great people.
pros: Smart, well-rounded people.  Management was great, and I appreciated the consistent feedback in regard to job performance.  I highly recommend them.
cons: My training session was abbreviated, and you are committed to stay in the position for a minimum of 18 months before being able to apply elsewhere.

headline: Maybe ok for some, but not my cup of tea.
pros: Close to home. Nice campus. Most peers seems nice and very willing to help out. Really my peers were the best part of the job. Some people dont mind call center jobs, this on is probably better because of no outbound calls.
cons: As Im sure you heard salary is ridiculously low and very little other incentitives. Its a promotion if you take a lateral move with no pay increase. Unhealthy static work environment as you are tied to your desk and phone for 98% of the day taking call after call . 30 min lunch. Expensive and nasty cafeteria. It's a cost/call center where efficincy is the priority. Pay will always be low and every ounce of producitvity will be squeezed from you.

headline: High stress
pros: To get your broker training paid for and to gain experience. If you can handle this environment you can work anywhere.
cons: Pay is terrible. Work is stressful. Answering phones all day makes you feel as though you are chained to your desk and isolated. Management shows no appreciation for the work you do.

headline: Great opportunity to learn about how corporations operate
pros: Founder vision is to make financial opportunities available to everyone, executive culture reflects that vision.  Compensation is good compared to other similar jobs.  Lots of opportunities to move sideways.
cons: Operating efficiency programs have led to short term decisions, and some less than stellar offerings.  Constant pressure to only deliver wins.

headline: Extremely positive
pros: Good opportunity for career advancement; caring work environment; company is going in the right direction and positioning itself for continued growth; good benefits; decent pay
cons: Depending on part of the country you live in, career mobility/advancement  can be limited; pay could be better;

headline: Neutral
pros: Opportunity to grow and obtain additional experience and licenses.
cons: Salary is very low.  Difficult to achieve additional salary as overtime is limited and reps are not paid any commissions.

headline: good development opportunitites
pros: development, good managers, great co-workers, opportunitites to get your securities licences, you will become a great communicator, positive attitude from managers and co workers
cons: compensation, hours not very flexible, depending on your position, work itself can be tedious

headline: Great until a poor manager forced several to find other jobs
pros: Many opportunities for growth at schw
cons:
Trouble with stock price.
Listen to employees

headline: As a temp employee, I have greatly enjoyed my time here.
pros: I like my supervisor and the people I work with and would like to stay; however, my temp assignement is ending at the end of December.  The company has provided me with a very good salary and working conditions are excellent.  The office/building are first rate, though a significant walk to BART.  I have been free to work my own hours, and my supervisor is not a micro-manager.  She is content to let me work on proejcts at my own speed in any manner I want.  All in all, it has been a pleaser to work here.
cons: I have applied for several permanent jobs at Schwab, but, unfortunately, with no job offer coming.  It is very frustrating to read the job posting requirements, have the experience and the requirements they are looking for, and then not get the job.  I really feel like after three months here, I have learned the job, and I wish they could open a requisition and keep me.  Just as I am really beginning to learn the job's requirements and functions, I will be leaving.  Does not make sense to me.
